questions.text: 1. A 60-year-old man working in a factory for the past 30 years presents with dyspnea and cough due to chronic exposure to a particular mineral agent. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy shows characteristic golden brown bodies with beaded and knobbed ends. All of the following are caused by exposure to this agent, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing golden-brown asbestos bodies with knobbed or beaded ends is due to asbestos exposure. All of the given conditions are caused by exposure to asbestos except anthracosis. Anthracosis is a coal-induced pulmonary lesion seen in coal miners, urban dwellers, and tobacco smokers.

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung that occurs due to asbestos exposure. The disease usually manifests after a minimum of 10 years of exposure. Asbestos-related diseases include:

* Localised fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis

* Recurrent pleural effusions

* Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis 

* Lung carcinoma

* Mesotheliomas

* Laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas

* Increased risks for systemic autoimmune diseases

Clinically, dyspnea and cough can be seen. They can progress to respiratory failure, cor pulmonale, and even death. Chest radiograph can show irregular linear densities in the lower lobes, and in late stages, can show a honeycomb pattern.

Histopathology shows diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and asbestos bodies. These appear as golden brown fusiform or rod-shaped beaded structures with a translucent centre that is made of asbestos fibres coated by a proteinaceous material. They arise when asbestos gets phagocytosed by macrophages. Iron-protein complexes may coat other inorganic particulate matter to form ferruginous bodies.

The image below shows asbestos bodies.

questions.text:
2. A 10-year-old child presents with extensive petechiae and purpura. Platelet count is 1.2 lakh/mm³. PT and aPTT are normal. Platelet aggregation studies are normal with ADP, collagen, and epinephrine. However, on ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation, there is no aggregation, and it does not correct with the addition of normal plasma.
What is the most likely underlying defect?
questions.solution:
This is a classic presentation of Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a defect in the GPIb-IX-V complex, which is required for platelet adhesion via binding to vWF.

In ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation (RIPA), normally, vWF binds to GPIb, and aggregation occurs. In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, GPIb is defective, so ristocetin cannot induce aggregation. Adding normal plasma (which contains vWF) does not help, because the receptor is defective.

Other options: 

Option A: In von Willebrand disease, vWF is deficient, so aggregation is also defective with ristocetin, but corrects with the addition of normal plasma.

Option B:  GPIIb/IIIa deficiency (Glanzmann thrombasthenia) causes defective aggregation with ADP, collagen, and thrombin, but normal ristocetin aggregation.

Option D: In Factor VIII deficiency, there is prolonged aPTT due to impaired intrinsic pathway, but platelet function and ristocetin aggregation are normal.

questions.text: 3. A patient presents with visual impairment. On fundoscopy, you notice dark streaks having irregular, serrated edges and radiating outwards from the peripapillary area. Your professor explains it to you as breaks in a calcified Bruch's membrane. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes angioid streaks. 

Angioid streaks are breaks in a brittle, thinned-out, and calcified Bruch's membrane; they are associated with the atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

Angioid streaks are associated with the following:

* Pseudoxanthoma elasticum—most common condition associated: Since it is a connective tissue disorder, all the elastic fibres in the body are affected, including those in Bruch's membrane.

* Paget disease: Metabolic bone disorder is thought to cause these streaks by calcium binding to the elastin of Bruch's membrane, imparting brittleness and fragility.

* Hemoglobinopathies such as sickle cell trait and disease and thalassemia: In these conditions, iron deposition imparts brittleness to Bruch's membrane.

Signs associated with angioid streaks include a greyish to dark red streak on fundoscopy radiating outwards from the peripapillary area. These streaks have irregular, serrated edges.

Treatment includes observation. If choroidal neovascularization develops, then intravitreal anti-VEGF drugs are preferred.

Other options:

Option B: Choroidal folds are horizontal parallel grooves or striae on the inner choroid, Bruch's membrane, and retinal pigment epithelium. They usually occur on the posterior pole. These folds develop as a result of choroidal congestion and scleral compression. They may be idiopathic, or they may be caused by conditions like papilledema, retroorbital and choroidal tumours, or inflammations like posterior scleritis.

Option C: Lattice retinal degeneration is a type of retinal degeneration associated with breaks in the retina. It is characterised by white arborising lines arranged in a lattice pattern. It is associated with retinal thinning and abnormal pigmentation.

Option D: Stargardt disease is a juvenile macular dystrophy. Fundus examination initially is normal but can subsequently show beaten-bronze or snail-slime reflex in the macular area.

questions.text: 4. A patient suspected of having leishmaniasis is tested by culturing a sample in an artificial medium. What stage of the organism's life cycle will be detected in the cultured sample?
questions.solution:
Promastigote will be detected in the cultured sample.

In leishmaniasis, the promastigote form is detected upon culturing in artificial media such as NNN (Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle) medium and Schneider's liquid medium.

Leishmania donovani exists in two forms: the amastigote form (found in humans and other mammals) and the promastigote form (found in the sandfly and artificial culture). The definitive hosts are man, dog, and other mammals, and the vector is a female sandfly. Promastigotes are infective forms to man. 

Culture on NNN medium and Schneider’s liquid medium is useful for detecting promastigotes, as well as for species identification and drug sensitivity testing. Promastigotes develop from amastigotes when cultured and are detected via Giemsa staining. In the promastigote form, the kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end, and a single flagellum is seen.



The lifecycle of Leishmania is shown below.



Other options: 

Option A: The amastigote form (Leishman-Donovan body) is intracellular and found inside macrophages, monocytes, or reticuloendothelial cells. A kinetoplast is present, which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent. Demonstration of amastigotes inside macrophages is the gold standard method for the diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis.



Option C and D: Epimastigote and Trypomastigote forms are not seen in Leishmania.

questions.text: 5. An 8-month-old male infant is found to have bilateral renal masses. The infant had an omphalocele, macroglossia and macrosomia at birth. Which of the following is the genetic basis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This infant presenting with bilateral renal masses, and history of omphalocele, macroglossia, and macrosomia at birth, most likely has Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, which occurs due to genomic imprinting.

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is characterized by neonatal hypoglycemia, macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, visceromegaly and embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and neuroblastoma.

The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is the WT2 locus in chromosome 11 (band p15.5) distal to the WT1 locus. This region contains multiple genes that are normally expressed from only one of the two parental alleles, with silencing (imprinting) of the other. IGF2 gene abnormalities have the strongest correlation to the development of tumors. Loss of maternal imprinting of IGF2 and uniparental paternal disomy of IGF2 are 2 pathways that can cause overexpression of IGF2 thus leading to tumorigenesis.

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Other presentations of Wilm's tumor include hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture, causing an acute abdomen. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs. On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

Other options: 

Option A: Mosaicism is the phenomenon where a single organism possesses more than one genetic line as a result of genetic mutation.

Option B: Anticipation is the phenomenon where symptoms become more severe and/or appear at an earlier age as the disorder is passed from one generation to the next.

Option D: Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair can lead to Xeroderma pigmentosum.

questions.text: 6. A 52-year-old man presents to your clinic with fatigue, low-grade fever, and night sweats for the past 3 months. He also complains of mild joint pain and easy bruising. He mentions having had a dental extraction around the time his symptoms began. Past history includes a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. Fundoscopic examination reveals Roth spots. Which of the following laboratory results accurately describes the most likely organism involved?
questions.solution:
The presence of low-grade symptoms with insidious onset and Roth spots, along with a history of recent dental extraction in a patient with MI, is suggestive of subacute bacterial endocarditis. The most likely organism implicated in this patient is Streptococcus viridans. It shows alpha hemolysis and optochin resistance.

Subacute endocarditis is a type of infective endocarditis that usually occurs in a previously damaged heart (e.g., scarred or deformed valves), and the implicated organisms are of low virulence (e.g., viridans streptococci, HACEK organisms). Viridans streptococci are part of normal oral flora and can enter the bloodstream during chewing, brushing, or dental procedures, leading to transient bacteremia. They are the most common cause of subacute bacterial endocarditis. 

Infective endocarditis (IE) refers to microbial invasion of the heart valves or mural endocardium resulting in the formation of bulky friable vegetations, composed of platelets, fibrin, microcolonies of organisms, and scanty inflammatory cells. Acute IE rapidly damages the cardiac structures and spreads to extracardiac sites, frequently involving a highly virulent organism (e.g., S. aureus) attacking a previously normal valve.

The cardiac manifestations include the appearance of a new/worsened regurgitant murmur. Non-cardiac manifestations include fever, chills and sweats, anorexia, weight loss, arthralgia, arterial emboli, splenomegaly, clubbing, petechiae, neurologic manifestations, and peripheral manifestations (Osler’s nodes, Janeway lesions, subungual haemorrhages). ™

Laboratory manifestations such as anemia, leucocytosis, microscopic hematuria, elevated ESR, CRP, or rheumatoid factor can be seen. Diagnosis is made using Modified Duke's criteria.

Pearl PM2026: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

* Pathologic criteria

* Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.



Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

* Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR

* If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: 7. A newborn baby is vaccinated against tuberculosis disease. All of the following are true about the vaccine except:

choices.text: The dose given at birth is 0.05 ml
Distilled water is preferred for reconstitution

questions.solution:
For reconstitution of the BCG Vaccine, normal saline is recommended, as the use of distilled water may cause local tissue irritation.

The BCG (Bacillus Calmette–Guérin) vaccine is primarily used for the prevention of tuberculosis (TB). It offers protection against severe forms of childhood TB, including tuberculous meningitis, and contributes to reducing morbidity and mortality from primary TB infections.

BCG is the only live bacterial vaccine currently in use. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the use of the Danish 1331 strain for its production.

There are two forms of the BCG vaccine available:

* Liquid (fresh) vaccine

* Freeze-dried (lyophilized) vaccine

The freeze-dried vaccine is the preferred formulation due to its greater stability and longer shelf life (Option B). It is currently the standard form distributed globally. Once reconstituted, the vaccine must be used within 3 hours.

The standard dosage for vaccination is 0.1 mg in 0.1 ml. However, for newborns less than 4 weeks of age (Option A), the dose is reduced to 0.05 ml. The vaccine is administered intradermally (Option C), typically over the left deltoid region, using a tuberculin syringe.

Following vaccination, a papule usually develops at the injection site within 2 to 3 weeks, gradually enlarging and potentially forming a shallow ulcer by around 5 weeks. This lesion typically heals spontaneously within 6 to 12 weeks, leaving behind a small, round scar measuring approximately 4–8 mm in diameter. Most individuals develop a positive Mantoux reaction within 8 to 14 weeks of vaccination.

Potential complications include:

* Prolonged or severe ulceration at the injection site

* Suppurative lymphadenitis

* Osteomyelitis

* Disseminated BCG infection in rare cases

The BCG vaccine is contraindicated in individuals with:

* Generalized eczema or other infectious dermatoses

* Hypogammaglobulinemia

* Immunodeficiency states

* Pregnancy

questions.text: 8. An immunologist is conducting an experiment involving precipitation reactions between antigens and antibodies. Which of the following zones is suitable for optimal precipitation?
questions.solution:
The zone of equivalence shows optimal precipitation.

According to the Lattice hypothesis, precipitation occurs when an antigen and antibody bind to form a lattice. This is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies.

When the precipitation reactions are plotted on a graph, it reveals the following:

* Prozone phenomenon: Weak or even absent precipitation due to excessive antibodies in the test system.

* Zone of equivalence: Antigen and antibody are in optimum proportions, and the most optimal precipitation occurs due to lattice formation. Lattice formation and visible reactions get enhanced

* Post–zone phenomenon: Precipitation is absent due to excessive antigen in the test system.



Other options:

Option D: When, instead of sedimenting, the precipitate remains suspended as a floculus, then the reaction is known as flocculation.

questions.text:
9. A 45-year-old male diagnosed with HIV is on an antiretroviral regimen including Lopinavir/Ritonavir. The treating physician ordered a lipid profile, the results of which are given below. Which of the following drugs is preferred for the management?

Total Cholesterol: 260 mg/dL (Normal < 200 mg/dL) LDL: 180 mg/dL (Normal < 130 mg/dL) HDL: 45 mg/dL (Normal > 40 mg/dL) Triglycerides: 150 mg/dL (Normal < 150 mg/dL)
questions.solution:
The best drug to treat hypercholesterolemia in a patient on a Lopinavir/Ritonavir (protease inhibitor) based antiretroviral regimen is Pravastatin.

Dyslipidemia (elevated cholesterol and triglycerides) is a significant side effect of protease inhibitors. Protease inhibitors, such as Lopinavir/Ritonavir, are metabolized by CYP3A4, and ritonavir is a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor. Many statins are metabolized by CYP3A4, increasing the risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis when used concomitantly with protease inhibitors.

Pravastatin is hydrophilic, minimally metabolized by CYP enzymes, and has low potential for drug interactions. It has an LDL-cholesterol-lowering effect, making it suitable for this patient’s hypercholesterolemia. Other statins that can be used include fluvastatin which is metabolized by CYP2C9, while rosuvastatin which is minimally metabolized and is not significantly dependent on CYP enzymes.

Other options:

Options A and B: Atorvastatin and simvastatin are metabolized by CYP3A4. Hence, this is not the best choice for the patient.

Option C: Gemfibrozil, a fibrate, is primarily indicated for hypertriglyceridemia. This patient’s lipid profile shows elevated total cholesterol and LDL with borderline triglycerides, making gemfibrozil less suitable in this patient.

questions.text: 10. The plateau of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve signifies ______

choices.text: No Hb is available for binding
No oxygen is available for binding

questions.solution:
The plateau phase of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (OHDC) represents the region where hemoglobin is nearly fully saturated with oxygen, typically around 97–100%.

At this stage, all four heme groups on each hemoglobin molecule are bound to oxygen. This high level of saturation reflects the maximum oxygen affinity of hemoglobin, enhanced by positive cooperativity, a mechanism by which the binding of one oxygen molecule increases the likelihood of subsequent oxygen molecules binding. This cooperative binding accounts for the sigmoidal shape of the OHDC.

The plateau region, corresponding to a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂) between 60 and 100 mm Hg, represents the conditions in the pulmonary capillaries, where oxygen is being loaded onto hemoglobin. In this range, even moderate decreases in PaO₂ result in minimal changes in oxygen saturation, providing a physiological buffer that ensures efficient oxygen loading even under conditions such as mild hypoxia or reduced atmospheric oxygen.

In contrast, the steep portion of the curve, occurring at PaO₂ values between 0 and 60 mm Hg, reflects the situation in systemic capillaries, where hemoglobin releases oxygen to tissues. In this range, small decreases in oxygen pressure lead to significant oxygen unloading, which is essential for meeting the metabolic demands of active tissues, where both oxygen levels and hemoglobin affinity are lower.

The image below shows the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve.

questions.text: 11. After an antigen is presented to a Naive T-cell, what other receptor interaction is required to activate the T Cell?
questions.solution:
B7 and CD28 receptor interaction is required to activate the T Cell.

CD80 (B7-1) and CD86 (B7-2) are the costimulatory molecules present on antigen-presenting cells (APCs). They bind to the CD28 protein present on T cells. This promotes the expansion of antigen-stimulated T cells and their differentiation into effector and memory cells.

T-cell activation requires two signals that are delivered by APCs. They include:

* Antigens displayed by APCs in the form of peptides bound to MHC molecules, which are recognised by T-cell receptors

* Costimulatory signal (as it stimulates T cells in conjunction with antigen) provided by molecules on APCs that engage particular costimulatory receptors on T cells

In the absence of costimulation, T cells that recognise an antigen either fail to respond and die or enter a state of unresponsiveness known as anergy. Thus, costimulation is a key determinant of the outcome of a T-cell encounter with an antigen.

questions.text: 12. A histological slide is shown to medical students. The type of cartilage depicted in the given slide stained with Trichrome-Masson stain is seen in _______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a section of fibrocartilage stained with Trichrome - Masson stain. It is seen in the acetabular labrum.

Fibrocartilage is an intermediate between dense fibrous connective tissue (tendon and ligaments) and hyaline cartilage. It consists of bundles of collagen fibres (both type I and II) with rows of chondrocytes present between the bundles. They are not covered by perichondrium.

Fibrocartilage is found in:

* Intervertebral discs

* Pubic symphysis

* Manubriosternal joint

* Menisci of the knee

* Glenoid and acetabular labra

* Lining of the bony grooves for tendons

* Articular disc of temporomandibular and sternoclavicular joint

On microscopy, fibrocartilage can be identified by:

* Presence of chondrocytes

* Matrix containing abundant collagen fibres

 Other options:

Option A: Arytenoid cartilages, except its apices, are mainly composed of hyaline cartilage.

Option C and D: Auricle (pinna) and apices of the arytenoid cartilages are composed of elastic cartilage.

Note: The colour of cartilage should not be considered while deciding its type, as it largely depends on the type of stain used. Instead, the structure or organisation of the cartilage tissue should be considered.



The 3 types of cartilage are Hyaline cartilage, elastic cartilage, and fibrocartilage. 

* Hyaline cartilage (except the subtype of articular cartilage) and elastic cartilage have perichondrium

* Fibrocartilage does not have perichondrium.

questions.text:
13. Which of the following head injuries are correctly matched to the type of delivery that causes them?

* Vacuum-assisted delivery - Cephalohaematoma

* Prolonged labour - Epidural haemorrhage

* Injudicious use of oxytocin- Subgaleal haemorrhage

* Forceps delivery- Cephalohaematoma

* Prolonged labour- Caput succedaneum
questions.solution:
1, 4, and 5 are the correct statements.

In prolonged labour, before complete cervical dilatation, the portion of the fetal scalp immediately over the cervical os becomes edematous. A swelling is formed due to fluid stagnation in the layers of the scalp beneath the girdle of contact. This is known as caput succedaneum. The swelling is diffuse, boggy, and not limited by the suture lines. No treatment is required as it resolves spontaneously within one week after birth.

Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal haemorrhage. It occurs following instrumental delivery. It does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. Most cephalohematomas are resorbed within 3 to 4 weeks, depending on their size.

Subgaleal haemorrhage is a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It occurs mostly in vacuum-assisted deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can occur in hereditary coagulopathies and is associated with skull fractures. There can be severe blood loss leading to hypovolemia and shock.

Epidural haemorrhage is usually traumatic in origin. Blood collects between the inner skull and the dura mater. It is usually associated with fractured skull bone following difficult instrumental delivery. It does not always need surgical intervention, but needs monitoring with serial imaging rare in newborns.

questions.text: 14. Identify the instrument and its use:
questions.solution:
The image shows Cheatle’s forceps, and it is used to pick sterilised instruments. 

Cheatle’s forceps is used to pick sterilised articles like instruments or drapes, so that touching of the sterilised instruments is avoided while transferring them onto the surgical table. Cheatle’s forceps is kept dipped in antiseptic solutions, and it does not have a lock.

Other options:

Option B: Kocher’s hemostatic forceps has opposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades. It is used to hold tough structures, pedicles, cut ends of muscles, ribs during rib dissection, hold gauze for blunt dissection, and hold resected bowel.



Option C: Allis’ tissue holding forceps is identified by the toothed tips, which are apposing. There is a lock in the proximal part, and the distal blades do not appose each other. It is used to hold skin flaps, fasciae, aponeurosis and bladder wall. The image below shows Allis’ tissue holding forceps:



Option D: Babcock’s forceps are used to hold tubular structures like the ureter, bowel loops, fallopian tubes and the appendix. The distal part of the blades is curved with a triangular fenestra in it, which allows the soft tissues to bulge out. The tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations on it. There is a lock in the proximal part.

questions.text:
15. A 65-year-old woman presented with gradually increasing shortness of breath over the past 6 months. Examination reveals finger clubbing and bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function test (PFT) reports are given below. Which of the following is the next investigation to determine the cause of her dyspnea?

FEV1: 65% predicted FVC: 67% predicted FEV1/FVC ratio: 74% TLC: 68% predicted DLCO: 62% predicted

choices.text: High-resolution CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic shortness of breath, finger clubbing, and fine inspiratory crackles, spirometry showing a restrictive defect and reduced lung volumes points to a diagnosis of interstitial lung disease. This is seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). High-resolution CT scan of the chest is the next investigation to determine the cause of her dyspnea.

Interstitial lung diseases are characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is similar. The patients are usually over 60 years of age and present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO which may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder that might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern. Note that extensive ground-glass opacities should raise suspicion for an alternative diagnosis.

The treatment of IPF is with antifibrotic therapy such as pirfenidone and nintedanib.

Other options:

Option A: Bronchoscopy with transbronchial lung biopsy is not the first-line investigation when HRCT is available.

Option B: CT pulmonary angiography is used for acute pulmonary embolism, and is not helpful in chronic, progressive dyspnea.

Option D: Echocardiography assesses cardiac function and pulmonary pressures, but does not evaluate lung parenchyma.

questions.text: 16. A 26-year-old nursing mother presents with pain in her left breast. She has had difficulty with breastfeeding previously, and now examination reveals that her left breast is warm, red, swollen, and painful to palpation. Her temperature is 38.3 degrees and the WBC count is 13000/mm3. What is the first line of treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of pain, redness, warmth, and tenderness in the breast, along with fever and leucocytosis, is suggestive of mastitis. Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers.

Mastitis refers to infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The infection is usually unilateral, with the source of infection being the bacteria residing in the infant's nose and throat. The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus, which can be cultured from breast milk. The symptoms appear in the 3rd or 4th week postpartum. Predisposing factors include fissures, abrasions, or cracks in the nipple. 

The first line of treatment is dicloxacillin, 500 mg orally, 4 times a day for 10-14 days. Other beta-lactamase-resistant penicillins that are recommended include cloxacillin and flucloxacillin. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.

If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing staphylococci or if resistant organisms are suspected while awaiting the culture results, then vancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given. 

Breastfeeding should be continued. Sometimes the infant may not nurse on the inflamed breast due to engorgement and edema, which makes the areola harder to grip. Pumping alleviates this. When nursing bilaterally, suckling is best started on the uninvolved breast. This allows let-down to commence before moving to the tender breast.

In HIV patients with mastitis or breast abscess, even in resource-poor countries, it is recommended to stop feeding from the infected breast because HIV RNA levels increase in affected breast milk. These levels return to baseline after symptoms resolve.

questions.text: 17. During the ward rounds, the consultant posts the following patients for certain procedures. In which of these patients would you expect a higher chance of surgical-site infection?

choices.text: Patient posted for elective Nissen fundoplication
Patient posted for elective orthopedic arthroscopy

questions.solution:
The patient posted for elective Nissen fundoplication (option B), indicating a clean-contaminated wound has a higher chance of surgical site infection rate among all the other options provided. All other options are categorized as clean wounds.

Class I (Clean wounds):  These have the lowest risk of surgical-site infection. They occur in procedures with no inflammation. The respiratory, GI, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered.

Examples:

* Elective herniorrhaphy is a clean wound categorized as class I (as the prosthetic mesh is placed)

* Elective splenectomy is a clean wound categorized as class I

* Elective orthopedic arthroscopy is also categorized under Class I Clean wounds.

Class II (Clean-contaminated wounds): These wounds are created in procedures involving the respiratory, digestive, genital, or urinary systems in a controlled way. It must be without notable contamination.

Examples:

* Elective cholecystectomy

* Elective gastrointestinal surgeries (e.g., fundoplication)

Class III (Contaminated wounds): These include:

* Recent open or accidental wounds

* Procedures with major breaches in sterile technique 

* Substantial GI spillage

* Surgical sites with acute, non-purulent inflammation 

Class IV (Dirty wounds): These comprise:

* Old traumatic wounds with devitalized tissue.

* Wounds with active infection

* Perforated internal organs

questions.text: 18. Gestational hypertension is defined as hypertension in pregnancy
questions.solution:
Gestational hypertension is defined as hypertension after 20 weeks without proteinuria.

Gestational hypertension is defined as a sustained rise of blood pressure to 140/90 mm Hg or more (without proteinuria) on at least two occasions, 4 or more hours apart, beyond the 20th week of pregnancy or within the first 48 hours of delivery in a previously normotensive woman.

questions.text: 19. A 9-year-old child was evaluated for night blindness. Ophthalmoscopy showed atrophic changes in the choroid, retina, and pigment epithelium. Urine and plasma ornithine levels were elevated. Defective catabolism of which of the following amino acids led to this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of essential/ gyrate atrophy of the choroid. This is due to the defective catabolism of arginine.

Gyrate atrophy is an autosomal recessive condition and is caused by a mutation in the OAT gene (chromosome 10q) that encodes the main ornithine degradation enzyme, ornithine aminotransferase. Catabolism of arginine involves the conversion of arginine to ornithine, followed by the transamination of ornithine to glutamate-γ-semialdehyde by ornithine δ-aminotransferase. Mutations in ornithine δ-aminotransferase cause elevated plasma and urinary ornithine levels, which lead to gyrate atrophy of the choroid and retina.

The patient presents with myopia and nyctalopia in adolescence, with a subsequent gradual worsening of vision. Fundus angography shows a sharp demarcation between areas of choroidal atrophy and normal choriocapillaris. ERG is subnormal in early disease but later becomes diminished. Treatment involves restricting dietary arginine.

questions.text: 20. You would suspect the presence of publication bias in a meta-analysis if you notice:
questions.solution:
The presence of an asymmetric funnel plot would indicate publication bias in a meta-analysis.

Pearl PM1148: Funnel Plots

* A funnel plot is basically a scatter plot of individual studies which are used in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. It plots their precisions and results.

* In a funnel plot, each dot represents an individual study.

* The y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision and the x-axis is the outcome, usually the odds ratio.

* Higher powered studies are placed towards the top and the lower powered ones towards the bottom such that the plot resembles an inverted funnel or a pyramid.

* This shape is expected as different studies have different standard errors and other estimates.

* A symmetrical funnel plot is shown in Fig. A. in the image below.

* These funnel plots are used in meta-analysis to check for bias like publication bias or other reporting bias.

* In the case of bias being present, an asymmetrical funnel plot results, as shown in Fig. B. of the image below.



Pearl PM1149: Forest Plot

* A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.

* It is also called blobbogram.



Interpretation of forest plots: 

* The rectangles represent the single studies

* The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size

* The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results

* The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 

* The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not

* A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged

* Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.

* The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 



* For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.

* For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.solution:

questions.text: 22. The table shows the examination findings of various psychiatric emergencies presenting with fever and altered sensorium. Which of the following is corresponding to the findings seen in serotonin syndrome?
questions.solution:
The findings in Table 2 correspond to Serotonin syndrome.  

Serotonin syndrome is a serious condition occurring due to serotonin overstimulation. Clinical features include diarrhea, restlessness, agitation, hyperreflexia, autonomic instability with fluctuations in vital signs, myoclonus, seizures, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, rigidity, delirium, coma, status epilepticus, cardiovascular collapse, and death. 

It can occur with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels, like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), dextromethorphan, etc.

It is treated with cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist). 

Other options:

Option A: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a rare condition that occurs on administration of neuroleptic (antipsychotic) drugs. It presents with autonomic instability, hyperpyrexia, rigidity, and delirium. Sustained rigidity leads to muscle breakdown and elevated creatinine kinase levels.

NMS will not show the hyperreflexia and clonus seen in serotonin syndrome. The causative drug should be stopped immediately and treatment can be started with dantrolene and bromocriptine.

Option C: Anticholinergic syndrome can occur due to concurrent use or use of higher doses of strong anticholinergic drugs like cyproheptadine or diphenhydramine. It will present with anticholinergic symptoms like blurring of vision, dry mouth, constipation, etc. Hyperreflexia and hypertonia would not be seen in this condition. 

Option D: Malignant hyperthermia is seen in the setting of neuromuscular blockade administration in the operating room, such as succinylcholine. It presents with elevated body temperature, muscle rigidity, hypotension, muscle breakdown, etc. The drug of choice to treat this condition is intravenous dantrolene.

questions.text: 23. A condition in autism spectrum with normal intelligence and normal language development is:
questions.solution:
Asperger’s syndrome is a form of autism spectrum disorder characterized by significant difficulties in social interaction and restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, but without any delay in language or cognitive development. It is more commonly seen in boys and is considered a milder form of autism, often referred to as "high-functioning autism."

Other options:

Option C: Heller’s syndrome (Childhood Disintegrative Disorder) usually appears between 3 and 5 years of age. A child who was developing normally suddenly loses skills in areas like language, social interaction, and movement. This decline is often followed by signs of neurological problems.

questions.text: 24. A young woman presents with fatigue, diarrhoea, and weight loss. She reports that the stool is bulky, pale, and foul-smelling. On examination, she has pallor and itchy rashes on her elbows, as shown below. Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are noted to be positive. Which of the following is not a typical manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is consistent with celiac disease/celiac sprue/gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Hypersplenism is not a typical manifestation of this condition. Hyposplenism is a typical manifestation. 

The image shows grouped erythematous papules and vesicles over the elbow. This is dermatitis herpetiformis, the cutaneous manifestation of celiac disease. It generally presents on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. These lesions are intensely pruritic and occur due to IgA deposits in dermal papillae.

Celiac disease is characterized by autoantibodies to tissue transglutaminase , leading to an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria and impairs nutrient absorption. Gluten is commonly found in wheat, barley, and rye. 

It is characterized by:

* Gastrointestinal manifestations such as bloating and irregular bowel habits. There is villous atrophy in the proximal intestine, causing steatorrhea (bulky, pale, and foul-smelling) as well as fluid hypersecretion from crypt epithelium. 

* Other manifestations: 

* Dermatitis herpetiformis - pruritic papules and vesicles on the extensor surfaces of the limbs

* Deficiency of vitamin B12 and vitamin E causes ataxia and peripheral neuropathy

* Iron-deficiency anaemia (Option B)

* Hyposplenism due to excessive loss of lymphocytes through inflamed intestinal mucosa, leading to the spleen’s reticuloendothelial atrophy.

* Abnormal liver enzymes

* Increased risk of malignancy, such as enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma (Option C) and small-bowel adenocarcinoma (Option D).

* Refractory celiac disease 

Screening for celiac disease is done by testing for tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deamidated anti-gliadin antibodies. Diagnosis is confirmed by small-intestinal biopsy, which shows characteristic villus blunting and crypt hyperplasia and inflammation. Given below is a histopathological image of celiac disease:



Treatment of celiac disease involves strict avoidance of gluten.

Note: The question has been updated from 'extraintestinal manifestation' to 'typical manifestation'

questions.text: 25. A 12-year-old weighing 40kg boy came in contact with a high-tension power line while flying a kite. He was severely burned, involving many parts of the body, with a total burn surface area of 60%. He presented in the emergency department, and you want to start fluid resuscitation after taking 2 wide-bore cannulas. Calculate the total fluid with which resuscitation is to be started.
questions.solution:
9.6 L of Lactated Ringer’s solution is the total fluid with which resuscitation is to be started.

In electrical burn for all ages, the total fluid required (in mL) is calculated as 4 x body weight (in kg) x %Total burn surface area.

Given weight: 40 kg and TBSA burned: 60%, hence fluid required is 4 x 40 x 60 = 9,600 ml (or 9.6 L). One-half of that volume (4.8 L) should be provided in the first 8 hours. The remaining one-half of the total fluid is administered during the subsequent 16 hours.

The current fluid of choice for burn resuscitation is Lactated Ringer’s solution as it most closely replicates the osmolality of plasma, and not Normal saline.



Pearl PM2215: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation (Updated according to ATLS 11th edition Guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24 hours = TBSA % x weight (kgs) x 4. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours. However, ATLS in its 10th edition, recommended against the use of this formula due to the concern of over-resuscitation.

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

* 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

* 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2

* 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: 27. A 27-year-old woman had an uncomplicated vaginal delivery and requested early discharge from the hospital. However, WBC counts and platelet counts were found to be 15,000 cells/mm3 and 5 lakh cells/mm3 respectively, one-day following delivery. Her body temperature was measured to be 37 degrees celsius. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Start her on high dose antibiotics

questions.solution:
During the first 24 hours following delivery, leukocytosis and thrombocytosis are considered normal physiological responses and do not warrant further intervention.

Elevated white blood cell and platelet counts are commonly observed during labor and the postpartum period. The white blood cell count may rise, but typically does not exceed 25,000/μL, with the increase primarily attributed to granulocytes. This is often accompanied by relative lymphopenia and absolute eosinopenia.

In the first few days after delivery, a moderate decline in hemoglobin and hematocrit levels is expected. A significant drop below pre-labor values, however, may suggest considerable blood loss.

Puerperal fever is defined as a maternal temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher on two separate occasions at least 24 hours apart, within the first 10 days postpartum, excluding the first 24 hours.

Other options:

Options A, C, and D: In the absence of additional clinical findings, elevated leukocyte and platelet counts alone in this context do not require further investigation.

questions.text: 28. An 85-year-old female patient presented with palpitations for the last 4 days. She is hemodynamically stable and the ECG done is shown below. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given ECG, showing tachycardia with narrow QRS complexes, irregularly irregular rhythm, and absent p waves, is suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF). If the duration of atrial fibrillation is >48 hours, then rate control (metoprolol) and anticoagulation (dabigatran) are done.

In patients with AF of >48 hours duration or unknown duration, there is a high risk of formation of thrombus in the left atrium. If the patients are cardioverted at this stage, this thrombus can embolize into the systemic circulation, leading to end-organ damage, such as stroke. Therefore, for these patients, any of the following two management strategies can be followed:

* Give anticoagulation for 3 weeks → cardioversion (pharmacological or electrical) → continue anticoagulation for 4 more weeks

* Start anticoagulation and do transesophageal echocardiography → if thrombus is absent, do cardioversion (pharmacological or electrical) → continue anticoagulation for 4 more weeks. If thrombus is present, then cardioversion is delayed by 3 weeks.

Direct-acting oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are preferred over warfarin for anticoagulation. However, warfarin is the preferred drug if the patient has a mechanical prosthetic valve, advanced CKD, or moderate-severe mitral stenosis.



Apart from anticoagulation, the most important aspect of the treatment of AF is rate control. The drugs used for this are β-blockers (such as metoprolol) and calcium channel blockers (such as diltiazem and verapamil). Reversion to sinus rhythm can be done electrically or using medications. Pharmacological cardioversion can be done using ibutilide, dofetilide, and amiodarone (class III antiarrhythmics) or flecainide and propafenone (class Ic drugs).

If, on presentation, the patient is hemodynamically unstable, synchronized cardioversion is done.

questions.text: 29. A 22-year-old male is planning a trek to Mount Everest. His family physician advises him to start taking oral acetazolamide as prophylaxis against acute mountain sickness. This drug inhibits the enzyme 'X'. Which of the following micronutrients is required for the activity of 'X'?
questions.solution:
The drug acetazolamide acts by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase. Zinc is important for the functioning of this enzyme. 

Zinc is an important micronutrient that is an essential part of several metalloenzymes such as carbonic anhydrase, alcohol dehydrogenase, superoxide dismutase, and alkaline phosphatase. Acetazolamide is the drug of choice for the prevention of acute mountain sickness. It inhibits renal carbonic anhydrase, causing bicarbonate diuresis that leads to metabolic acidosis and hyperventilation. 

Zinc helps to stabilise the intermediates formed during the reactions involving these enzymes. In addition, zinc forms a polynucleotide-binding structure called 'zinc fingers'. These zinc fingers function as transcription factors as well as DNA/RNA-binding proteins. Scientists are hoping to use zinc fingers in gene therapy because of their very specific binding sites on DNA and RNA. 

Other options:

Option B: Selenium is a known component of enzymes such as glutathione peroxidase.

Option C: Manganese can also be found in metalloenzymes like isocitrate dehydrogenase, arginase, and phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase.

Option D: Copper is also a component of several important metalloenzymes such as lysyl oxidase, cytochrome oxidase, tyrosinase, and dopamine-beta-hydroxylase.

questions.text: 30. A 55-year-old man was recently diagnosed with anal carcinoma. The tumour, measuring 5 × 4 × 2 mm, is located below the pectinate line of the anal canal. Metastasis from this tumor would most likely involve which of the following lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The tumor in the given clinical scenario is located below the pectinate line. Lesions below this line typically drain lymph to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, making them the most likely site for metastasis in this case.

The anal canal measures approximately 3.8 cm in length and extends from the anorectal junction to the anus. It is divided into three parts:

* The upper mucosal part is 15 mm long, is endodermal in origin, and contains the anal columns and anal sinuses. The pectinate line marks the junction between the upper mucosal part and the middle transitional zone.

* The middle transitional zone is 15 mm long, is also lined by mucous membrane, and is ectodermal in origin. The lower boundary of this part often appears whitish and is referred to as the white line of Hilton.

* The lowest cutaneous part is 8 mm long, is lined by keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium, and contains sebaceous glands.

Lymphatic drainage from the region above the pectinate line is directed to the internal iliac lymph nodes, whereas drainage from the region below this line is directed to the medial group of superficial inguinal lymph nodes. The pectinate line serves as the watershed line of the anal canal.

questions.text: 32. All of the following are the uses of the instrument given in the image except______

choices.text: To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp
To measure the uterine cavity and the cervical length

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is Simpson’s uterine sound. It is not used in the fallopian tube recanalization procedure.

Simpson’s uterine sound is a 30 cm-long angulated instrument. It has a handle at one end and a rounded, blunt tip at the other. The angulation of the instrument accommodates the flexion of the uterus.

Uses:

* To measure the uterine cavity and cervical length

* To diagnose cervical stenosis

* To sound a polyp, IUCD, or uterine septum

* To break uterine adhesions in Asherman syndrome

* To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp.

questions.text: 33. A 4 months-old male child was brought to the hospital with the complaints of a lesion in the abdomen as shown in the image. The drug used for the treatment of this condition is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows flat to elevated, irregular, red-blue masses in the skin of the abdomen, suggestive of hemangioma. Propranolol is the preferred drug for the treatment of infantile hemangioma.

It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis, and inhibiting angiogenesis. Propranolol at 2 mg/kg/day has been found useful in infants younger than 6 months and children up to 5 years of age. 

Complications of infantile hemangioma include pain, functional impairment, or permanent disfigurement. Timolol is also used in the treatment of infantile hemangioma.

Other options:

Options B, C, D: Bisoprolol, acebutolol, and atenolol are cardioselective beta-blockers that are not used in the treatment of hemangioma.

questions.text: 34. A young woman presented with skin hardening and tightening over the fingers, hands, and face. The doctor noticed mask-like facies, microstomia, and the findings shown in the image below. Which of the following is not a feature seen in her condition?
questions.solution:
A young woman with mask-like facies, stretched, shiny skin, microstomia, and pitted scarring on the right index finger (as shown in the image) suggests the diagnosis of scleroderma or systemic sclerosis. Loss of sweat glands is seen in this disease and not the preservation of sweat glands.

Scleroderma includes both localized and systemic forms that manifest internal organ features, as well as demonstrate vascular manifestations such as the Raynaud phenomenon. There is a 4:1 female: male predominance.

Two types of systemic sclerosis are the limited and diffuse forms.

Cutaneous features:

* Hands and feet - Raynaud's phenomenon, non-pitting edema, painful ulcerations which heal with pitted scars, sclerodactyly, contractures, loss of sweat glands

* Face - mask-like facies, telangiectasia, and diffuse hyperpigmentation

* Trunk - firm, shiny, and thickened skin

Systemic features:

* GIT- dysphagia, GERD, diminished or abnormal motility, malabsorption

* Lungs- pulmonary fibrosis and alveolitis

* Heart- cardiac conduction defects, heart failure

* Kidney- Scleroderma renal crisis, headache, fever, malaise, hypertension

* Musculoskeletal- weakness, carpal tunnel syndrome

The image shows a woman with mask-like facies with stretched, shiny skin, loss of normal facial lines, microstomia, and resorption of distal phalanges of the fingers:



The image below shows an acrosclerotic piece-meal necrosis of the first digit in a patient:



The progressive disappearance of fingerprints is seen in systemic sclerosis due to changes in skin elasticity, hardness, and thickness over the fingertips.

Autoantibodies detected in systemic sclerosis are antitopoisomerase 1 antibody (anti‐Scl‐70 or ATA), anticentromere antibody (ACA), and anti‐RNA polymerase III antibody (ARA or RNAP).

questions.text:
35. A 28-year-old female with a past history of arthralgia presented with recurrent attacks of yellow discoloration of eyes and generalized weakness for the past 4 weeks. She was treated for viral hepatitis in the past. Liver function tests show AST-120U/L and ALT-140U/L. On further evaluation, viral serologies were negative, and the patient was found to be ANA positive. What is the mainstay of treatment?

ANA- Antinuclear antibodies
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 28-year-old female, presenting with recurrent attacks of yellowish discoloration of eyes, with elevated transaminases and ANA positivity, with a history of arthralgia, suggests a diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis, for which glucocorticoid therapy is the mainstay of treatment.

Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis can present with recurrent attacks of jaundice and fatigue, which may be confused with acute viral hepatitis. Viral serology is required to eliminate it as a differential diagnosis. Most commonly occurs in females and has lupoid features such as arthralgias. Marked hyperglobulinemia, circulating Antinuclear antibodies(ANA), and HLA-DR3, HLA-DR4 are also common. 

Liver biopsy, along with the exclusion of genetic disorders, viral hepatitis, drug hepatotoxicity, and alcohol, is used for the diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis, which shows interface hepatitis and piecemeal necrosis.

Other options: 

Option A: Tacrolimus is used in medically refractory cases of autoimmune hepatitis, which shows no improvement on high-dose glucocorticoid monotherapy of 60mg daily or combination therapy of prednisone 30mg daily and high-dose azathioprine of 150mg daily. 

Option B: Supportive treatment with IV fluids is beneficial in acute viral hepatitis, in which spontaneous recovery is present in most persons affected. Glucocorticoid therapy has no role in acute viral hepatitis. Lupoid features like arthralgias are not present in viral hepatitis. Since viral serologies are given negative in the case above, it is not the correct option.

Option C: Azathioprine alone is not effective in achieving the remission of autoimmune hepatitis. However, azathioprine combined with half the dose of prednisone is equally effective as prednisone 60mg/day only.

questions.text: 36. A 45-year-old male farmer presents with fever, chills, severe myalgia, and decreased urine output. Two weeks ago, he received antisnake venom for a snake bite. On examination, he has a serpiginous, urticarial rash and mild cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory findings show eosinophilia and elevated creatinine. What is the best line of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The onset of fever with chills, severe myalgia, impaired renal function, and the presence of urticarial rash and eosinophilia occurring approximately two weeks after antisnake venom administration is suggestive of serum sickness. The best line of treatment for this patient is oral prednisolone.

Adverse reactions to antisnake venom administration can be of two types:

* Early - Usually anaphylaxis, with clinical manifestations of early hypersensitivity such as tachycardia, rigors, vomiting, urticaria, dyspnea, laryngeal edema, bronchospasm, and hypotension. Epinephrine and airway equipment should always be immediately available. If the patient develops an anaphylactic reaction to antisnake venom, the infusion should be stopped temporarily and the reaction treated immediately with injection epinephrine (0.01 mg/kg up to 0.5 mg), an IV antihistamine (e.g., diphenhydramine, 1 mg/kg up to 50 mg), and a glucocorticoid (e.g., hydrocortisone, 2 mg/kg up to 100 mg).

* Late - Serum sickness, a type of type III hypersensitivity reaction. It typically develops 1–2 weeks after antivenom administration and usually presents as myalgias, arthralgias, fever, chills, urticaria, lymphadenopathy, or neurological or renal dysfunction. Treatment consists of systemic glucocorticoids (e.g., oral prednisolone, 1–2 mg/kg daily) until all symptoms have subsided. The dose can be subsequently tapered over 1–2 weeks. Analgesics and oral antihistaminics may provide additional relief of symptoms.

Other options :

Option A: IV antibiotics have no role because the clinical features and timing point toward serum sickness, not an active infection

Option C: IV adrenaline is usually used for anaphylactic (early) reaction caused due to antisnake venom administration, not serum sickness. 

Option D: Oral antihistamines can be used only as supportive therapy.

questions.text: 37. A 2-month-old infant is found to be hypotonic. On examination, there is a large anterior fontanelle and hepatomegaly. Further investigations confirmed a diagnosis of the cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome. Which of the following is not a biochemical finding in this case?

choices.text: Elevated levels of very long chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome (Zellweger syndrome) shows a marked reduction of plasmalogens, not elevated plasmalogens.

Plasmalogens belong to a class of glycerophospholipids. They make up about 10 mol per cent of total phospholipids. In humans, they are primarily found as membrane structure components. Their synthesis is impaired in Zellweger syndrome. 

Zellweger syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX (Peroxins) family of genes. As a result of this, there is a defective transport of the proteins to the peroxisomes. This results in defective beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA), and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

Biochemical findings will show accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids (option A), phytanic acid (option B), abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids (option C), and marked reduction of plasmalogens.

The child presents with dysmorphic facial features like large anterior fontanelles, hypoplastic supraorbital ridges, micrognathia, and redundant nuchal skin folds. Profound developmental delay, profound hypotonia with depressed deep tendon reflexes, neonatal seizures, and impaired hearing are seen. Other observed abnormalities are calcific stippling of the epiphysis, renal cysts, and liver cirrhosis.

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe, and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

questions.text:
38. A 30-year-old male had a history of fever and muscle weakness 1 week ago, and now presents with progressive shortness of breath and chest pain. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Serum troponin levels are raised. What is the most probable diagnosis?

ECG- electrocardiogram
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a 30-year-old male with progressive shortness of breath and chest pain, with raised serum troponin levels, sinus tachycardia, and a history of fever and muscle weakness, suggests a diagnosis of acute viral myocarditis. 

Acute viral myocarditis typically occurs in a young to middle-aged adult with symptoms of shortness of breath after a few days of viral syndrome that was accompanied by fever and muscle pain caused by coxsackie, HHV-6, enteroviruses, and parvovirus B19. Inflammatory Myocarditis is a common cause of dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) and can be infective or non-infective.

On evaluation of myocarditis, sinus tachycardia in an electrocardiogram with non-specific  ST/T wave changes is commonly seen, and serum levels of troponin and CK-MB are raised. Fulminant myocarditis presents with cardiogenic shock, multiple organ system involvement leading to renal failure, and hepatic failure.

Endomyocardial biopsy shows diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration as shown below:



Other options: 

Option A: ST-elevated myocardial infarction(MI) shows ST elevation in ECG and presents with chest pain increasing on exertion, and also can show increased levels of troponin, but prior history of fever and muscle weakness is more consistent with myocarditis. 

Option C: Decompensated heart failure often presents with signs of orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, elevated Jugular venous pressure, pedal edema, and pulsus alternans, which are not present in the clinical scenario above.

Option D: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterised by asymmetric septal hypertrophy caused by a mutation to MYH7, presenting with chest pain, exertional dyspnea, and systolic ejection murmur, increasing on Valsalva maneuver, and spontaneous sustained ventricular tachycardia, unlike the above clinical scenario.

Pearl PM0821: Causes of Myocarditis

Causes of myocarditis include:

* Infections:

* Viruses (e.g., coxsackievirus, ECHO, influenza, HIV, cytomegalovirus)

* Chlamydiae (e.g.,  Chlamydophila psittaci)

* Rickettsiae (e.g., Rickettsia typhi, typhus fever)

* Bacteria (e.g., Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Neisseria meningococcus)

* Borrelia (Lyme disease)

* Fungi (e.g., Candida spp.)

* Protozoa (e.g., Trypanosoma cruzi [Chagas disease], toxoplasmosis)

* Helminths (e.g., trichinosis)

* Poststreptococcal (rheumatic fever)

* Immune-Mediated Reactions

* Systemic lupus erythematosus

* Drug hypersensitivity (e.g., methyldopa, sulfonamides)

* Transplant rejection

* Sarcoidosis

* Giant cell myocarditis

* Unknown

Morphology:

The heart in myocarditis may appear normal or dilated. Some hypertrophy may be present depending on disease duration. Mural thrombi may be present. Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with focal myocyte necrosis. Endomyocardial biopsies are diagnostic in some cases, but not when the inflammation is focal or patchy.

The morphological pattern of myocarditis in certain conditions:

* Hypersensitivity myocarditis: Interstitial infiltrates with a high proportion of eosinophils

* Giant-cell myocarditis: Multinucleate giant cells (fused macrophages)

* Chagas disease: Scattered myofibers by trypanosomes.

* Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,

* 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: 41. Which among the following skin conditions is correctly matched with its appearance under the Wood's lamp examination?

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: 42. A 3-year-old unimmunized boy presented with conjunctivitis and a rash that spread from his face to his trunk. On examination, the doctor noticed findings as shown in the image below. What dose of Vitamin A will you give at the time of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, as well as the Koplik's spot (bluish-white spots ) seen in the image given above, suggests a diagnosis of measles. Children who are above 12 months of age are given 2,00,000 lU of Vitamin A at the time of diagnosis. 

Vitamin A therapy is indicated in all cases of severe measles (and in areas with high case-fatality rates) as patients may develop an acute deficiency of vitamin A, leading to keratomalacia and corneal scarring. A high dose of vitamin A is given immediately on diagnosis and repeated the next day. The recommended age-specific daily doses are:

* 50,000 IU for infants aged <6 months

* 1,00,000 IU for infants aged 6- 11 months

* 2,00,000 IU for children aged ≥12 months

An additional third dose should be given 4-6 weeks later if the child has clinical signs of vitamin A deficiency (such as Bitot's spots) with measles. 

Measles, otherwise known as rubeola, is caused by the paramyxovirus, which is an RNA virus. The virus has an incubation period of 10 to 14 days. It is a droplet infection, and the period of infectivity ranges from 4 days before to 4 days after the appearance of the rash. 

The prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomonic Koplik spots. Koplik spots are small, bluish-white spots on the buccal mucosa opposite to the first and second lower molars. This is followed by the appearance of a characteristic dusky red maculopapular rash that begins on the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. The image below shows the characteristic rashes and the Koplik spots seen in measles.



The diagnosis of measles infection is mainly clinical but may be confirmed by serological demonstration of serum IgM antibodies. The management is mainly supportive in the form of relieving common symptoms such as fever, cough, and nasal congestion and providing adequate nutritional support. 

According to the national immunisation schedule, the measles vaccine is administered by reconstituting a freeze-dried live attenuated vaccine called the MR(measles, rubella) vaccine. The first dose and second doses are administered at  9-12  months and 16-24 months of age, respectively.

questions.text: 43. A 60-year-old woman presents with throbbing headaches on one side. She has a fever and tenderness over the temple. Investigations reveal an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. A biopsy of the affected site is most likely to reveal _____
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical history and laboratory findings are consistent with a diagnosis of temporal arteritis, also known as giant cell arteritis (GCA). This condition is characterized by medial granulomatous inflammation and is a form of granulomatous large-vessel vasculitis that primarily affects the branches of the carotid artery, particularly the temporal artery.

It typically presents in older adults with symptoms such as new-onset headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, visual disturbances, and elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR, CRP). The hallmark histological feature of giant cell arteritis is granulomatous inflammation predominantly involving the arterial wall. This inflammation is classically centered on the internal elastic lamina, leading to its fragmentation.

There is a prominent infiltration of T lymphocytes, with a predominance of CD4+ helper T cells over CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, along with activated macrophages. These macrophages may fuse to form multinucleated giant cells, which are observed in approximately 75% of sufficiently sampled temporal artery biopsies. 

Other options:

Option B: Eosinophil-rich infiltration is suggestive of Churg-Strauss Syndrome (now called eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, EGPA). It is commonly associated with a history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, and peripheral eosinophilia. It can also show necrotizing vasculitis involving small to medium-sized vessels.

Option C: Leukocytoclastic Vasculitis (LCV) is seen in conditions such as microscopic polyangiitis (MPA). It is characterized by neutrophilic infiltration in small vessels, often with nuclear debris (leukocytoclasia).

Option D: Microabscesses composed of neutrophils are indicative of Buerger’s Disease (Thromboangiitis Obliterans). It is a segmental, inflammatory, non-atherosclerotic vascular disease that affects small and medium-sized arteries and veins, usually of the extremities. It is strongly associated with tobacco use and typically occurs in young male smokers.

questions.text: 44. A 21-year-old male patient presents with low-grade fever, loss of weight, dry nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing for the past 6 months The eosinophil count is markedly increased along with a high level of serum IgE and filarial antibodies. Following treatment with diethylcarbamazine, he developed a severe allergic reaction. This is known as:
questions.solution:
Following treatment with diethylcarbamazine (DEC), the severe allergic reaction that may occur is known as the Mazzotti reaction. It occurs due to the death of microfilariae. The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is a manifestation of occult filariasis. It presents with low-grade fever, weight loss, and pulmonary symptoms like a dry nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing. There is an increase in the eosinophil count, IgE, and filarial antibodies. The condition is treated with DEC.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice for filariasis. It is given orally (the dose is 6 mg/ kg body weight daily for 12 days). It has both macro and microfilaricidal properties. The Mazzotti reaction that may develop can be controlled with antihistamines and steroids.

Other options:

Option B- A Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction is a transient clinical phenomenon that occurs in patients infected with spirochetes like syphilis, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, and relapsing fever, who are treated with antibiotics. The reaction occurs within 24 hours of antibiotic therapy. It generally manifests as fever, chills, rigors, nausea and vomiting, headache, tachycardia, hypotension, hyperventilation, flushing, myalgia, and exacerbation of skin lesions. It is an acute, self-limiting condition.

Option C- Hoigne Syndrome is a pseudoanaphylactic or pseudoallergic reaction that occurs after intramuscular administration of penicillin G procaine or benzathine. It is not due to a penicillin allergy. 

Option D- Meyer's-Kouwenaar syndrome is a synonym for occult filariasis. It occurs as a result of a hypersensitivity reaction to microfilariae antigens. Microfilariae are not found in the blood. It presents with massive eosinophilia, hepatosplenomegaly, and pulmonary symptoms.

questions.text: 45. A 3-year-old child is diagnosed with rhabdomyosarcoma. Among the following, what is the most common site affected?
questions.solution:
Rhabdomyosarcoma, a tumor of striated skeletal muscle, most commonly occurs in the head and neck. Other chief sites are the genitourinary tract and extremities. 

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma. The site-specific presentation is as follows:

* Orbital tumors present in young children with proptosis or eyelid swelling.

* Parameningeal tumors (nose, nasopharynx, middle ear, mastoid, paranasal sinuses) may show intracranial extension.

* Genitourinary tumors present with pelvic mass, bladder/prostate enlargement, or polypoid vaginal masses. A unique variant, botryoid RMS, arises from the bladder or vagina and appears like a grape-like mass, seen almost exclusively in young children.

* Extremity tumors, especially of the hand and foot, tend to occur in older children, are commonly of the alveolar subtype, and have a higher risk of metastasis.

The histologic subtypes include: 

1. Embryonal (60%): It is the most common subtype and occurs in head, neck, and genitourinary tract with better prognosis

2. Alveolar (20%): It is seen in older children and occurs more in the extremities and perineal region, associated with a worse outcome. 

Almost one-fourth patients present with metastasis at diagnosis commonly in lungs, bone marrow and bone. Treatment includes a combination of medical, surgical, and radiotherapy, ensuring a 5-year survival in over 70 % of the patients with rhabdomyosarcoma. The chemotherapeutic agents used are vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and actinomycin.

questions.text: 46. The gastrocolic reflex is mediated by
questions.solution:
The gastrocolic reflex is mediated by prevertebral sympathetic ganglia.

Distension of the stomach and digestive byproducts in the small intestine activate afferents to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia. This results in stimulation of the colon and an urge to defecate. This is the reason for frequent defecation after meals in children. This reflex can also be amplified by the action of gastrin.

Other reflexes that involve the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia include the following:

* Enterogastric reflex: Signals from the colon and the small intestine stop gastric motility and secretion

* Colonoileal reflex: Signals from the colon prevent ileal emptying

The brain stem and spinal cord are involved in:

* Pain reflexes that cause inhibition of the whole gastrointestinal tract

* Long-distance vagal reflexes regulating gastric motor and secretory activity

* Defecation reflex: Distension of the rectum and colon results in powerful contractions of the rectum, colon, and abdominal wall.

Local reflexes mediated by the enteric nervous system regulate local secretion, peristalsis, mixing contractions, and ileus.

questions.text: 47. A baby is brought to the OPD with a deformity in the hip and lower limbs. On examination, there is an asymmetry of the groin crease and a click sound is heard on moving the left hip. The following test is done and found to be positive. Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and a positive Galeazzi's test, as shown in the above image, are suggestive of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The female sex of the baby is a risk factor for developing this condition.

Galeazzi's test is done between 3 to 8-month-old children in unilateral cases of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). To perform this test, the child is in the supine position with the hip and knee in flexion. The level of both knee joints is noted with respect to the horizontal line. Normally, both knees should be at the same level. In DDH, the affected knee is seen at a lower level, indicating femoral shortening.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip, or congenital dysplasia of the hip, is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. Risk factors for DDH include:

* Sex of the baby- females are more susceptible to DDH due to the action of maternal relaxin on the fetal joints in utero, predisposing them to dislocation. It is 3-5 times more common in females.

* Intrauterine positioning- breech position is associated with a higher incidence of DDH

* Genetic predisposition- DDH is more common in children of parents who had DDH themselves.

* Firstborn child

Examination findings in the developmental dysplasia of the hip are:

1) Newborn to 3 months of age. Tests to check the instability of the hip:

* Asymmetrical skin creases in the inguinal, gluteal, and thigh regions.

* Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum, producing a palpable "clunk", which indicates a positive test.



* Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk".

The image below shows the Barlow test.



2) At 3-6 months of age:

* Galeazzi's test 

* Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.

* Decreased abduction on the affected side.

3) In children of walking age:

* Trendelenburg gait

* Positive Trendelenburg sign

* Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.
