questions.text: 48. The marked phase in the cardiac muscle action potential mainly occurs due to ______.
questions.solution:
The marked phase in the cardiac action potential is phase 3. It occurs due to the efflux of potassium ions.

Phases of the cardiac muscle action potential:

* Phase 0 (depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels (voltage-gated sodium channels) open and cause sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell, and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reaches about +20 mV. 

* Phase 1 (initial repolarization): When the membrane potential reaches +20mV, the fast sodium channels close and the potassium channels open. The potassium ions leave the cell, leading to a brief repolarisation. 

* Phase 2 (plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The voltage-gated Ca2+ channels start opening slowly in phases 0 and 1. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the decrease in the efflux of potassium via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 

* Phase 3 (rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels, and the calcium channels close, stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to the resting level. 

* Phase 4 (resting membrane potential):  around −80 to −90 millivolts.

The illustration given below shows the action potential of cardiac muscle.



In skeletal muscle, the action potential is generated almost entirely by the rapid opening of large numbers of fast sodium channels. In contrast, cardiac muscle action potentials are produced by both fast sodium channels and L-type (slow) calcium channels, which contribute to the prolonged depolarization phase.

questions.text: 49. On tapping a long saphenous varicose vein in the lower part, the impulse can be felt at the saphenous opening with the other hand. This is known as ______
questions.solution:
This is known as the Schwartz test.

In a standing position, when the lower part of the long saphenous vein in the leg is tapped, an impulse is felt at the saphenous junction or the upper end of the visible part of the vein. This is known as the Schwartz test. It signifies a continuous column of blood due to valvular incompetence.

Other options:

Option A: Perthe’s Test: The affected lower limb is wrapped with an elastic bandage, and the patient is asked to walk around and exercise. The development of severe cramp-like pain in the calf signifies deep vein thrombosis.

Option B: Modified Perthe’s Test: The tourniquet is tied just below the saphenofemoral junction without emptying the vein. The patient is allowed to have a brisk walk, which precipitates bursting pain in the calf and also makes superficial veins more prominent. It signifies deep vein thrombosis. 

Option D: Morrisey’s cough impulse test: In this test, the varicose veins are emptied. The leg is elevated, and then the patient is asked to cough. An expansile impulse is felt at the saphenous opening if there is saphenofemoral incompetence. It is a venous thrill that occurs due to vibration caused by turbulent backflow.

questions.text: 50. A patient presents with generalized rash, cough, and breathlessness. Peripheral smear reveals eosinophilia. To diagnose hypereosinophilic syndrome, what should be the absolute eosinophil count?
questions.solution:
Hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES) is diagnosed when a patient has a sustained absolute eosinophil count exceeding 1.5 × 10⁹/L (or >1500/mm³), in combination with eosinophil-mediated organ damage or dysfunction, after excluding other potential causes.

HES is a rare disorder characterized by persistent eosinophilia and multisystem involvement, with common clinical features including skin rashes, cough, and dyspnea. In some cases, gastrointestinal and neurological symptoms may also occur.

Evaluation involves assessing end-organ involvement, including laboratory tests such as liver enzymes, creatine kinase, renal function, troponin, as well as electrocardiography, echocardiography, and pulmonary function tests. Bone marrow biopsy and cytogenetic studies are essential to rule out myeloproliferative variants or secondary causes.

Systemic corticosteroids remain the first-line treatment for most forms of HES.

Differential diagnosis of eosinophilia:

* Bronchial asthma

* Loffler syndrome

* Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis

* Churg-Strauss syndrome

*

Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia

*

Hypereosinophilic syndrome

questions.text: 51. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the right mastoid to assess hearing. While the sound is heard, the right tragus is pressed and released, but no change in sound perception is noted. What is the most likely inference?
questions.solution:
The test done here is the Bing test and the above findings in correlate to right sided conductive hearing loss. 

Bing test is done to evaluate bone conduction and evaluate the effect of ear canal occlusion on hearing. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid, and tragus is pressed inwards to occlude the ear canal. If there is no change in hearing, it is likely conductive hearing loss. In a normal ear, sound is heard louder when the canal is occluded.

questions.text: 52. A 21-year-old man, who had a fight with his friend, presented to the emergency ward with complaints of pain and tenderness in the right forearm. The X-ray image is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The fracture seen in the X-ray is called a night stick fracture. Isolated shaft of ulna fractures are also called night stick fractures, which are sustained while trying to ward off a stick blow.

If the fracture is undisplaced with good apposition, a forearm cast (elbow free) is usually sufficient, with recovery taking about 8 weeks. However, due to risks of displacement or non-union, rigid internal fixation is often preferred, especially to preserve forearm rotation and allow earlier activity

Other options:

Option A: Monteggia Fracture refers to fracture of the proximal third of the ulna, with dislocation of the head of the radius, as shown below:



Option B: Essex Lopresti Fracture refers to the fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseus membrane, with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint. It is usually caused due to longitudinal force transmitted from the wrist to the elbow.

Option D: Chauffeur’s fracture, also known as Hutchinson fractures, are intra-articular fractures of the radial styloid process, as shown below.



Note: Green stick fractures refer to unicortical fractures usually seen in long bones of the pediatric age group, where the traumatic force is not able to entirely overcome the tensile strength of immature bone, resulting in a unicortical fracture. It is not the same as night stick fracture. The given image shows a green stick fracture.

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.



 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).



 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.



 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

questions.text: 53. Activation of which of the following caspases occurs in pyroptosis?
questions.solution:
Pyroptosis is a form of apoptosis that occurs due to the activation of caspase 1.

Pyroptosis occurs due to the release of fever-inducing cytokine interleukin-1 (IL-1). Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognise microbial products that have entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death. Unlike classical apoptosis, pyroptosis is characterized by the release of inflammatory mediators. 

Other options:

Options A, B and C: Apoptosis- The intrinsic mitochondrial and extrinsic death receptor-initiated pathways converge to activate a caspase cascade that mediates the final phase of apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway activates caspase 9, whereas the extrinsic pathway activates caspases 8 and 10. These caspases then activate caspase 3 and caspase 6. Activated caspases cause DNA degradation and nuclei fragmentation.

Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent distinct pathway of cell death induced by lipid peroxidation. The widespread peroxidation disrupts membrane function, which leads to the loss of plasma membrane permeability and results in cell death resembling necrosis. 

Necroptosis, as the name suggests, has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. Ligation of TNFR1 initiates necroptosis. This is a caspase-independent programmed cell death.

questions.text: 54. A patient had been treated for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), and his treatment outcome was labelled as ‘treatment failed’. This label applies to all of the following conditions, except:

choices.text: Lack of conversion by the end of intensive phase
Bacteriological reversion in the continuation phase after initial conversion
Adverse drug reactions to standard MDR-TB drugs
Patient treatment interrupted for at least 2 consecutive months

questions.solution:
Treatment failed includes all the above-mentioned statements except patient treatment interrupted for at least 2 consecutive months.

Patient treatment interrupted for at least 2 consecutive months- is not labelled as ‘treatment failed’, instead labelled as ‘lost to follow up’, and the patient’s treatment is continued as a new case.

Patients treated for MDR-TB and labelled as ‘treatment failed’ include - 

* Lack of conversion by the end of the intensive phase

* Bacteriological reversion in the continuation phase after initial conversion

* Adverse drug reactions to standard MDR-TB drugs

* Evidence of additional acquired resistance to fluoroquinolones or second-line injectable drugs

For ‘treatment failed’, lack of conversion by the end of the intensive phase implies that the patient does not convert within the maximum duration of the intensive phase applied by the programme. If no maximum duration is defined, an 8-month cut-off is proposed. 

Conversion (to negative): Culture is considered to have converted to negative when two consecutive cultures, taken at least 30 days apart, are found to be negative. In such a case, the specimen collection date of the first negative culture is used as the date of conversion.

Reversion (to positive): Culture is considered to have reverted to positive when, after an initial conversion, two consecutive cultures, taken at least 30 days apart, are found to be positive. For the purpose of defining treatment failed, reversion is considered only when it occurs in the continuation phase.

Other outcomes for Rifampicin Resistant-TB(RR-TB)/MDR-TB/Drug-resistant TB patients treated include -

* Cured - Treatment completed as recommended by NTEP(National tuberculosis eradication programme) without evidence of failure, and three or more consecutive cultures taken at least 30 days apart are negative after the intensive phase.

* Treatment completed - Treatment completed as recommended by NTEP without evidence of failure, but no record that three or more consecutive cultures taken at least 30 days apart are negative after the intensive phase.

* Died - A patient who dies for any reason during the course of treatment.

* Not evaluated - A patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned. (This includes cases transferred out to another treatment unit, and whose treatment outcome is unknown.)

* Treatment success - The sum of cured and treatment-completed.

questions.text:
55. Which of the following drugs is correctly matched to their respective routes of administration?

1. Ipratropium MDI, DPI, Nebulised aerosol
2. Tiotropium DPI, Nebulised aerosol
3. Ipratropium MDI, Nebulised aerosol
4. Tiotropium MDI, SMI, Nebulised aerosol


MDI - Metered Dose Inhaler, DPI - Dry Powder Inhaler, SMI- Soft Mist Inhaler
questions.solution:
Ipratropium can be administered as MDI and a nebulised aerosol.

Ipratropium bromide is a short-acting antimuscarinic agent that is used for the control of asthma not adequately controlled by beta-2 agonists. It is slow to start its action, after 30-60 minutes and has action lasting for 6-8 hours. Ipratropium is administered as MDI 3-4 times daily or as a nebulised solution. It is not available as a dry powder inhaler (DPI). It is used for the treatment of asthma and COPD.

Tiotropium Bromide is a long-acting anti-muscarinic agent which is administered as a dry powder inhaler (DPI) or using a soft mist inhaler device (SMI) or MDI. It is not administered as a nebulised aerosol. It is also used for the treatment of asthma and COPD. It is considered more effective than ipratropium.

questions.text: 56. A 9-year-old female presented with a unilateral skin lesion with leukotrichia. The clinical image is given below. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The image showing a unilateral white skin lesion in a child is indicative of segmental vitiligo.

Segmental vitiligo is characterized by the loss of skin pigmentation in a localized, often unilateral, segmental distribution. This pattern usually affects a limited area on one side of the body and is often associated with depigmentation of hair within the affected region.

Segmental vitiligo is further classified based on the extent and number of segments involved. It can present as uni-segmental, affecting a single segment; bi-segmental, involving two segments; or plurisegmental, where multiple segments on one or both sides are affected.

Non-segmental vitiligo is the more common form. Non-segmental vitiligo tends to progress gradually and symmetrically. It includes a variety of clinical subtypes. These include

* Acrofacial vitiligo, which primarily affects the fingers and face (Option A)

* Mucosal vitiligo involves mucous membranes

* Generalized vitiligo has widespread symmetrical lesions

* Universal vitiligo is characterized by nearly complete depigmentation of the skin

* Mixed vitiligo has segmental and non-segmental patterns.

Some cases present with small, focal, isolated depigmented lesions that do not follow a segmental distribution and do not progress to non-segmental vitiligo within a period of 1 to 2 years. These also have isolated mucosal lesions confined to a single site. These are classified as undetermined or unclassified vitiligo because their clinical course and prognosis are less predictable, and they do not fit neatly into the established segmental or non-segmental categories.

Other options:

Option C: Pityriasis alba typically presents with one or several hypopigmented macules on the face. These lesions have normal sensation and sweating, often occur in individuals with a history of atopy, and tend to show a pattern of waxing and waning. Leukotrichia is not associated with Pityriasis alba. 

Option D: Piebaldism is a rare genetic condition that commonly presents with a characteristic V-shaped leucoderma (depigmented patch) on the mid-forehead and a distinctive white forelock of hair. Unlike vitiligo, piebaldism is stable and present from birth.

questions.text: 57. Which of the following blood products can be safely transfused from an Rh(D)-positive donor to an Rh(D)-negative recipient without significant risk of any transfusion reaction?
questions.solution:
Fresh frozen plasma can be safely transfused from an Rh(D)-positive donor to an Rh(D)-negative recipient without significant risk of any transfusion reaction. 

Rh antigen is located on the surface of RBCs. RBC transfusion from RhD-positive donors to RhD-negative individuals should be avoided to prevent alloimmunisation and possible transfusion reactions. Whole blood transfusion and packed red blood cell transfusion have RBCs in the transfusion. 

Fresh frozen plasma, platelet concentrates and cryoprecipitates transfusions are deprived of RBCs and generally have a low risk of any transfusion reaction. Seroconversion can occur with large volumes owing to the presence of red cell fragments. Rh­D immunisation should also be considered during the transfusion.

questions.text: 58. Ochronosis is a feature of______
questions.solution:
Ochronosis refers to the bluish-black pigmentation resulting from the accumulation of certain pigmented compounds in connective tissues such as cartilage and skin. This pigmentation is most commonly associated with alkaptonuria, a metabolic disorder, but it can also occur due to prolonged exposure to certain chemicals.

In the context of phenol poisoning, ochronosis develops as a result of chronic exposure to phenol or its derivatives, which leads to the deposition of pigment-like substances in various tissues, especially cartilage. This pigmentation is not typically seen in acute or short-term phenol poisoning because it requires time for these pigmented compounds to accumulate sufficiently.

Chronic phenol poisoning may cause other characteristic features, such as a leathery appearance of mucous membranes due to its corrosive effects. Phenol's antimicrobial properties also allow it to delay putrefaction, but this is unrelated to ochronosis. Therefore, ochronosis is specifically a manifestation of chronic rather than acute phenol exposure.

Other options:

Option A: Acute phenol poisoning causes systemic toxicity like CNS depression, respiratory failure, and metabolic acidosis. It does not result in ochronosis.

Option B: Acute mercury poisoning presents with corrosive bronchitis with fever, chills, and dyspnea, which may progress to pulmonary edema and fibrosis. The symptom profile in children is similar to that of Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome). It does not result in ochronosis.

Option D: Chronic exposure to elemental mercury leads to a classic triad of gingivitis, tremors, and neuropsychiatric changes. It does not result in ochronosis.

questions.text: 59. A 17-year-old male presents with vertical gaze palsy. MRI reveals a pineal region mass compressing the quadrigeminal plate. All of the following features are typically seen in this condition except:
questions.solution:
All of the above features are typically seen in this condition except the Rising Sun sign.

The clinical picture describes Parinaud syndrome (dorsal midbrain syndrome), which can be caused by pinealoma, meningitis or aqueduct stenosis. The setting sun sign is seen due to downward ocular deviation, and not the rising sun sign.

Parinaud syndrome is a distinct supranuclear vertical gaze disorder caused by damage to the posterior commissure. Features include:

* Loss of upgaze (and sometimes downgaze)

* Light-near dissociation of the pupils.

* Convergence-retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze

* Downward ocular deviation (setting sun sign)

* Lid retraction (Collier’s sign)

* Skew deviation

* Pseudoabducens palsy

questions.text: 60. A 55-year-old woman comes with a history of a mobile lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 7×9 cm with no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump is given below. What is the gene most likely to be mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient with a large breast lump in a woman in her 6th decade, with no axillary lymphadenopathy and characteristic histological features such as increased stromal cellularity with typical leaf-like architecture , points towards the diagnosis of phyllodes tumor. The gene most likely to be mutated is the MED12 gene.

Phyllodes tumors are benign tumors, also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes. They present in the 6th decade, 10-20 years later than the occurrence of fibroadenoma. Similar to fibroadenomas, the majority of these tumors have MED12 mutations. Malignant behaving tumors are more likely to express additional genes such as TERT. Histologically, they can be low-grade tumors like fibroadenomas but are more mitotically active.

Clinically these present as a large, sometimes massive, tumor with an uneven, bosselated surface. Occasionally, ulceration of the overlying skin occurs because of pressure necrosis. Phyllodes tumors remain mobile on the chest wall. Lymphatic spread is rare, and axillary lymph node dissection is contraindicated. Metastasis in high-grade tumors is by the hematogenous route.

MED12 gene mutations are seen in two-thirds of fibroadenoma cases. They occur in women in their 20s and 30s, and they are frequently multiple and bilateral. Histology shows delicate and often myxoid stroma that resembles normal intralobular stroma. The epithelium may be surrounded by stroma (pericanalicular pattern) or compressed and distorted by it (intracanalicular pattern) as shown below:



Other options:

Option A: p53 mutation is associated with the comedo subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), high nuclear grade, and a high mitotic index. Comedo pattern of DCIS is defined by two features, tumor cells with pleomorphic, high-grade nuclei and areas of central necrosis. The various patterns of DCIS are shown below.



Option B: CDH1 mutation is associated with lobar carcinoma in situ (LCIS) of the breast. Histologically, LCIS consists of a monomorphic population of cells with oval or round nuclei and small nucleoli involving ducts and lobules. Mucin-positive signet ring cells are commonly present. The histological image is given below:



Option C: TERT mutations may appear later in malignant transformation, but MED12 mutations are more frequent and characteristic in early/benign forms, like in the given clinical scenario.

questions.text: 61. Methimazole acts by __________.

choices.text: Inhibition of deiodinase type 1 and type 2

questions.solution:
Methimazole is an anti-thyroid drug that acts by inhibition of thyroid peroxidase.

Methimazole interferes with the oxidation of iodide ions and iodotyrosyl residues, resulting in decreased formation of active hormones. It does not interfere with the trapping of iodide and does not modify the action of T3 and T4 on peripheral tissues or the pituitary.

Mechanism of action of anti-thyroid drugs:

* Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis

* Propylthiouracil

* Methimazole

* Carbimazole

* Drugs Inhibiting Iodide Trapping

* Thiocyanates

* Perchlorates

* Nitrates

* Drugs inhibiting hormone release

* Iodine

* Sodium iodide

* Potassium iodide

* Organic iodide

* Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue

* Radioactive iodine

questions.text: 62. Which one of the following is incorrectly matched to its biochemical test?
questions.solution:
Escherichia coli- Citrate positive is incorrect. Escherichia coli is Citrate negative.

Oxidase test: It detects the presence of cytochrome oxidase enzyme in bacteria, which catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by atmospheric oxygen.

* Oxidase positive (deep purple): Examples include Pseudomonas, Vibrio, Neisseria, Bacillus, Haemophilus.„

* Oxidase negative (no colour change): Examples include members of the family Enterobacteriaceae, Acinetobacter.



Indole test: It detects the ability of certain bacteria to produce an enzyme tryptophanase that breaks down amino acid tryptophan present in the medium into indole. 

* Indole positive: A red colored ring is formed near the surface of the broth. Examples include Escherichia coli, Proteus vulgaris, Vibrio cholerae. ™

* Indole negative: Yellow colored ring is formed near the surface of the broth, e.g. Klebsiella pneumoniae, Proteus mirabilis, Pseudomonas, Salmonella.

The image below shows a positive Indole test.



Citrate Utilisation test: It detects the ability of a few bacteria to utilize citrate as the sole source of carbon for their growth, with production of alkaline metabolic products. Test is performed on Simmon’s citrate medium. Citrate utilizing bacteria produce growth and a colour change, i.e. original green color changes to blue.

* Citrate test is positive for Klebsiella pneumoniae, Citrobacter, Enterobacter.

* The test is negative for Escherichia coli, Shigella.



Urea hydrolysis test: Urease producing bacteria can split urea present in the medium to produce ammonia that makes the medium alkaline. Test is done on Christensen’s urea medium, which contains phenol red indicator that changes to pink color in alkaline medium.

* Urease test is positive for Klebsiella pneumoniae, Proteus species, Helicobacter pylori, Brucella.

* Urease test is negative for Escherichia coli, Shigella, Salmonella.

questions.text: 63. A 70-year-old male reports to the ophthalmology OPD for follow-up after cataract surgery. On examination, the lens shown below is noted. Which of the following statement is not true regrading the lens?

choices.text: It is used for correcting aphakia
It is placed behind the iris
It is associated with high incidence of postoperative complications

questions.solution:
The image depicts Singh and Worst’s iris claw lens which is placed on the iris with the help of sutures, loops, or claws

Intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is done to correct aphakia following cataract surgeries. Singh and Worst’s lens is fixed on the iris by enclavating the mid-peripheral iris stroma into claw-shaped haptics, without sutures. Haptics refer to the supporting structures that hold the lens in place within the eye. They are associated with a high incidence of postoperative complications.

Posterior chamber lenses (PCIOLs) are placed entirely behind the iris. Anterior chamber IOLs are placed entirely in front of the iris. They are supported at the angle of the anterior chamber.

questions.text: 64. A patient just underwent a surgery and is still in the operating room. You are incharge of monitoring the adductor pollicis for overall non-depolarising muscle blockade. Which of the following TOF values can be considered adequate for a safe extubation ?
questions.solution:
The T4/T1 ratio is calculated in case of non-depolarizing muscle blockade, and recent evidences prove that a TOF ratio of 0.9 and above should be considered safe for extubation.

Train of four (TOF) is the response elicited by a muscle upon stimulation. Four successive stimuli of 2Hz strength are given at fixed time intervals, and the response achieved is plotted as a graph (T1-T4) as shown below.



Initially TOF value of 0.6 - 0.75 was considered safe for extubation, but evidence from recent research has shown significant muscle weakness and impaired respiratory control up to a TOF value just below 0.9. Hence, a TOF ratio of 0.9 is now widely accepted as safe for extubation.

questions.text: 65. A 45-year-old woman, who is confirmed by colposcopy and biopsy to have high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL). She undergoes a procedure that was performed with the instrument (marked by the arrow) in the image below. Which one of the following is true about the given procedure?

choices.text: Usually performed in the immediate post-menstrual phase

questions.solution:
The image given in the question shows electrodes used for a loop electrosurgical procedure, which is usually performed in the immediate post-menstrual phase.

Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) is an OPD procedure that is carried out under colposcopic view and local anaesthesia. It uses low-voltage diathermy. The loop is advanced into the cervix lateral to the lesion until the required depth is reached. It is then taken across to the opposite side, and a cone of tissue is removed. The instruments used are cheaper and easily portable, hence preferred over other procedures such as conization.

questions.text: 66. Which of the following is not a contraindication to the type of dressing given in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows Negative Pressure–Assisted Wound Therapy (NPWT). This modality is not contraindicated, but rather preferred in the treatment of ischemic ulcer.

NPWT is not a replacement for definitive wound closure but is a useful adjunct and an alternative to surgery in extremely ill patients. Negative pressure helps draw the wound edges together, removes exudate, increases local blood flow, reduces oedema, and promotes granulation tissue formation. There is a significant improvement in wound depth in chronic wounds treated with NPWT compared with those treated with saline wet-to-moist dressings. It is used in acute, subacute, or chronic wounds like ischemic ulcers and diabetic wounds.

Improved outcomes in patients with diabetic wounds, ischemic ulcers, and complex vascular, abdominal, gynecologic, and other oncologic surgical wounds with or without contamination have been noted. NPWT has been shown to significantly increase growth factors, decrease inflammatory cytokines, and normalise MMP activity, enhancing wound healing.

NPWT is contraindicated in the presence of exposed vessels, malignancy, untreated osteomyelitis, necrotic tissue or non-enteric and unexplored fistulae.

questions.text: 67. A 55-year-old male patient presented after an episode of acute gastroenteritis and was infused with fluids. A while later, after fluid infusion, his heart rate rose to 122 bpm and he complained of palpitations. The presence of tachycardia can be explained by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The presence of tachycardia can be explained by the Bainbridge reflex.

It is a compensatory cardiac reflex where there is an increase in the heart rate in response to raised atrial stretch.

In fluid overload states, commonly after excessive fluid infusion, there is distension of the atria due to increased blood volume. This distension activates the atrial stretch receptors, which transmit the afferent signals to the medulla via the vagus nerve. The efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves. This leads to an increase in the strength of contraction of the heart and tachycardia. This reflex helps in preventing the excess accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and the pulmonary circulation.

Other options:

Option A: The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is due to the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region. They can be elicited after administering certain irritants like capsaicin or serotonin. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography. This reflex is characterized by profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. 

Option B: Pulmonary chemoreflex is due to the stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) which are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung. This produces reflex apnea followed by a rapid increase in breathing rate, bradycardia, and hypotension.

Option D: Cushing's reflex is seen when the intracranial pressure is raised where the blood supply to ventrolateral medulla neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia stimulate the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

Note: Bainbridge reflex causes tachycardia, whereas all the other mentioned reflexes predominantly cause bradycardia.

questions.text: 68. A 60-year-old chronic alcoholic male presented with abdominal distention. He has been on spironolactone 100mg/day and furosemide 40mg/day for the past 2 weeks. He complains that abdominal distension has not decreased over the past 2 weeks. He is taking up to 2 g/day of sodium. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Increase the dose of spironolactone and furosemide

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of decompensated cirrhosis presenting with ascites, for which increasing the dose of spironolactone and furosemide would be the next best step of management. 

Increasing the dose of diuretics is recommended in ascitic patients when they are not controlled on the initial dose of diuretics, spironolactone 100mg/day, and furosemide 40mg/day.

Ascites is defined as the accumulation of free fluid within the peritoneal cavity. Patients who have developed ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, or variceal bleeding are classified in decompensated cirrhosis. Portal hypertension is significant in the development of ascites. 

Management of mild to moderate cirrhotic ascites:

* Restriction of sodium <2g/day 

* Tablet spironolactone 100mg/day and furosemide 40mg/day

* If a low-sodium diet is confirmed and fluid is not mobilised dose can be increased

* Spironolactone and furosemide are increased up to a maximum dose of 400mg/day and 160mg/day, respectively 

* If ascites is still present after all the above measures, it's termed as refractory ascites

Other options:

Option B and Option C:  Large volume paracentesis (more than 5 litres) is done in cases of refractory ascites, combining with 25% albumin IV infusion of 6–8 g/L of ascitic fluid removed to prevent circulatory dysfunction. 

Option D: Restriction of sodium diet <2g/day is the first step of management in mild to moderate ascites. Here, the patient is already on a low-sodium diet.

Pearl PM2049: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: 69. A 45-year-old hypertensive man complains of fever, migraine, loss of appetite, and myalgia. On examination, splinter hemorrhages and palpable purpura are noted. On CT angiography, aneurysm and stenosis of medium-sized vessels are observed. What is the type of hypersensitivity reaction associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa. It is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

The pathogenesis of systemic immune complex disease can be divided into three phases:

* Formation of immune complexes

* Deposition of immune complexes

* Inflammation and tissue injury.

Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions: 

* Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

* SLE

* Polyarteritis nodosa

* Serum sickness

* Arthus reaction

* Farmer’s lung

* Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

questions.text: 70. Which of the following is not a risk factor of endometrial cancer?
questions.solution:
Smoking is not a risk factor for endometrial cancer.

Risk factors of endometrial carcinoma include:

* Prolonged use of estrogen without progestins

* Obesity

* Diabetes

* Hypertension

* Nulliparity

* Late menopause

* Early menarche

* Lynch syndrome.

questions.text: 71. A 22-year-old male presents with primary infertility. He has never needed to shave frequently and has minimal body hair. On examination, he has a bifid scrotum, perineoscrotal hypospadias, gynecomastia, sparse facial hair, and underdeveloped muscle mass. Both testes are palpable in the inguinal canal, and pelvic ultrasound reveals no uterus. Laboratory investigations show a 46,XY karyotype with a mutation in the androgen receptor gene. Serum testosterone is normal to high, with elevated LH and FSH. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Reifenstein syndrome.

Reifenstein syndrome is also called partial androgen insensitivity syndrome (PAIS). It is caused by mutations in the androgen receptor (AR) gene, leading to partial resistance to androgens. Patients are genetically 46, XY males but exhibit varying degrees of undervirilization depending on the severity of receptor dysfunction.

Key clinical features are:

* Gynecomastia

* Sparse facial and body hair

* Undescended testes

* Small penis or ambiguous genitalia (bifid scrotum and perineoscrotal hypospadias)

* Normal to elevated testosterone

* Elevated LH and FSH (due to androgen resistance and feedback failure)

* Infertility

Other options:

Option A: Klinefelter syndrome is associated with a 47, XXY karyotype. Patients typically have small, firm testes, tall stature, and gynecomastia, but there is no defect in the androgen receptor.

Option B: Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (CAIS) is caused by a mutation in the androgen receptor, leading to complete resistance to androgens. Affected individuals have a 46, XY karyotype, female external genitalia, absent uterus, and no virilization at puberty.

Option C: In 5-alpha-reductase deficiency, testosterone acts normally at puberty. Individuals typically develop normal muscle mass and facial hair growth, along with other signs of masculinization. Gynecomastia is absent in 5-alpha-reductase deficiency. While ambiguous genitalia can be seen in both 5-alpha-reductase deficiency and partial androgen insensitivity syndrome (PAIS), the presence of gynecomastia, systemic signs of androgen resistance (sparse facial hair, underdeveloped muscle mass, primary infertility), and the androgen receptor mutation make Reifenstein syndrome (PAIS) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: 72. A 55-year-old male patient diagnosed with a urinary tract infection was prescribed an antibiotic that binds to the region marked by the arrow in the given image and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. Identify the drug given to this patient:
questions.solution:
From the clinical scenario, the drug given to the patient suffering from urinary tract infection is gentamicin. An antibiotic that binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis is an aminoglycoside and gentamicin is an aminoglycoside from the given options. 

Aminoglycosides like gentamicin act by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit. They also cause misreading of the mRNA.

Aminoglycosides include streptomycin, gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin, and kanamycin. They are bactericidal and the killing is concentration dependant. 

They are used in the treatment of aerobic gram-negative bacterial infections such as urinary tract infections, mycobacterial infections, tularemia, respiratory infections in cystic fibrosis, and other pseudomonal infections. Anaerobic bacteria are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides because the transport of aminoglycosides across the cytoplasmic membrane requires oxygen.  

The adverse effects of aminoglycosides include-

* Ototoxicity is characterized by irreversible high-frequency hearing loss and vestibular dysfunction. Streptomycin and gentamicin are the most vestibulotoxic. Amikacin, kanamycin, and neomycin mainly affect auditory functions. 

* Nephrotoxicity due to damage to proximal tubular cells. Neomycin, tobramycin, and gentamicin are the most nephrotoxic.

* Neuromuscular blockade due to inhibition of prejunctional release of acetylcholine and reduced sensitivity of the receptor to the neurotransmitter. The maximum blockade is by neomycin.

Resistance to aminoglycosides is typically due to drug inactivation by bacterial enzymes through acetylation, adenylation, or phosphorylation.  

Other options: 

Option A: Vancomycin is a glycopeptide that inhibits cell wall synthesis. It binds to terminal dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala of peptidoglycan to inhibit cell wall synthesis.

Options C and D: Clindamycin and chloramphenicol act by binding to the 50S subunit of the ribosome.

Pearl PM1271: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

* C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin

* E: Erythromycin (macrolides)

* L: Lincosamides

* L: Linezolid

* S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

* Te: Tetracyclines

* Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: 73. What is the specific antidote for the toxicity triggered by consuming the plant shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the flowers of Cerbera thevatia. Digibind (Digoxin immune Fab) is the specific antidote for the toxicity triggered by consuming the plant.

Digibind is effective against the toxicities of digitalis, Cerbera thevetia, Cerbera odallam and Nerium odorum and is given intravenously. Stomach wash and symptomatic treatment are also given.

All parts of the Cerbera thevatia (yellow oleander) are poisonous. The active principles are thevatin and thevatoxin, which are cardiac glycosides. Symptoms include a burning sensation in the mouth, tingling of the tongue, dryness of the throat, vomiting, diarrhoea, headache, dilated pupils, irregular action of the heart, followed by drowsiness, coma, collapse, and death. The lethal dose is 8 to 10 seeds, 15 to 20 grams of root, and 5 to 10 leaves. The fatal period is 2 to 3 hours following the consumption of its flowers.

Other options:

Option A: Datura contains active ingredients such as anticholinergic alkaloids atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. The seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked. The appropriate antidote is physostigmine, which is a reversible acetylcholine esterase antagonist. 

Option C: Andexanet alpha is a reversal agent against excess consumption of factor Xa inhibitors.

Option D: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug. It acts through reversible, competitive inhibition of the postsynaptic muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. It is indicated in the treatment of organophosphate/muscarinic poisoning.

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous



Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text: 74. A patient's blood investigations reveal the following: Na⁺ - 140 mEq/L, K⁺ - 5 mEq/L, HCO₃⁻ -18 mEq/L, Cl⁻ - 95 mEq/L. Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with these findings?
questions.solution:
Renal tubular acidosis is least likely to present with these findings.

The given reports show an elevated anion gap of 27 [Na - (Cl + HCO3) = 140 - (18+95)]. Elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis is seen in all of the above conditions, except renal tubular acidosis.

Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is associated with loss of alkali in urine. Reciprocal changes in the levels of Cl and HCO3 result in a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. 

Other options:

Option B: Ethylene glycol poisoning leads to high anion gap acidosis from toxic metabolites like oxalate and glycolate.

questions.text: 75. Which is the enzyme involved in the detoxification of ammonia in the brain?
questions.solution:
Glutamine synthetase is involved in the detoxification of ammonia in the brain. It combines ammonia with glutamate to form glutamine. It requires the hydrolysis of ATP.

Glutamine synthetase provides glutamine, which serves as a carrier of nitrogen, carbon, and energy between organs. It also plays a major role in ammonia detoxification and acid-base homeostasis.

The deficiency of glutamine synthetase in neonates results in severe brain damage, multiorgan failure, and death.

Other options:

Option A: Glutamate dehydrogenase is found in the liver mitochondria and deaminates glutamate to alpha-ketoglutarate and ammonia.

Option C: Glutamate aminotransferase converts α-amino nitrogen to ammonia along with glutamate dehydrogenase. This is termed transdeamination.

Option D: Glutaminase is present in the liver and converts glutamine back to glutamate and ammonia, which is then detoxified to urea.

questions.text: 76. A 50-year-old man presented with gradually progressive cough, hemoptysis, breathlessness and weight loss for the past 6 months. He has been working for a company that manufactures roofing sheets with asbestos for the past 15 years. The company did not provide him with personal protective equipment. Lung biopsy showed the following picture. Which immunohistochemical marker will be most likely positive in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture, occupational history of asbestos exposure and the histological image showing lepidic growth patterns are seen in adenocarcinoma of the lung. Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) will most likely be positive in this condition.

Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumour. It grows in various patterns, including acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid. It is usually more peripherally located and tends to be smaller. Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) is a protein first identified in the thyroid that is required for normal lung development.

Lepidic growth pattern refers to the pattern of spread of the tumour in which the tumour cells crawl along normal-appearing alveolar septae and resemble butterflies resting on a fence. Tumour cells are positive for mucin, napsin-A and thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1).

Asbestos exposure increases the risk of lung cancer development. Lung cancer is the most frequent malignancy in individuals exposed to asbestos, particularly when also exposed to smoking. The latent period between asbestos exposure and lung cancer is 10 to 30 years.

Other options:

Options A and B: Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.

Option D: P40 and P63 are the markers for squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: 77. Which of the following nerves produces the extraocular movement as seen in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows an elevation of the eye in adduction. It is caused by the inferior oblique muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

questions.text: 78. A 44-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a swelling on her hand as shown in the image below. She says that her fingertips change color when exposed to cold, and she has had occasional ulcers on her fingertips since last year. Auscultation reveals a loud P2. Laboratory investigations reveal normal renal function. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows calcinosis cutis, a feature commonly seen in patients with longstanding limited systemic sclerosis or CREST syndrome. The anticentromere antibody is positive in these patients.

CREST stands for calcinosis cutis, Raynaud’s phenomenon (color change in fingers on exposure to cold), esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasias. The condition can be associated with ulcers on the fingertips and isolated pulmonary hypertension (loud P2), which can be asymptomatic or present with reduced exercise capacity.

Calcinosis cutis is dystrophic calcification in the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and soft tissues. The serum calcium and phosphate levels are generally normal. 

Systemic sclerosis (SSc)  is a complex heterogeneous disorder that can potentially involve every organ system. There is significant variability in the patterns of skin involvement, organ complications, and rates of disease progression that gives rise to two major subtypes of the disease - diffuse cutaneous SSc and limited cutaneous SSc.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

* Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.

* Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis or CREST

* Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (option A)

* Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Other options:

Option C: Anti-Ro antibodies are used to diagnose Sjogren’s syndrome, which is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the involvement of the exocrine glands which results in impairment of salivary and lacrimal gland function. Although patients with Sjogren’s syndrome may have arthralgias, Raynaud’s phenomenon and cough, calcinosis cutis is not a feature of this disease.

Option D: Anti Mi-2 antibodies are highly specific for dermatomyositis which may have cutaneous manifestations such as Gottron's papules on the dorsum of the hands. This disease is characterized by proximal muscle weakness and is usually associated with an underlying malignancy.

80. Which of the following MRI imaging techniques produce a bright cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) appearance?

* T1 weighted image

* T2 weighted image

* STIR

* FLAIR
questions.solution:
A bright CSF appearance is seen in T2-weighted images and STIR (Short tau inversion recovery).

T1-weighted images:

* It is one of the basic MRI pulse sequences.

* The difference in the appearance of various tissues is due to their different T1 relaxation times.

* CSF has a long T1 time and appears dark.

T2-weighted images:

* It is also a basic MRI pulse sequence.

* It is based on the T2 relaxation time of the tissues.

* CSF appears bright in these images.

The image below shows both T1 and T2 weighted images.



Short tau inversion recovery(STIR):

* It is a form of inversion recovery sequence.

* It is used to selectively null signals from fat.

* The imaging sequence is identified by observing the fat tissues and fluid-filled spaces.

* Fluids like CSF appear bright, and fat appears dark.

The image below shows STIR.



Fluid attenuated inversion recovery(FLAIR):

* It is also a form of inversion recovery sequence.

* It is used to selectively null signals from fluids.

* Fluids like CSF appear dark, and pathological processes appear bright.

* It would appear as a fluid suppressed T2 image.

The image below shows FLAIR.

questions.text: 81. A child was having GTCS, and his EEG showed slow (3 Hz) spike-and-wave discharges. A primary diagnosis of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and was started on Rufinamide drug with other medications. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Rufinamide is a Sodium channel blocker.

Rufinamide is FDA-approved for adjunctive treatment of seizures related to Lennox-Gastaut syndrome in children aged 4 years and older and adults. It enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels and limits sustained repetitive firing, the firing pattern characteristic of focal seizures. It is well absorbed orally, minimally protein-bound in plasma and reaches peak plasma concentrations approximately 4 to 6 h after oral administration. It is metabolised by carboxylesterases, and the products are excreted in the urine.

It is effective against all seizure phenotypes in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. Common adverse effects are headache, dizziness, somnolence, fatigue and nausea.

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is defined by the triad:  

* Multiple seizure types (usually including generalised tonic-clonic, atonic, and atypical absence seizures)

* An EEG showing slow (<3 Hz) spike-and-wave discharges and a variety of other abnormalities

* Impaired cognitive function in most but not all cases

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is associated with CNS disease or dysfunction from a variety of causes, including de novo mutations, developmental abnormalities, perinatal hypoxia/ischemia, trauma, infection, and other acquired lesions. Many patients have a poor prognosis due to the underlying CNS disease and severe, poorly controlled epilepsy.

questions.text: 82. Which of the following nerves enters through the floor of the middle ear and gives sensory supply to the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Jacobson's nerve enters through the floor of the middle ear and gives sensory supply to the middle ear. Jacobson's nerve, a branch of glossopharyngeal, enters through the floor of the middle ear and forms the tympanic plexus on the promontory.

The floor of the middle ear is related to the internal jugular vein and glossopharyngeal nerve. Occasionally, the floor is deficient and the jugular bulb is then covered only by fibrous tissue and a mucous membrane, making it susceptible to injury during middle ear surgery. Jacobson's nerve, a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, along with branches from the sympathetic plexus, forms the tympanic plexus. This plexus provides sensation to the middle ear, upper eustachian tube, and medial surface of the tympanic membrane.

The middle ear can be likened to a room with a roof, floor, and 4 walls (anterior, posterior, medial & lateral), as shown in the image:



Other options:

Option A: Chorda tympani is a branch of the facial nerve which enters the middle ear through posterior canaliculus, and runs on the medial surface of the tympanic membrane between the handle of malleus and long process of incus, above the attachment of tendon of tensor tympani. It carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and supplies secretomotor fibres to the submaxillary and sublingual salivary glands. 

Option B: Arnold's nerve i.e. the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (CN X), supplies the concha and the corresponding eminence on the medial surface of pinna. 

Option D: Auriculotemporal nerve supplies the tragal area and crus helix.

questions.text: 83. A 56-year-old patient from West Africa presents with multiple skin lesions and generalised lymphadenopathy. Blood examination reveals peripheral lymphocytosis and hypercalcemia. Serology is positive for HTLV-1. What is the most characteristic shape of the nuclei in the tumour lymphocytes?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of skin lesions, lymphadenopathy, lymphocytosis and hypercalcemia with HTLV-1 infection is classic for Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma (ATLL). The most characteristic shape of the nuclei in the tumour lymphocytes is cloverleaf (flower-shaped).

ATLL shows multilobulated cloverleaf or flower-shaped nuclei in peripheral blood smear. HTLV-1 infection can also cause a progressive demyelinating disorder affecting the central nervous system and spinal cord. Most patients present with a rapidly worsening condition that is often fatal within months to one year, even with intensive chemotherapy. In rare cases, the disease is limited to the skin and progresses slowly.



Other options:

Option A: Cerebriform nuclei are seen in Mycosis fungoides / Sézary syndrome as shown below:



Option B: Horseshoe-shaped nuclei are seen in Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma (ALCL) as shown below:



Option D: Round nuclei with prominent nucleoli can be found in immunoblastic lymphoma or some diffuse large B-cell lymphomas, not in ATLL, as shown below:

questions.text: 84. Which component of the triangle of auscultation is formed by a muscle derived from branchial arch mesoderm?
questions.solution:
The medial border of the triangle of auscultation is formed by the trapezius muscle, which is derived from branchial arch mesoderm.

Trapezius, which forms the medial boundary of the triangle of auscultation, and the sternocleidomastoid develop from branchial arch mesoderm and are supplied by spinal accessory nerve.

The triangle of auscultation is a small triangular area located on the back. It is bounded

* Medially by the lateral border of the trapezius muscle 

* Laterally by the medial border of the scapula (Option B)

* Inferiorly by the upper border of the latissimus dorsi (Option C)

The floor of the triangle is formed by the sixth and seventh ribs, the sixth intercostal space, and the rhomboid major muscle. There is no separate anterior border of the triangle of auscultation anatomically (Option D). 

This region is unique because it is not covered by thick overlying muscles, making it an ideal site for clinical auscultation. Respiratory sounds from the apex of the lower lobe of the lung can be clearly heard through a stethoscope when placed over this area on either side of the back. On the left side, the cardiac orifice of the stomach lies deep to this triangle.

questions.text: 85. A young man presents with a painless mass in the submandibular region. On performing drainage, the discharge contained yellow granules and was foul-smelling. Microscopy of the sample showed gram-positive filamentous rods. The colonies on agar had a molar tooth appearance. Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
This is a typical case of cervicofacial actinomycosis. The patient presents with a painless nodule that indurates with purulent discharge that contains sulfur granules. Sulfur granules are composed of a matrix of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue. Penicillin is the drug of choice.

Actinomycosis is an indolent, slowly progressive suppurative and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules. It is caused by anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria, primarily of the genus Actinomyces.

 

It presents as one of the following clinical types:

* Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) a fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)

* Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 

* Abdominal actinomycosis- following a ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.

* Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonisation of intrauterine contraceptive devices.

* Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.



Diagnosis:

* Gram staining of sulfur granules shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures. (sunray appearance)

* Culture shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies.

The image below shows the molar tooth appearance of the Actinomyces colonies.





Treatment requires prolonged administration of penicillin for about 6–12 months. Clindamycin or erythromycin can be used in penicillin-allergic patients. Surgical excision and drainage may be required.

questions.text: 86. The triple therapy for maintenance of immunosuppression for organ transplant doesn’t include which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
The triple therapy for maintenance of immunosuppression for organ transplant doesn’t include an IL-2 receptor blocker. It is a part of the induction therapy.

Immunosuppression for transplantation has two phases:

* Induction therapy consists of a combination of

*

* High-dose intravenous steroids

* Anti-CD25 monoclonal antibody basiliximab (IL-2 receptor blocker)

* Other induction agents for high-risk cases are ATG and the monoclonal antibody alemtuzumab (Campath)

* Maintenance therapy consists of Triple therapy, with

*

* Calcineurin inhibitor (ciclosporin or tacrolimus)

* Antiproliferative agent (azathioprine or mycophenolic acid)

* Steroids

questions.text: 88. Which of the following hormone is deficient in Laron syndrome?
questions.solution:
Insulin-like growth factor-1 is deficient in Laron syndrome.

Laron syndrome/dwarfism is caused by end-organ resistance to growth hormone due to the mutation of the growth hormone receptor.

Growth hormones are produced, but are not able to act on the target tissues as growth hormone receptors are not responding to growth hormones in the target tissues. So, the resting and stimulated growth hormone levels are high, and insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels are low.

The only specific treatment available for this condition is subcutaneous injections of insulin-like growth factor 1 (a growth-promoting hormone).

questions.text: 89. While examining a patient, the doctor finds a brownish black abrasion on his arm. When could the patient have probably suffered this injury?
questions.solution:
The patient would have probably suffered this injury 5 days ago. Abrasion appears brownish-black in colour 4-7 days after the injury.

Abrasion types:

* Linear abrasions (scratches): Caused by the relative movement of a pointed object on the skin. It leaves a clean area at the start and tags at the end.

* e.g. nail, thorn, or the point of a sword or knife.

* Grazed abrasions (sliding /scrapping/grinding abrasion): Caused by the relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin.

* known as brush burns.

* e.g. fall, a victim being dragged on the ground, a road traffic accident.

* Impact abrasions (imprint abrasions): Caused by the impact of a rigid, hard, rough surface over a localised area of the skin, without any movement

* e.g. fingernails, tires, grills, bicycle chains, or bite marks.

* Friction abrasions (pressure abrasion): Caused by pressure upon the skin with an agent with a smooth surface, accompanied by movement.

* e.g. ligature marks around the neck in hanging, strangulation.

* Patterned abrasion: Caused by impact abrasion or pressure abrasion, reproducing the pattern of the object that caused it

Note: Grazed abrasion is the most common type of abrasion.

questions.text: 90. A 50-year-old woman with a history of pleomorphic adenoma in the left parotid gland comes to the clinic for follow-up three weeks after a parotidectomy. She complains of flushing, sweating, and burning sensation on the left side of her face every time she sits down to have a meal. The area is also pruritic. The postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibres of which of the following nerves is the likely culprit for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The symptom complex in this patient, coupled with a history of recent parotid surgery, is indicative of Frey's syndrome, in which the Auriculotemporal nerve, marked as "D" is involved.

Frey’s syndrome/Gustatory sweating (auriculotemporal syndrome)

* Commonly develops after parotid surgery or other trauma that results in the opening of the parotid capsule

* It results from damage to the autonomic innervation of the salivary gland. There is a regeneration of the parasympathetic nerve fibres that stimulate the sweat glands of the overlying skin in response to salivary stimulation or mastication

* It is thought to reflect abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face by regrowing parasympathetic secretomotor axons that would previously have innervated the parotid gland

* Clinical features:

* Sweating, warmth, and erythema over the region of surgical excision of the parotid gland. This is due to the autonomic stimulation of salivation by the smell/taste of food

* Diagnosis:

* The starch iodine will aid in diagnosis. The affected area painted with iodine will turn blue on exposure to sweat

* Management:

* Prevention: Sternomastoid muscle flap, temporalis fascial flap, and insertion of an artificial membrane between the skin and the parotid bed will minimise the inappropriate regeneration of the autonomic nerve fibres

* Treatment:

* Antiperspirants with aluminium chloride

* Subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area

* Denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion has been advocated, but is often not curative

questions.text: 91. A 2-week-old neonate presents with failure to thrive, abdominal distension and severe vomiting due to malabsorption. Genetic analysis showed an autosomal recessive mutation in the LIPA gene. The infant's condition improves after the administration of Sebelipase alfa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a neonate presenting with failure to thrive, abdominal distension and severe vomiting with genetic analysis showing an autosomal recessive mutation in the LIPA gene along with improvement in symptoms following the administration of Sebelipase alfa, points towards a probable diagnosis of Wolman disease.

Wolman disease is a rare disorder that results from an autosomal recessive mutation in the LIPA gene that provides instructions for producing an enzyme called lysosomal acid lipase (LAL). This leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in most of the visceral organs, leading to the above symptoms. Patients present in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.

LAL deficiency can present in two forms- Wolman disease and cholesterol ester storage disease. Cholesterol ester storage disease (CESD) is less severe and usually presents late in adulthood, whereas Wolman disease presents within the first few weeks of life and results in death within the first 6 months of life. 

Wolman disease can be diagnosed by measuring LAL activity in peripheral leukocytes or cultured skin fibroblasts.

Treatment involves enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) with Sebelipase alfa which was recently approved by the FDA. It is given every other week at a dose of 1 mg/kg body weight and has the potential to prolong survival in patients with CESD and save lives in those with severe Wolman syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Abetalipoproteinemia is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a defect in the MTTP gene that catalyzes the transfer of triglycerides to nascent ApoB particles in the ER. It is associated with severe fat malabsorption/ steatorrhea from birth. There is a decrease in the plasma levels of cholesterol (<50 mg/dL) and triglycerides (<20 mg/dL). As a result, there is marked accumulation of triglycerides in the intestinal villous enterocytes due to the absence of chylomicron and VLDL formation. 

Option B: Farber disease results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme acid ceramidase. Thus, ceramide accumulates in various tissues, especially the joints. Symptoms include painful joint swelling and nodule formation, resembling rheumatoid arthritis within the first year of life.

Option D: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Low HDL levels are seen. Clinical features include hyperplastic yellow-orange tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral neuropathy, which may be either relapsing-remitting or chronic progressive in nature.

The child is expected to weigh 12 kg at 2 years of age.

questions.text:
94. A 45-year-old woman presented with a breast lump categorized as BI-RADS 4. What is the next best step in management?

BI-RADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System
questions.solution:
The best option for further management would be tissue diagnosis by biopsy.

A BI-RADS category 4 is indicative of a suspicious abnormality with the likelihood of malignancy being 2% to 95%. Therefore, the next best step would be a tissue diagnosis by biopsy to rule out/confirm the malignancy.

The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) is used to categorize the degree of suspicion of malignancy for a mammographic abnormality. This is helpful when mammographic abnormalities that cannot be detected by the patient's physical examination include clustered microcalcifications and areas of abnormal density that have not yielded a palpable finding.

Other options:

Option A: Annual screening is usually done for BI-RADS categories 1 and 2.

BI-RADS 1 means that there are no masses, suspicious calcifications, or areas of architectural distortion on mammography.

BI-RADS 2 is consistent with benign findings, including secretory calcifications, simple cysts, fat-containing lesions, calcified fibroadenomas, implants, and intramammary lymph nodes.

Option B: Bi-annual screening is done for BI-RADS category 3. BI-RADS 3 includes a non-palpable, circumscribed mass or a solitary group of punctate calcifications on a mammogram.

Option D: Surgical excision/lumpectomy is done for BI-RADS category 6, which indicates a known, biopsy-proven malignancy.

questions.text: 95. Which among the following enzymes does not contribute in the reversible phase of the pentose phosphate pathway?
questions.solution:
6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase is involved in the irreversible oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway.

The pentose phosphate pathway (hexose monophosphate shunt) is an alternative metabolic route for glucose utilization. It serves two primary functions:

* Production of NADPH, which is essential for fatty acid and steroid biosynthesis, as well as for maintaining reduced glutathione involved in cellular antioxidant defense

* Synthesis of ribose sugars, required for the formation of nucleic acids and nucleotides.

The pathway operates entirely within the cytosol and consists of two distinct phases:

* Irreversible oxidative phase: Glucose-6-phosphate undergoes dehydrogenation and decarboxylation, leading to the formation of ribulose-5-phosphate and the generation of NADPH

* Reversible non-oxidative phase: Ribulose-5-phosphate is converted into intermediates that can re-enter glycolysis or regenerate glucose-6-phosphate, depending on cellular needs.



NADPH produced by the pentose phosphate pathway is vital for regenerating reduced glutathione, which protects red blood cells from oxidative damage. Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase impairs this process, leading to hemolytic anemia under oxidative stress.

Note: Transketolase, keto-isomerase, and phosphohexose isomerase are involved in the reversible non-oxidative phase.

questions.text: 96. Which of the following statements is true regarding the intrauterine device shown below?

choices.text: It has silver added to the copper wire
It can be used as an emergency contraceptive
It has a lifespan of 10 years

questions.solution:
The given image shows the intrauterine contraceptive device, multi-load copper 250. It can be used for emergency contraception.

Once placed inside the uterine cavity, the multi-load copper 250 device acts as a foreign body and induces inflammatory changes in the endometrium. Copper released from the device causes enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrium. It increases uterine contractility, leading to the expulsion of the fertilized egg from the fallopian tube into the endometrium before the development of chorionic villi and ultimately causes failure of implantation.

The fertilized egg is then engulfed by the macrophages recruited due to the inflammatory changes. In addition, the device hinders the migration of the sperm. The lifespan of multi-load copper 250 is about 3-5 years.

Other options:

Option A: Nova T has silver added to the copper wire, which prolongs its lifespan to 5 years. 

Option C: Copper T 380 A (Paraguard) is effective as a contraceptive for up to 10 years, and is shown in the image below.



Option D: Mirena IUCD contains levonorgestrel 52 mg, and is shown below



Other important intrauterine devices are progestasert having 38 mg of progesterone and levonova containing 60mg of levonorgestrel (LNG).

questions.text: 97. The STEPS by WHO is aimed at:

choices.text: Surveillance of risk factors for non-communicable diseases
Surveillance of risk factors for communicable diseases
Surveillance of mortality due to nosocomial infections
Surveillance of morbidity in the visually impaired

questions.solution:
WHO STEPwise approach to Surveillance (STEPS) is used for surveillance of adult risk factors for non-communicable diseases and for stroke surveillance.

WHO STEPS approach is a survey methodology developed to assess risk factors of non-communicable diseases (NCD). It helps the countries to establish an NCD surveillance system. The steps include the following:

* Questionnaires contain questions about behavioral risk factors like tobacco use, alcohol use, diet, and physical activity. 

* Physical measurements contain blood pressure, height, weight, and waist size

* Biochemical measurements contain blood glucose, blood lipids, urinary sodium, and creatinine.  

Surveillance is defined as systematic and continuous data analysis and taking appropriate preventive actions according to the results obtained. Identification of cases that are missed and not notified is known as sentinel surveillance. It is used in communicable diseases such as HIV, malaria, etc.

98. How will you calculate the sensitivity of a test from the information given below?

* x: Total population under study 

* y: Total diseased population out of 'x'

* z: Total population testing positive out of 'y'
questions.solution:
The sensitivity of a test from the given information can be calculated by z/y.

The sensitivity of a test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives i.e. z) out of the total diseased population (y). 

The specificity of a test is given by those who do not have the disease and test negative (true negatives) out of the total non-diseased population.

The positive predictive value of the test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total positive population.

The negative predictive value of the test is given by those who do not have the disease and test negative (true negatives) out of the total negative population.

* It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.

* PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.

questions.text: 100. A 20-year-old primigravida is in labor and it was noted that the action potentials of a single unit of myometrium caused the entire uterus to contract or relax simultaneously. This is possible due to the presence of which intercellular connections?
questions.solution:
The intercellular connections responsible for the myometrial cells causing the entire uterus to contract or relax simultaneously are gap junctions. During the time of labour, the number of these gap junctions is also increased under the influence of estrogen, thereby increasing the intensity of uterine contractility. 

Gap junctions are intercellular junctions that allow the passage of ions and smaller molecules between the cells. It permits rapid cell-to-cell spread of action potentials that provide for coordinated and smooth contraction. 

They are present in intercalated discs, uterus, urinary bladder, ureter, choroid plexus between the cells etc. The cells in these organs constitute a unit or syncytium containing thousands of smooth muscle fibres that contract together as a single unit. 

 Thus, the functions of gap junctions include - 

* Passage of ions, sugars, amino acids, and other solutes with molecular weight up to about 1000 Da. It permits these substances to pass between the cells without entering the extracellular fluid. 

* Provide both chemical and electrical coupling between cells. 

The structural unit present in the gap junctions is connexons, made of subunits called connexins. These connexons determine the permeability and selectivity of these junctions. 

Mutations of the connexin have predisposed to conditions like arteriosclerosis, myoclonic epilepsy, idiopathic atrial fibrillation, and Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (X-linked).



Other options - 

Option B: Tight junctions or zonula occludens are present around the apical margins of the cells in epithelia such as the intestinal mucosa, the walls of the renal tubules, and the choroid plexus. They have ridges, half from each cell, which adhere so strongly that there is no space between the cells. These tight junctions permit the passage of ions, solutes, and intracellular signalling molecules between adjacent cells via the paracellular pathway.

Option C: Hemidesmosomes attach cells to the underlying basal lamina and are connected intracellularly to intermediate filaments. They contain integrins.

Option D: Adherent junctions or zonula adherens is a continuous structure on the basal side of the zonula occludens. It contains cadherins.

questions.text: 101. A patient presenting to emergency due to bronchospasm and angioedema is administered adrenaline. Which of the following actions of adrenaline does not contribute to its effects in this scenario?

choices.text: Action on blood vessels via alpha-receptors

questions.solution:
Action on presynaptic alpha-receptors is not a mechanism of adrenaline in the case of anaphylaxis.

Epinephrine (adrenaline) is a potent stimulant of both α and β adrenergic receptors. It is a physiological antagonist of histamine, which is a mediator of acute hypersensitivity reactions. Adrenaline is life-saving in case of laryngeal edema and anaphylaxis. The vasoconstrictor, cardiac stimulant, and bronchodilator actions contribute to these effects.

* Adrenaline increases heart rate and force of cardiac contraction primarily through β1 receptors

* The α receptors (both α1 and α2) cause vasoconstriction in the precapillary arterioles, increasing peripheral vascular resistance and blood pressure. This reduces any tissue edema that has developed as a result of the increased vascular permeability.

* It is a potent bronchodilator by acting on β2 receptor, which is more marked when the bronchi are constricted in case of anaphylaxis.

Presynaptic α2 receptors on nerve endings are responsible for the inhibition of neurotransmitter release and decreased central sympathetic flow.

questions.text: 102. A 19-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of progressive swelling in his left arm. An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Radiotherapy is mandatory as it is a highly radiosensitive tumor
Cisplatin  is the chemotherapeutic agent of choice
The goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy is to treat micro metastasis.
Hindquarter amputation is indicated in tumors involving upper end of tibia

questions.solution:
The X-ray showing periosteal lifting and sunburst appearance is suggestive of osteosarcoma, and the goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy in osteosarcoma is to treat micro-metastasis.

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal.

The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. 

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a "Codman's triangle" or it may have a "sunburst (sunray) appearance" on X-ray.

The image given in the question shows the following features:

* Irregular destruction in the metaphysis is overshadowed by the formation of new bone

* Lifting of the periosteum due to the formation of new bone inciting a periosteal reaction

* Bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumor centrifugally gives rise to a "sunburst (sunray) appearance" on the radiograph.

Treatment:

Osteosarcoma is treated by neoadjuvant chemotherapy, wide excision, or radical surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Since here, safe margins are difficult to achieve, limb ablation is done. Osteosarcoma is a radioresistant tumor

The goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy is to treat micrometastasis.

T-10 protocol of chemotherapy is used in the management of osteosarcoma. It involves:

* High-dose methotrexate and Citrovorum factor rescue

* Adriamycin

* BCD (bleomycin, cyclophosphamide, dactinomycin/doxorubicin)

Note: T-10 protocol is replaced with newer protocols such as MAP (High dose Methotrexate, Doxorubicin, Cisplatin) protocol as per National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN).

Levels of amputation in osteosarcoma:

Upper end of the humerus Forequarter amputation
Upper end of the tibia Midthigh amputation
Upper end of the femur Hindquarter amputation and hip disarticulation
Lower end of the femur Midthigh amputation and hip disarticulation
