questions.text: 103. All are true about Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy except?

choices.text: Optic atrophy in one eye may precede the other

questions.solution:
Abnormal pupillary reaction is the incorrect statement. In Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy, the pupillary reaction is normal.

Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) is characterised by subacute optic neuropathy. It is usually seen in males due to a point mutation in the maternal mitochondrial DNA. Clinical features include:

* Pupillary reactions are often normal

* Visual loss is painless 

* Both eyes are always involved, although one may precede the other by a period varying from a few days to 18 months

* Visual fields show centrocecal scotoma

* The fundus shows blurring of the edges of the disc in the initial stages. Small, telangiectatic blood vessels can be seen near the disc that do not leak on fluorescein angiography.

* Optic atrophy develops, in the later stages, after several months with pallor confined to the temporal side or involving the whole disc.

No specific treatment is effective, and genetic counselling should be offered.

questions.text: 104. A 10-year-old boy presented with growth over the nasal aspect of the left eye. Initially, it was small but has now progressed to the size shown in the image below. The vision was 6/12 in the left eye and refraction examination revealed astigmatism. Choose the correct statement regarding the management of this case.

choices.text: It is best left alone for spontaneous resolution
Only medical management is sufficient at this stage
Limbal conjunctival tissue from the same eye can be used for grafting
Application of mitomycin C drops reduces recurrence with no complications

questions.solution:
The clinical case and image point to a diagnosis of pterygium with astigmatism, for which conjunctival autografting is an effective method of treatment after excision. Conjunctival tissue can be taken from the limbus on the same side or from the other eye for grafting.

A pterygium is a degenerative subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching on the cornea. It is most commonly seen on the nasal aspect of the eye. It is made up of three parts:

* cap (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge)

* head

* body

Patients may be asymptomatic or present with irritation, grittiness, or episodes of inflammation. As it enlarges, it can obstruct vision and lead to astigmatism.

Treatment: 

* A pterygium is best left alone unless:

* It is progressing towards the pupillary area

* Causes excessive astigmatism

* Restricts ocular motility

* Causes disfigurement.

* Excision: Simple excision of the pterygium is associated with a high recurrence rate, and should be combined with:

* Mitomycin C drops- applied pre-operatively/ intra-operatively, or post-operatively to prevent a recurrence. However, it may lead to complications like scleral necrosis, cataract, and iritis, and should be used judiciously. 

* Beta irradiation

* Conjunctival autografting- limbal tissue from the same or other eye is grafted and secured with fibrin glue or sutures.

* Amniotic membrane graft

* Peripheral lamellar keratoplasty if the lesion is deep.

questions.text: 105. An infant presented with a lack of tonicity of the abdominal wall along with a wrinkled appearance of the skin as shown in the figure. Further examination reveals the diagnosis to be Eagle Barrett syndrome. Which of the following is not a component of the characteristic triad seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Eagle Barrett Syndrome is also known as Prune Belly Syndrome (Triad Syndrome), and kyphosis is not a component of the characteristic triad seen in this condition.

Prune Belly Triad includes:

* Cryptorchidism

* Abdominal Wall Defects

* Genitourinary Defects

Features of Prune Belly Syndrome:

* Flabby, hypotonic, and thin abdominal wall - Due to deficient abdominal wall muscles

* Urethral obstruction in the Fetal Life

* Predominantly seen in males

Associated defects:

* Posterior urethral valve

* Vesicoureteric Reflux

* Limb Anomalies and Scoliosis

Treatment :

* Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism

* Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjunction with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

questions.text: 106. Which of the following would you not expect on administering etomidate to a patient?
questions.solution:
Etomidate does not cause hemodynamic instability due to the lack of influence on the sympathetic nervous system and baroreceptor functions.

Due to this characteristic, etomidate is a useful anesthetic agent for patients with poor cardiac function and/or hemorrhagic shock. 

Etomidate is an intravenous anesthetic agent. Etomidate depresses the reticular activating system and mimics the inhibitory effects of GABA. It has a rapid onset with a shorter duration of action. 

Adverse effects include post-operative nausea and vomiting, myoclonus, pain at the injection site, and transient acute adrenal insufficiency.

Other options:

Option A: Adrenocortical suppression is caused by inhibition of the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase, resulting in decreased biosynthesis of cortisol.

Option C: Thrombophlebitis, a side effect of etomidate, may be avoided by the use of the anesthetic's lipid formulation.

Option D: The incidence of myoclonus may be reduced by premedication with a hypnotic agent such as midazolam.

questions.text: 107. A 3-year-old boy born to an HIV-positive mother is brought to the clinic with the findings shown in the image below. Which other condition can this child develop in the clinical stage that he is currently in?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of esophageal candidiasis and the image showing Kaposi's sarcoma is suggestive of HIV Stage IV according to the WHO staging of HIV/AIDS in children with confirmed HIV infection. The other condition that can develop in this stage is cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.

Other Options:

Option A: Persistent parotid enlargement is seen in stage 2. 

Option B: Persistent oral candidiasis is seen in stage 3. 

Option D: Persistent hepatosplenomegaly is seen in stage 2.

Pearl PM2302: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. questions.text: 108. Which of the following transfusion-related complications is not prevented or reduced by leukoreduction?
questions.solution:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is not prevented or reduced by leukoreduction. 

TRALI usually results from donor plasma containing high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies, which bind to the recipient's antigens. It can also be caused by anti-HLA class I and anti-HNA antibodies, or cytokine/chemokine-mediated mechanisms. These are not mitigated by leukoreduction. Instead, TRALI risk is reduced by careful donor selection, such as using male plasma donors or nulliparous/parous females without anti-HLA antibodies.

Other options: 

Option A: Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction is prevented by leukoreduction, especially pre-storage leukoreduction.

Option C: Leukoreduction removes the donor WBCs expressing HLA antigens, which prevents the incidence of HLA alloimmunization.

Option D: Leukoreduction reduces WBCs, thereby decreasing the occurrence of infections transmitted by these cells e.g., CMV. 

The image below shows a leukoreduction filter, which is used for filtering out donor WBCs.

questions.text: 109. A 38-year-old male patient presents to the OPD for evaluation of low back pain. The patient gives a history that he also feels pain in the back of the leg and at the ankles. On examination, there is decreased sensation in the ankle region, and the ankle jerk reflex is diminished. The test shown in the image is positive. Which of the following is not an absolute indication for surgical management in this condition?

choices.text: Marked progressive weakness of the muscles

questions.solution:
The clinical features and a positive straight leg raising test, as shown in the image, are suggestive of an intervertebral disc prolapse involving the L5-S1 nerve root. Recurrent episodes of severe sciatica are only a relative indication for surgical management.

Indications for surgical management: 

Absolute indications:

* Failed conservative management.

* Marked progressive weakness of muscles.

* Progressive neurological deficit.

* Cauda equina paralysis.

Relative Indications:

* Recurrent episodes of incapacitating sciatica

* Pain unrelieved by complete rest from activity.

Features of Intervertebral disc prolapse (IVDP) pain:

* Pain is increased by flexion episodes, sneezing, coughing, straining, and sitting

* Pain is decreased by rest and in the semi-Fowler position (lying in a bed supine with the head of the bed raised at approximately 30 to 45 degrees)

* Leg pain that is equal to or greater than back pain in cases of intervertebral disc prolapse (IVDP) indicates nerve root involvement caused by the herniated disc.

Important tests for diagnosis:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT) or Lasegue sign

This is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area.  The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in the neutral position. The affected leg is then passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. The examiner stops further leg elevation when pain is elicited. Normally, it should be possible to raise the limb to 80–90 degrees. The SLRT test is positive if the patient develops pain when the leg is between 30 and 60/70 degrees from horizontal. The pain should be radicular type and radiating to the back of the thigh or to the calf.



2. Bragard test (or Sciatic stretch test or Flip test)

Perform SLRT. At the point where the patient experiences discomfort, the leg is lowered a little. The stretching and pain become less. At this angle, the ankle is passively dorsiflexed. If the pain at the back of the thigh or in the calf is felt again, the test is positive. This is also called reinforcement positive or Bragard’s sign positive



3. Crossed SLRT (or well-leg raising test or Fajersztajn sign)

When SLRT is performed on the unaffected side, the patient may feel pain on the affected side. This is termed a contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is a very specific sign of root compression. It becomes positive usually when there is severe compression due to a centrally located prolapse.

4. Bowstring sign (or popliteal compression test)

The ‘bowstring sign’ is even more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. Perform SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Without reducing the amount of lift, bend the knee so as to relax the sciatic nerve (Buckling sign). Buttock pain is immediately relieved. The examiner then presses the popliteal fossa to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. This will tighten the nerve like a bowstring and re-induce the pain.



5. Femoral stretch (reverse Lasegue test or Mackiewicz sign)

The patient lies prone. The examiner flexes the knee to the thigh and the hip is passively extended. The test is positive if the patient experiences anterior thigh pain. This test is usually positive for L2-L3 and L3-L4 (high lumbar) protrusions



Treatment:

Conservative:

* Continuous bed rest and traction for 2 weeks will reduce the herniation in over 90% of cases.

* Back exercises and posture correction are also a part of conservative management

* Epidural steroids

Surgical: Surgical procedures include laminectomy, hemilaminectomy, fenestration surgery, and microscopic & endoscopic lumbar discectomy.

questions.text: 110. A 47-year-old male body builder presents with chronic abdominal pain. On examination, you notice a mass between the umbilicus and the xiphoid. The patients pain increases when he lies down. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic abdominal pain with a mass present between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus makes an epigastric hernia the likely diagnosis.

Epigastric hernias arise due to chronic force, like lifting weights or coughing, on a congenitally weak linea alba. These patients present with a dull aching pain initially. The pain increases on lying on the back. The herniated mass is usually small, and there may be multiple discrete masses. The omentum and falciform ligament are present most commonly in the herniated mass. 

Diagnosis is via ultrasonography of the abdomen. Treatment is surgical to strengthen the linea alba and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: 111. A patient presents with a history of drug abuse and multiple unstable relationships. You notice scars on the patient’s forearm that look self-inflicted. The patient also mentions a long-lasting feeling of emptiness and anger issues in relationships. Which of the following personality disorders is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is indicative of borderline personality disorder.

Borderline personality disorder belongs to cluster B of personality disorders. Diagnostic features of this disorder include at least five of the following:

* Frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment

* Unstable or intense interpersonal relationships, alternating between idealization and devaluation

* Markedly and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self

* Impulsivity in at least two potentially self-damaging areas (spending, sex, reckless driving, substance abuse, binge eating)

* Recurrent suicidal behavior, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behaviors

* Instability of affect due to marked reactivity of mood

* Chronic feelings of emptiness

* Inappropriately intense anger or difficulty controlling anger

* Stress-related, transient paranoid ideation or dissociative symptoms.

Associated features can include a tendency to undermine self when close to reaching a goal and an intense attachment to non-human objects like pets and material things rather than to other humans.

Other options:

Option B: Histrionic Personality Disorder involves excessive emotionality and attention-seeking, but not typically self-harm or chronic emptiness.

Option C: Antisocial Personality Disorder is associated with disregard for others’ rights, deceit, and criminal behavior, but not characterized by emotional instability or self-harm in the same way.

Option D: Schizoid Personality Disorder involves detachment from social relationships and limited emotional expression, but without unstable relationships or impulsivity.

questions.text: 112. A patient is about to undergo a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Which of the following supraglottic airway devices is potentially unsuitable for the procedure?
questions.solution:
LMA classic can potentially be unsuitable for laparoscopic surgeries because of the increased risk of pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents. This is because the abdomen is inflated during laparoscopic surgeries, and hence, the risk of aspiration is high.

All the other devices mentioned (second-generation supraglottic airway devices) provide highly improved airway sealing for the same cuff pressure. These devices also have a dedicated gastric port to drain secretions. Hence, aspiration risk is very low with these devices. For this reason, these devices are preferred over the LMA classic in 

* Surgeries adopting non-supine positions (lateral, prone)

* Laparoscopic surgeries

* Gynaecological surgeries

* Obese patients

questions.text: 113. A woman who was a victim of sexual assault finally opens up to her group during group therapy about the night of the assault and reveals suppressed memories. After doing so, she feels a sense of relief. Which of the following best describes what this woman experienced?
questions.solution:
The sense of relief that the woman experiences on expressing her suppressed memories is known as catharsis.

Catharsis is a general term for the process of releasing strong or suppressed emotions. The expression of ideas, thoughts, and suppressed emotions is accompanied by an emotional response that produces a state of relief in the patient. 

Other options:

Option A: Transference is a psychoanalytical term for the projection of feelings, thoughts, and wishes by the patient onto the therapist. It occurs when the patient transfers their feelings towards an object from their past onto the therapist. 

Option C: Altruism is a beneficial factor of group therapy wherein a member of the group helps another member by putting that person's needs before their own. By doing so, the person learns the value of giving to others. 

Option D: Insight is when a patient gains awareness and understanding of their psychodynamics and symptoms of maladaptive behavior.

These are mainly of two types of insight:

* Intellectual insight - This refers to knowledge and awareness of the person, but does not reflect any changes in the maladaptive behavior

* Emotional insight - This is awareness and understanding that leads to a positive change in the personality and behavior of that person.

questions.text: 114. A patient with erectile dysfunction did not respond to PDE-5 inhibitor drugs. A second-line treatment involves the injection of prostaglandin into the part of the penis marked as X in the image below. Which is the prostaglandin used?
questions.solution:
The part marked as X in the image is the corpus cavernosum, and prostaglandin indicated for direct intracavernosal injection for erectile dysfunction is PGE1- Alprostadil.



Alprostadil is a natural PGE1 preparation available as an intraurethral suppository and intracavernosal injection. It is a second-line treatment for erectile dysfunction. It is rapidly metabolised and can lead to prolonged erection in a few patients. Alprostadil is also used for temporarily maintaining the patency of a patent ductus arteriosus in neonates. 

Other Prostaglandins/Prostaglandin analogues:

* PGE1 analogue: Misoprostol is approved for the termination of pregnancy and the prevention of NSAID-induced gastric ulcers.

* PGE2: Dinoprostone is used for cervical ripening, induction of labour, and as abortifacients in the second trimester of pregnancy.

* PGI2: Epoprostenol improves symptoms and delays the need for lung or heart-lung transplantation in Pulmonary artery hypertension.

* PGI2 analogues: Iloprost and Treprostinil are used in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension.

* PGF2α: Carboprost is used to induce second-trimester abortions and to control postpartum haemorrhage. Latanoprost is a long-acting PGF2α derivative, used for glaucoma. Similar prostanoids with ocular hypotensive effects include bimatoprost, tafluprost, and travoprost.

questions.text: 115. A study was conducted on the efficacy of oral contraceptive pills. Out of 100 women who took the pills, 10 women became pregnant within 24 months. What is the Pearl Index?
questions.solution:
The Pearl index is calculated to be 5 per hundred woman years.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

In this scenario, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 10.

There are 100 couples who are exposed to the method.

So, the total months of exposure are 24 months x 100 = 2400.

We arrive at this: Pearl index = 10 x 1200/2400 = 5 per hundred woman-years

Pearl PM1715: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).



* In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.

* In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

* It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.

* It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.

* Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: 116. A patient from Columbia presented with fever and anemia. He is diagnosed with Oroya fever. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Bartonella bacilliformis is the causative organism of Oroya fever. 

Oroya fever is also known as Carrion's disease and presents as fever with progressive anemia due to bacterial invasion of erythrocytes.

A late sequela in survivors of Oroya fever or in individuals with asymptomatic Bartonella bacilliformis infection is known as verruga peruana. It is characterized by the appearance of vascular, nodular skin lesions that emerge in successive crops. An image of verruga peruana is shown below.



Option A: Streptobacillus moniliformis & Spirillum minus cause Rat bite fever.

Option C: Bartonella quintana causes trench fever or 5-day fever.

Option D: Bartonella henselae causes cat scratch disease. It also causes bacillary angiomatosis and bacillary peliosis in HIV infected people.

questions.text:
117. How do the following hormones affect appetite?

* Leptin

* Orexin

* Ghrelin
questions.solution:
Leptin decreases the appetite, whereas ghrelin and orexin increase the appetite.

* Leptin, secreted by adipose tissue, acts on the hypothalamus to suppress appetite and increase energy expenditure.

* Orexin, produced in the hypothalamus, promotes wakefulness and also plays a role in stimulating food intake.

* Ghrelin, released from the stomach in the fasting state, stimulates appetite by activating hypothalamic neurons.

questions.text: 118. Which of the following is the preferred drug for patients with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs)?
questions.solution:
Sunitinib is the preferred drug for patients with imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs). 

Sunitinib is an inhibitor of Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGFR) and intracellular kinases participating in angiogenesis. It can also be used in the treatment of metastatic renal cell carcinoma and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours. It can lead to bleeding, hypertension, proteinuria, thromboembolism and gastrointestinal perforations.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GIST) are mesenchymal tumours originating from the interstitial cells of Cajal, located in the gastrointestinal myenteric plexus. The most common mutation associated with GIST is the c-KIT gene mutation. Most of the tumours are found in the stomach, but they can arise from any part of the GIT. Symptoms of GIST include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and hematemesis. GIST can also present as an asymptomatic mass in the abdomen.

They are diagnosed incidentally on endoscopy and can be confirmed by targeted biopsy by endoscopic ultrasound. The primary mode of treatment is surgical resection. Tumours>5 cm in size are considered to have metastatic potential, and such patients should continue to receive imatinib after surgery as well.

Other options:

Option A: Sorafenib is an intracellular inhibitor of multiple kinases used in hepatocellular carcinoma. It is not preferred, but may be used as a later-line option in advanced gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs) after failure of both imatinib and sunitinib.

Option C: Vandetanib is a multikinase inhibitor used in progressing, locally advanced medullary thyroid cancer.

Option D: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to VEGF and is used in multiple cancer regimens, including in metastatic colorectal cancer.

Pearl PM1081: Indications for Imatinib

* Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)

C-KIT mutations

* Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans

* Hypereosinophilia syndrome

* Chronic myelomonocytic leukaemia (CML)

Pearl PM1077: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

* c-KIT (CD117)

* PDGF receptor A

* CD34

* SDH

Clinical Features:

* Peaks at 60 years of age.

* M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding

* Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding

* Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

* IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen

* IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT

* IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34

* Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:



* Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.

* Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).

* Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text:
119. Which among the following is not a subcutaneous fungal infection?

* Chromoblastomycosis

* Histoplasmosis

* Pityriasis versicolor

* Sporotrichosis
questions.solution:
Histoplasmosis and pityriasis versicolor are not subcutaneous fungal infections.

The infection caused by fungi can be broadly classified as follows:



Histoplasmosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by the dimorphic fungi Histoplasma capsulatum. It is acquired by inhalation and causes disease similar to tuberculosis and may present as fever, chills, headache, dry cough, dyspnea and chest pain.

Pityriasis versicolor is a superficial fungal infection localised to the stratum corneum and is caused by Malassezia furfur. Lesions are characterised by discrete or confluent, discoloured or depigmented macules occurring on the chest, abdomen, upper limbs and back.

Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection involving subcutaneous tissue, causing warty nodules that resemble cauliflower around the site of inoculation. It is characterised by the presence of sclerotic bodies, which are round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae.

Sporotrichosis is an infection involving cutaneous, subcutaneous and lymphatic tissue caused by the dimorphic fungi Sporothrix schenckii. It presents as nodules that are first formed at the site of inoculation, followed by ulceration and necrosis of the nodules. The infection can spread via the lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes, resulting in cord-like hardened lymphatics and secondary ulcers on the lymph nodes.

questions.text: 120. A 45-year-old female complains of difficulty in swallowing and a neck mass that moves with swallowing but not with tongue protrusion. On examination, cervical lymph nodes are enlarged. A fine needle aspiration of the specimen shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light. Which of the following precursor proteins is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma with amyloid deposition, in which calcitonin is the precursor protein associated. 

Amyloidosis occurs when abnormal fibrils, which are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins, are deposited extracellularly. Congo red staining shows apple-green birefringence under polarised light, and pink or red color in ordinary light. 

Note: Microscopic amyloid deposits are found in endocrine tumors, such as medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, islet cell tumors, pheochromocytoma, and islets of Langerhans. 

Other options:

Option A. Amyloid light chains are seen in primary amyloidosis and are of the AL type. Its occurrence is commonly seen in conditions like multiple myeloma. 

Option C. 𝛃2 microglobulin is a precursor protein leading to A��2m deposition in chronic renal failure and hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis.  

Option D. Transthyretin is a precursor protein, from which the ATTR major fibril protein is derived, which is deposited in familial amyloidosis and systemic senile amyloidosis(senile cardiac amyloidosis).

questions.text: 121. A patient was decided to be started on an anti-CD25 antibody for immunosuppressive therapy. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate?
questions.solution:
Basiliximab would be appropriate for the patient.

Basiliximab is a murine-human chimeric mAb that binds to CD25, the IL-2 receptor α chain, on activated lymphocytes. Another drug acting on the IL-2 receptor α chain is Daclizumab. They are IL-2 antagonists, block IL-2 from binding to activated lymphocytes, and are therefore immunosuppressive. They are indicated for the prophylaxis of acute organ rejection in renal transplant patients, along with corticosteroids and cyclosporine.

Other options:

Option A: Eculizumab binds to the C5 complement component and is approved for patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

Options B and C: Reslizumab and Mepolizumab bind to IL-5 and selectively inhibit eosinophilic inflammation in patients with severe eosinophilic asthma.

questions.text: 122. A 26-year old woman with complaints of heartburn and dyspepsia was diagnosed with H.pylori gastritis after a positive urea breath test and started on the first-line regimen for H.pylori. It has now been 4 weeks since the completion of the regimen. Which of the following is not a reliable test in evaluating the treatment success in this patient?
questions.solution:
H. pylori-specific antibody testing (serology) is not a reliable method to assess treatment success 4 weeks after therapy. This is because antibody titers decline very slowly and may remain elevated for months, making it difficult to determine whether the infection has resolved.

In contrast, the urea breath test, stool antigen test, and biopsy-based tests are all appropriate tools to evaluate eradication. Among these, the urea breath test and stool antigen test are non-invasive and are commonly used in follow-up.

The first-line treatment for H. pylori typically consists of triple therapy with a proton pump inhibitor (e.g., Omeprazole), Clarithromycin, and Metronidazole.

It is recommended to perform follow-up testing at least 4 weeks after completion of treatment, as testing earlier can result in false negatives due to suppressed bacterial load. Additionally, testing should be delayed by at least 2 weeks after stopping PPIs or 4 weeks after antibiotics or bismuth-containing compounds, as these can also affect accuracy.

While non-invasive tests are preferred in most cases, endoscopy with biopsy may be necessary in patients with a history of gastric ulcer to evaluate healing and rule out progression to gastric carcinoma.

questions.text: 123. An intern posted in a pathology laboratory observed a spleen specimen as shown below. Clinical history indicates that the patient is on treatment for HIV, presented with left upper abdominal pain, enlargement of the spleen, and pharyngeal lymphoid tissue. Immunophenotyping reveal CD20+, CD10+, and BCL-6 over-expression. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of an HIV-infected person having enlargement of pharyngeal lymphoid tissues with positive markers of CD10, CD20, with BCL-6 overexpression, and an image showing an isolated large mass in the spleen, suggests a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma(DLBCL).

DLBCL is the most common form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and can present in advanced HIV infections. It typically presents as a large enlarging mass in pharyngeal lymphoid tissues and can also have primary and secondary involvement of the spleen and liver. Immunophenotyping shows overexpression of BCL-6, and B-cell tumors express CD19 and CD20, and CD10 B-cell markers. 

Primary splenic diffuse large B-cell lymphoma can present with abdominal pain and a rapidly enlarging mass with splenomegaly. 

Combination chemotherapy of Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine, and Prednisone(R-CHOP) is the standard first-line chemotherapy for the disease. 

Other options:

Option A. Opportunistic HIV neoplasm involves the brain as the primary lymphoma site, not the pharyngeal lymphoid organs and spleen.

Option B. Follicular lymphoma presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and is associated with overexpression of BCL2. 

Option D. Lardaceous spleen is a fusion of the early deposits of amyloid in the wall of splenic sinuses in the red pulp.

questions.text: 125. A patient presented with complaints of breathlessness that worsen with exertion and fatiguability for a few months. Based on further workup, a diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis was made. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen in him due to this condition?

choices.text: Rise in his JVP during inspiration
Sharp fall in his JVP during inspiration
Sharp rise followed by a sustained deep fall in JVP during expiration
Sharp fall followed by a rise in JVP during expiration

questions.solution:
In a patient with constrictive pericarditis, the clinical sign that is likely to be seen in JVP is Kussmaul’s sign.

It is defined by either a rise or a lack of fall of the JVP with inspiration. Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration.

Kussmaul's sign is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis, although it has been reported in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy, massive pulmonary embolism, right ventricular infarction, and advanced left ventricular (LV) systolic heart failure. The pathophysiological mechanisms responsible for Kussmaul’s sign can be explained by conditions that cause right ventricular dysfunction, impair right ventricular filling, and raise atrial pressure.

The heart's ability to fill effectively can be compromised by:

* reduced myocardial elasticity due to conditions like infection or fibrosis, as seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy

* external mechanical constraint from pericardial diseases, such as constrictive pericarditis

* impaired right ventricular function following a right-sided myocardial infarction.

These factors hinder proper right ventricular filling and lead to a paradoxical rise in jugular venous pressure during inspiration.

questions.text:
126. Which of the following findings are seen in pigmentary glaucoma?

1. Sampaolesi line 2. Krukenberg’s spindle 3. Aqueous flares 4. Hudson–Stahli line 5. Iris transillumination defects
questions.solution:
Sampaolesi line (statement 1), Krukenberg spindle (statement 2) and Iris transillumination defects (statement 5) are seen in pigmentary glaucoma.

Pigmentary glaucoma is a type of secondary glaucoma more common in young myopic males and they usually have hyperpigmented trabecular meshwork and an open-angle on gonioscopy. It occurs due to the blockage of the trabecular meshwork by the pigment particles that are released from rubbing the iris pigment epithelium.

Patients are usually asymptomatic or may present with intermittent haloes. It has the following features:

* The pigment particles are deposited on the corneal endothelium in a vertical spindle shape called Krukenberg’s spindle (Statement 2) as seen in slit lamp examination. The image is given below:



* Radial transillumination defect (Statement 5) on the illumination of the iris is a pathognomonic feature. The image is given below:



* Gonioscopy shows pigment accumulation along the Schwalbe line inferiorly called the Sampaolesi line (Statement 1).

* Pigment granules may be deposited on the anterior surface of the lens. There may be a Scheie line or Zentmayer ring of pigment on the peripheral/equatorial surface around the zonular insertions.

Some patients may exhibit higher levels of IOP (Intraocular pressure) than in POAG. Over time the control of IOP may become easier as pigment liberation decreases and occasionally the IOP may revert to normal.

Other options: 

Statement 3: Aqueous flares occur due to the breakdown in the blood-aqueous barrier, and protein exudates escape into the anterior chamber. It seen in anterior uveitis. The image below shows the presence of cells and aqueous flare in a case of anterior uveitis.



Statement 4: The Hudson-Stahli line represents age-related linear iron deposition in the corneal epithelium, which is commonly seen in the junction between the middle and lower third cornea.

questions.text:
127. Which of the following landmarks is important for the identification of sphenopalatine foramen while performing TESPAL?

TESPAL - Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation
questions.solution:
Crista ethmoidalis is the important landmark for the identification of the sphenopalatine foramen while performing transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL).

The crista ethmoidalis is a small crest of the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone that is present anterior to the sphenopalatine foramen (The crista has variability in size but is consistent in its position) and provides a consistent and reliable landmark to identify the sphenopalatine artery during endoscopic dissection. There are often two or more branches of the sphenopalatine artery that are medial to the crista ethmoidalis.

Sphenopalatine foramen transmits sphenopalatine artery, vein and the nasal palatine nerve (maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve). Clinically, the said foramen is the key to the procedure of Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL).



Other options : 

Option A: The pterygopalatine fossa is in the shape of an inverted pyramid located between the maxillary bone anteriorly, the pterygoid process posteriorly, and the orbital apex superiorly (image below). 

The major bleeding vessel in epistaxis is the sphenopalatine artery, and its source is the maxillary artery. From the infratemporal fossa, the maxillary artery enters the pterygopalatine fossa. After giving various branches here, the maxillary artery then runs through the sphenopalatine foramen to finally enter the nose. While the pterygopalatine fossa is anatomically related, it is not a useful endoscopic landmark during surgery.



Option B: Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest air cell in the ethmoidal air sinus, and is not closely related to the sphenopalatine foramen location. It is situated behind the uncinate process and forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris through which the maxillary, frontal, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses drain (image below). It's a part of the ostiomeatal complex (OMC).



Option D: Bleeding from a source anterior to the plane of the piriform aperture is anterior epistaxis. Bleeding from a vessel placed posterior to the piriform aperture is posterior epistaxis. However, it is irrelevant to locating the sphenopalatine artery.

questions.text: 128. Hidden hunger refers to:

choices.text: Food shortage cause of by famines

questions.solution:
Hidden hunger refers to micronutrient deficiencies

Hidden hunger occurs when intake or absorption of vitamins and minerals is too low to sustain good health and development in children and normal physical and mental function in adults. It occurs due to poor diet, disease, or increased micronutrient needs that are not met during pregnancy and lactation.

questions.text: 129. A 27-year-old primigravida undergoes an elective cesarean section at 39 weeks of gestation for breech presentation. The surgery is uncomplicated, and a healthy female infant is delivered. Anticipating the risk of atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), the obstetrician administers carbetocin immediately after placental delivery for uterotonic prophylaxis. Which of the following statements regarding carbetocin is most accurate?

choices.text: It provides sustained uterine contraction with a single dose
It must be administered as infusion due to its short half-life
It must be stored in a refrigerated environment as it is unstable at room temperature
It is a safe alternative for women with known hypersensitivity to oxytocin

questions.solution:
Carbetocin mimics oxytocin and provides sustained uterine contraction with a single dose.

Carbetocin is a long-acting oxytocin analogue, effective in preventing atonic PPH, particularly after cesarean delivery. A single dose (IV or IM) provides sustained uterine tone due to its longer half-life (~40 minutes).

Other options: 

Option B: Continuous infusion is required for oxytocin, not for carbetocin.

Option C: Carbetocin is stable at room temperature.

Option D: Carbetocin, being an oxytocin analogue, is contraindicated in patients with oxytocin hypersensitivity.

questions.text: 130. A 68-year-old patient presents with right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain for 3 days, accompanied by 2–3 episodes of vomiting. On examination, there is RUQ tenderness and a positive Murphy’s sign. Laboratory investigations reveal total leukocyte count (TLC) of 25,000/mm³. According to the Tokyo Guidelines for the severity grading of acute cholecystitis, what is the most likely grade of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Grade 2 Acute Cholecystitis.

According to the Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for the severity grading of acute cholecystitis:

Grade I: It is defined as acute cholecystitis in a healthy person with no organ dysfunction and mild inflammatory changes in the gallbladder, making cholecystectomy a safe and low-risk operative procedure 

Grade II: Associated with any one of the following conditions:

*

* Elevated white cell count (>18000/mm3)

* Palpable tender mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant 

* Duration of complaint >72 hours

* Marked local inflammation (gangrenous cholecystitis, pericholecystic abscess, hepatic abscess, biliary peritonitis, emphysematous cholecystitis)

Grade III: Associated with dysfunction of any one of the following organs/systems:

*

* Cardiovascular dysfunction: Hypotension requiring treatment with dopamine ≥5 μg/kg/min, or any dose of epinephrine 

* Neurological dysfunction: Decreased level of consciousness 

* Respiratory dysfunction: PaO2/FiO2 ratio <300

* Renal dysfunction: Oliguria, creatinine >2.0 mg/dL

* Hepatic dysfunction: Prothrombin time (PT-INR) >1.5

* Haematological dysfunction Platelet count <100000/mm3

Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune condition where there is T-cell-mediated inflammation and destruction of islet cells by cytotoxic T lymphocytes. questions.text: 132. Fructose is transported in the spermatozoa through which of the following transporters?
questions.solution:
Fructose is transported in the spermatozoa through GLUT 5 transporters.

The body needs to regulate glucose levels. This is done with the help of the glucose transporters (GLUT). GLUT 5 is present in the sperm and the small intestine. It is the only transporter that transports fructose. The liver and the pancreatic islet cells use the GLUT 2 transporter for rapid uptake of glucose. Other organs like the brain, kidney, placenta, and intestine have specific GLUT transporters.  

Other Options: 

Option A: GLUT 1 is present in the brain, kidney, colon, placenta, and erythrocytes. It is responsible for glucose uptake. 

Option B: GLUT 3 is present in the brain, placenta, and kidneys. It is responsible for glucose uptake. 

Option C: GLUT 4 is present in the heart, skeletal muscle, and adipose tissue. It is involved in insulin-dependent glucose uptake.

questions.text: 133. A 52-year-old man complains of shortness of breath and tachypnea on post-op day 2 following emergency surgery for a ruptured appendix. He maintains an oxygen saturation of 88% on 10 liters of oxygen by a face mask. His chest radiograph is given below. Which of the following interventions has shown mortality benefit in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the chest radiograph point to a diagnosis of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Low tidal volume ventilation has shown mortality benefits in the treatment of this condition.

ARDS refers to an acute onset and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema that occurs due to endothelial injury in the pulmonary capillaries due to inflammation. The diagnostic criteria for ARDS include:

* PaO2/FiO2 ratio < 300 mmHg

* Acute onset (within 1 week of a clinical insult)

* Chest radiograph shows diffuse bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema

* Absence of any left atrial hypertension (ie, pulmonary edema is not due to a cardiac cause)

Conditions associated with direct lung injury like pneumonia, aspiration of gastric contents, pulmonary contusion, near-drowning and toxic inhalational injury are associated with ARDS. Systemic conditions causing indirect lung injury and ARDS include sepsis, severe trauma (head injury, burns, multiple bone fractures), multiple blood transfusions, and pancreatitis.

The chest radiograph of a patient with ARDS will show diffuse bilateral alveolar infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema that can be difficult to distinguish from left ventricular failure. 

The main treatment strategy that has been shown to reduce mortality in patients is low tidal volume ventilation (6 mL/kg of predicted body weight). Conventional tidal volume ventilation leads to overdistension injury because the lung in ARDS is already consolidated and any attempt to push more air through it will lead to barotrauma. Apart from this, high PEEP, prone position, selective use of neuromuscular blockade, and use of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)  may also be useful. Management strategies that have not been shown to improve the outcome in ARDS patients include glucocorticoids, surfactant replacement, anti-inflammatory therapies and inhaled vasodilators.

* V D /V T >0.6

* Clinical indices

* Respiratory rate >35 breaths/min

* Mechanical indices

* Tidal volume <5 mL/kg

* Vital capacity <15 mL/kg

questions.text: 134. Which of the following does not fit the definition of pyrexia of unknown origin?

choices.text: Fever > 38.3°C on at least two occasions
Uncertain diagnosis after obligatory examination and investigations

questions.solution:
Pyrexia or Fever of Unknown Origin (PUO/FUO) is defined as:

* Fever > 38.3°C on at least two occasions

* Duration of illness > 3 weeks

* No known immunocompromised state

* Uncertain diagnosis even after thorough history taking, clinical examination and obligatory investigations.

PUO is more often due to an atypical presentation of a common disease rather than a rare disease. Infection with M. tuberculosis remains the most common cause of PUO outside of western countries, while atypical manifestations of endocarditis, diverticulitis, vertebral osteomyelitis are the other common causes.

questions.text: 135. A neonate weighing 2.5 kg is found to have moderate hypothermia. The production of heat in this neonate can be seen with all of the following mechanisms, except:
questions.solution:
Neonates do not generate heat by shivering.

When a neonate is exposed to a cold environment, the neonate tries to generate heat by increasing physical activity, such as crying or increased body movements. Brown fat is located in the axillae, groin, and nape of the neck, interscapular, and perirenal areas and has a rich vascular supply as well as sympathetic innervation. Preterm and small for gestational age infants have fewer brown fat stores.

A cold environment stimulates the baby’s sympathetic system, leading to cutaneous vasoconstriction and generation of heat by non-shivering thermogenesis in the brown fat. The release of norepinephrine uncouples beta-oxidation in fat, which results in heat production. Blood passing through brown fat gets heated up and eventually keeps the neonate warm.

questions.text: 136. A 40-year-old male patient is scheduled for open abdominal surgery. He was admitted the day before, and all routine preoperative investigations are within normal limits. The surgeon instructs the intern to prepare the patient for surgery. When and how should hair removal be performed in this patient?

choices.text: The night before surgery using skin clippers with disposable blades
On the operating table using skin clippers with disposable blades
On the operating table using disposable razor blades
The night before surgery using disposable razor blades

questions.solution:
Hair removal should be done on the operating table, using skin clippers with disposable blades.

It is recommended to remove the hair on the OT table after a dose of prophylactic antibiotic. Removal of hair causes microabrasions and can potentially cause surgical site infection. Skin clippers with disposable blades are relatively safer with a lower incidence of surgical site infections. Removal of hair preoperatively outside the confines of the operating room is discouraged.

Hair is removed from the surgical site when it is assumed to interfere with the operation, and it also makes postoperative plastering or dressing relatively pain-free. Shaving using a razor blade can lead to unintended microincisions and often result in exaggerated skin infection and inflammation.

questions.text: 137. A 24-year-old woman presented with pain, deformity, and swelling affecting the femur. On examination, she has areas of cafe-au-lait pigmentation on her left shoulder and right forearm. The patient is known to be hyperthyroid and is under treatment for the same. Radiographs reveal multiple lesions involving the bilateral femur with the characteristic Rind sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are most likely suggestive of fibrous dysplasia.

Fibrous dysplasia is a sporadic bone disorder characterized by the presence of either monostotic (single bone) or polyostotic (multiple bones) expanding lesions composed of bone-forming mesenchymal tissue. A classic imaging feature is the "rind sign," where the lesion is encased by a thick, sclerotic layer of reactive bone. This sign is most commonly observed in the proximal femur and is considered highly suggestive of fibrous dysplasia.

Fibrous dysplasia is caused by a somatic activating mutation in the GNAS1 gene. This mutation leads to abnormal bone development and can also result in café-au-lait skin pigmentation due to increased signaling through the melanocyte-stimulating hormone receptor, as well as various endocrine abnormalities.

McCune-Albright syndrome (MAS) is a clinical triad comprising polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, café-au-lait spots, and autonomous endocrine hyperfunction. The most common endocrine manifestation is isosexual precocious puberty in girls. Other possible endocrinopathies include thyrotoxicosis, Cushing’s syndrome, acromegaly, hyperparathyroidism, hyperprolactinemia, and precocious puberty in boys.

Other options:

Option A, B: Osteomyelitis is unlikely in the absence of a previous history of infection and does not present with this symptom complex.

Option C: Osteopetrosis is a systemic rather than local disorder characterized by high bone mass.

questions.text: 139. An anatomy resident, while examining a histological section of a lymphoid organ under high magnification, observes a distinctive structure in the medullary region. The image is shown below. These structures are derived from which pharyngeal pouch?
questions.solution:
The magnified view of the histology slide shows the Hassall’s corpuscles (thymic corpuscles) which are seen in the medullary area of the thymus. They are derived from the 3rd pharyngeal pouch.

Hassall’s corpuscles are pink-stained, small rounded structures with concentrically arranged epitheliocytes intermingled with keratohyalin and lipid droplets. The central core is formed by degenerating epitheliocytes and macrophages. 

The 3rd pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the thymus in the ventral part and the inferior parathyroid gland in the dorsal part. The thymus then moves away from the pharyngeal wall in a caudal and medial direction, pulling the inferior parathyroid with it. It reaches the anterior part of the thorax, where it fuses with its counterpart from the opposite side.

The endodermal cells of the thymus get invaded by the vascular mesoderm, which contains numerous lymphoblasts. Hassall’s corpuscles (thymic corpuscles) are derived from the endoderm of the 3rd pouch.

Other options:

Option A: The first pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the middle ear cavity and eustachian tube.

Option B: The second pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the palatine tonsils and tonsillar fossa.

Option D: The fourth pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the superior parathyroid gland, ultimobranchial body, which then develops into the parafollicular "C" cells of the thyroid gland.

questions.text: 140. A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient with multi-drug resistant HIV-1 infection is initiated on enfuvirtide as part of a antiretroviral regimen. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of enfuvirtide?

choices.text: Inhibits fusion of the viral envelope with the host cell membrane
Blocks the CCR5 co-receptor to prevent viral entry
Binds to HIV-1 gp120 and prevents attachment to the CD4 receptor
Binds to CD4 receptor and prevents post-attachment conformational changes

questions.solution:
Enfuvirtide inhibits fusion of the viral envelope with the host cell membrane.

The amino acid sequence of enfuvirtide derives from the transmembrane gp41 region of HIV-1 that is involved in fusion of the viral membrane lipid bilayer with that of the host cell membrane. The peptide blocks the interaction between the N36 and C34 sequences of the gp41 glycoprotein by binding to a hydrophobic groove in the N36 coil. This prevents formation of a six-helix bundle critical for membrane fusion and viral entry into the host cell.

Enfuvirtide inhibits infection of CD4+ cells by free virus particles. Enfuvirtide retains activity against viruses that have become resistant to antiretroviral agents of other classes. HIV can develop resistance to this drug through specific mutations in the enfuvirtide-binding domain of gp41.

Other options:

Option B: Maraviroc blocks the CCR5 co-receptor to prevent viral entry.

Option C: Fostemsavir binds to HIV-1 gp120 and prevents attachment to the CD4 receptor.

Option D: Ibalizumab binds to CD4 receptor and prevents post-attachment conformational changes.

questions.text:
141. A 54-year-old woman presents with painful swelling in the neck, a few days after experiencing fever, malaise, and generalized body aches. She also reports tremors, palpitations, and heat intolerance for the past 2 weeks. She has no significant past medical history. On examination, both thyroid lobes are enlarged and extremely tender. Radioiodine uptake at 24 hours is 1%. Laboratory and biopsy findings are given below. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?

TSH: 0.05 mIU/L Free T4: 2.8 ng/dL  ESR: Elevated Leukocyte count: Normal

choices.text: Hurthle cells are seen in this case

questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms and lab results, suggestive of thyrotoxicosis, along with the biopsy findings showing the thyroid parenchyma containing a chronic inflammatory infiltrate with multinucleate giant cells and colloid follicles, are characteristic of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis. This condition is transient and resolves in 2 to 6 weeks, even if the patient is not treated.

This condition is also known as painful subacute thyroiditis, de Quervain thyroiditis, and migratory thyroiditis (this is because the pain can shift to different locations in the thyroid). It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections. Many viruses, such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses, have been clinically implicated in this condition. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years, and women are generally affected three times more often than men.

The histopathology image depends on the stage of the disease. The earlier picture shows the presence of granulomas in the thyroid gland. Aggregates of lymphocytes, activated macrophages, and plasma cells, and damaged thyroid follicles can be seen. Multinucleate giant cells encircle pools of colloid, hence the name granulomatous thyroiditis. Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever.

It has three distinct phases:

* Thyrotoxic phase

* Hypothyroid phase

* Recovery phase

There may be raised inflammatory markers, absent thyroid antibodies, serum T4 may be high, normal or slightly raised, and I123 uptake of the gland is low. The thyroid hormone levels are increased from the release of the preformed hormone from the damaged thyroid cells, and not from excessive production, and therefore, antithyroid medications are not effective. The low iodine uptake and the tenderness of the thyroid confirm the diagnosis of subacute (painful) thyroiditis.

It is treated with large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids, and/or beta-blockers to relieve the observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid phase is prolonged, levothyroxine can be used.

Other options: 

Options A, B and D: Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that presents as painless enlargement of the thyroid associated with some degree of hypothyroidism in middle-aged women. Hurthle cells are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis.

The slide shows the picture of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with

* Follicular destruction

* Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue

* Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration

* A well-developed germinal centre may be seen

* Atrophied thyroid follicles, lined by epithelial cells, which contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. These epithelial cells are referred to as Hurthle cells.



The histopathological slide given below shows a Psammoma body. They are a product of dystrophic (not metastatic) calcification.

Psammoma bodies are seen in:

* Papillary thyroid carcinoma

* Papillary renal cell carcinoma

* Ovarian papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma

* Meningiomas

questions.text: 142. You notice the presence of both acidophilic and basophilic cells in the report of Papanicolaou Test, done on a 21-year-old woman during her hormonal cytological evaluation. Which of the following vaginal epithelial cells appear as acidophilic in the given test?
questions.solution:
Superficial cells are acidophilic in the given test.

Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. The presence of malignant cells on a Pap smear requires further evaluation with colposcopy, cervical biopsy, fractional curettage, etc.

The prerequisites are:

* It should be done before vaginal examination.

* Lubricants should not be used.

* The patient should not be menstruating during the Pap test.

* The ideal time is around ovulation.

* The patient should not have intercourse 24 hours before the test.

Procedure:

* The patient is put in a dorsal position, and the labia are parted.

* Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced.

* The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayer’s spatula.

* The scrapings are evenly spread onto a glass slide and immediately fixed.

* After fixing it for 30 min, the slide is air-dried and stained with Pap or short stain.

* Endocervix is also scraped with a brush and added to the slide to improve the predictive value.

questions.text: 143. A 43-year-old male patient is being evaluated for sweating, palpitations, and pallor that occur a few times a day. He was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and planned for surgery. Choose the incorrect statement regarding anesthesia for this patient.

choices.text: Ketamine may exacerbate the effects of his condition
Halothane can be used safely in this patient
Vecuronium is safe to use in this patient

questions.solution:
Halothane should not be used in pheochromocytoma as it sensitizes the heart to the arrhythmogenic effects of epinephrine.

Pheochromocytoma is a condition where the chromaffin tissue, most commonly in the adrenal medulla, produces excessive norepinephrine and epinephrine. 

Other anaesthetic drugs to be avoided in a pheochromocytoma patient are:

* Succinylcholine -can cause fasciculations, which lead to raised intraabdominal pressure and catecholamine release from the tumor

* Ketamine - as it is sympathomimetic and might exacerbate the effects of adrenergic agonists

* Anticholinergics and Pancuronium – vagal blockade leading to tachycardia

* Atracurium – due to histamine release, which may provoke catecholamine release.

The safest options for these patients would be vecuronium and rocuronium.

Other considerations in patients with pheochromocytoma:

* Phenoxybenzamine, an alpha1-antagonist, which can be administered orally, is often given preoperatively to reverse the vasoconstriction. This results in a drop in arterial blood pressure and a drop in hematocrit

* Phentolamine is used intraoperatively to control hypertensive episodes

* A major regional block, such as spinal/epidural, could block sensory and sympathetic discharge in the area of the surgical field. But catecholamines released from the pheochromocytoma could still bind to receptors all over the body.

questions.text:
144. Arrange the following steps of the synthesis of thyroid hormones in order.

* Oxidation

* Coupling reaction

* Transport via sodium-iodide symporter

* Organification/Iodination

* Transport via pendrin
questions.solution:
The formation of thyroid hormones starts with the trapping of iodine via sodium-iodide symporter and its transport into the follicle via pendrin. This is followed by oxidation, organification, and coupling reaction.

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

* Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (Option 3) actively takes up I- (iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. The process of concentrating iodide in the cell is known as iodide trapping. Iodide is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter (Option 5).

* Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by the thyrocytes and secreted into colloids.

* Iodination of thyroglobulin: This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 

* Oxidation (Option 1): TPO oxidizes iodine in the presence of H2O2 

* Organification (Option 4): TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)

* Coupling reactions (Option 2): TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)

* Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months

* Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes in the colloid from the thyroid cells. This releases thyroxine and triiodothyronine into the peripheral blood. 

* Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone.

questions.text: 145. A 28-year-old woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation for an antenatal checkup. Ultrasound reveals an empty uterus and a gestational sac surrounded by myometrium, located outside the endometrial cavity and not communicating with it. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of cornual pregnancy. 

A cornual pregnancy occurs in the rudimentary horn of a malformed uterus, such as a unicornuate uterus with a non-communicating horn. It is outside the endometrial cavity and has no connection to it, which helps differentiate it from angular and interstitial pregnancies.

Key features suggesting cornual pregnancy:

* The gestational sac is separate from the main uterine cavity

* Surrounded by thick myometrium

* No communication with the endometrial canal

* Often diagnosed late, with a high risk of rupture and hemorrhagic shock

Other options:

Option A: Interstitial pregnancy occurs within the myometrial portion of the fallopian tube and typically communicates with the endometrial cavity.

Option C: Abdominal ectopic implantations occur on peritoneal surfaces and are not surrounded by myometrium.

Option D: Angular pregnancy occurs within the uterine cavity, at the lateral angle, and communicates with the endometrial canal.

questions.text:
146. Which of the following are part of the CASPAR criteria?

* History of psoriatic skin lesions

* Presence of typical psoriatic nail dystrophy

* Positive test result for rheumatoid factor

* High ESR and CRP

* Juxta-articular new bone formation on X-ray of foot
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2 and 5 are part of the CASPAR criteria.

Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative inflammatory arthritis that is destructive to the joints, associated with moderate to severe psoriasis. A negative test for the rheumatoid factor is included in the CASPAR (Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis) criteria used for diagnosing psoriatic arthritis, not a positive test. 

A diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis can be made from the Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria, if there is an inflammatory articular disease of a joint, enthesis or spine, along with >=3 of the following criteria:

* Evidence of current or history of psoriasis/ family history of psoriasis

* Typical psoriatic nail involvement on current physical examination

* Rheumatoid factor negative

* Current or history of dactylitis recorded by a rheumatologist

* Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation in the hand or foot

questions.text: 148. All the following syndromes are associated with pheochromocytoma except:
questions.solution:
Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is not associated with pheochromocytoma. 

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is characterised by hypoglycemia, macroglossia, ear pits, omphalocele or umbilical hernia, lateralized overgrowth, organomegaly, and high risk of embryonal tumours until age seven. It is caused by genetic and epigenetic abnormalities in the 11p15 region. It is Wilms tumour, hepatoblastoma, neuroblastoma and rhabdomyosarcoma.

Pheochromocytomas are neoplasms composed of chromaffin cells, which synthesise and release catecholamines and peptide hormones in some cases.

questions.text: 149. A middle-aged patient presents with right upper quadrant pain radiating to the back for 1 day. His abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a middle-aged patient with right upper quadrant pain, radiating to the back for 1 day and x-ray showing air in the lumen and wall of the enlarged gallbladder suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Emphysematous cholecystitis.

Acute cholecystitis can lead to emphysematous cholecystitis when complicated by infection with gas-forming organisms. Emphysematous cholecystitis commonly occurs in diabetics and patients with calculi. CT shows intramural and/or intraluminal gas, while on MRI, the gas appears as a signal void. Emergency cholecystectomy is required in such patients.

Other options: 

Option A: Nephrolithiasis causes flank pain that radiates to the groin, not typically RUQ. The given abdominal X-ray shows left staghorn renal calculi.



Option C: In acute pancreatitis, pain is usually epigastric, not isolated to RUQ. The given erect X-ray abdomen shows the colon cut-off sign, suggestive of acute pancreatitis.



Option D: Hollow viscous perforation causes sudden, diffuse abdominal pain with signs of peritonitis. The below radiograph shows a hollow viscus perforation.

questions.text: 150. There are many recently discovered methods of post-translational modification of histone proteins, which alter the rate of DNA transcription. Which of the following novel methods decreases the rate of transcription?
questions.solution:
O-Palmitoylation decreases the rate of transcription, whereas Glutarylation, Lactylation, and Serotonylation are the novel PTMs that increase the rate of transcription.  

Histone covalent modification, also dubbed the histone code, is an important determinant of gene activity. Histones are subjected to a wide range of specific posttranslational modifications. These modifications are dynamic and reversible. Histone acetylation and deacetylation are best understood.

Acetylation typically occurs on lysine residues located in the amino-terminal tails of histone proteins and is consistently associated with active transcription or the potential for gene activation. This modification reduces the positive charge on the histone tails, thereby weakening their interaction with the negatively charged DNA. As a result, the chromatin structure becomes more relaxed, allowing greater access to the underlying DNA.

These covalent modifications of histones also serve as docking sites for other regulatory proteins, including ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling complexes. These complexes often contain specific structural domains that recognize and bind to histones modified by coregulatory enzymes. Once recruited, these complexes can reposition, remove, or alter nucleosomes, further increasing access to nearby DNA regions.

Chromatin modifiers (which add or remove chemical groups) and chromatin remodelers (which shift or restructure histones) cooperate to "open" gene promoters and regulatory elements. This enables the binding of key transcriptional components, such as transcriptional activators, RNA polymerase II, and general transcription factors (GTFs), facilitating gene expression.

Conversely, histone deacetylation carried out by transcriptional corepressors typically leads to chromatin compaction and reduced gene accessibility.

questions.text: 151. While karyotyping a sample of cells to look for the presence of the BCR-ABL fusion gene, the dividing cells are arrested in which phase of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
For karyotyping, dividing cells are arrested in the metaphase in the M-phase of the cell cycle.

Chromosomes isolated from cells during the metaphase stage of mitosis are chosen for karyotyping because, it is during metaphase that the chromosomes assume their characteristic condensed, discrete shape.

The cell cycle refers to the events surrounding eukaryotic DNA replication and cell division (mitosis). The period preceding DNA replication is called the Gap 1 phase (G1). DNA replication occurs during the synthesis (S) phase. Following DNA synthesis, there is the Gap 2 phase (G2) before mitosis occurs (M). Cells that have stopped dividing, for example, T lymphocytes, have gone out of the cell cycle into the G0 phase.

There are five stages in mitosis namely prophase, prometaphase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase. These occur in strictly sequential order. In metaphase, the individual chromosomes take the form of two chromatids connected at the centromere. Hence, in metaphase chromosomes can be visualized clearly during karyotyping.

The image given below shows different phases of the cell cycle:



Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. It is used in prenatal diagnosis, investigation of repeat pregnancy loss, investigation of children and adults suspected of having a chromosomal disorder, and subtyping of lymphomas and leukaemias for exact diagnosis, giving a prognosis, and treatment.

questions.text: 152. The following instrument is used in which of the following surgery?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a Blakesley straight forceps. It is used in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) operations.



Endoscopic surgery is minimally invasive and does not require skin incisions or removal of bone to access the disease. In sinus surgery, this allows ventilation and drainage of the sinuses, preserving nasal and sinus mucosa, and preserving mucociliary clearance. 

Indications of FESS:

* Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.

* Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.

* Polypoid rhinosinusitis (diffuse nasal polyposis).

* Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball or nasal polyp.

* Antrochoanal polyp.

* Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.

* Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.

* Removal of a foreign body from the nose or sinus.

questions.text: 153. Which of the following drugs is preferred for morning sickness along with pyridoxine?
questions.solution:
Doxylamine with pyridoxine is preferred in morning sickness. 

Doxylamine is a sedative H1 antihistamine with prominent anticholinergic activity. Its efficacy is improved when combined with pyridoxine (vitamin B6).

A bedtime administration of doxylamine 20 mg and pyridoxine 20 mg is given for nausea and vomiting of pregnancy. Major adverse effects are drowsiness, dry mouth, light-headedness, and constipation. 

Other options:

Option A- Promethazine is an H1 antihistaminic drug used for motion sickness. These drugs produce protection of 4- 6 hours but produce sedation and dryness of the mouth.

Option C- Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used for mountain sickness. It should be started 1-2 days before ascending to high altitude. Acetazolamide alters carbon dioxide transport in the lungs, tissues, and brain. It also decreases cerebrospinal fluid formation and lowers its pH.

Option D- Meclizine is a less sedative, less anticholinergic, and long-acting H1 antihistaminic drug. It is used for seasickness and protects for nearly a day.

questions.text: 154. False regarding reactive arthritis:

choices.text: It is most common among young men
It is linked with the HLA-B27 locus
X-ray evidence of sacroilitis is found in patients with long standing disease
Anti-inflammatory agents have no role in the treatment

questions.solution:
Anti-inflammatory agents have no role in the treatment is the incorrect statement. Anti-inflammatory agents help to relieve symptoms in reactive arthritis.

Reactive polyarthritis develops several weeks after nongonococcal urethritis and enteric infections. Classic reactive arthritis findings, including urethritis, conjunctivitis, uveitis, oral ulcers, and rash, are seen only in a minority of the patients.

Reactive arthritis is more commonly seen in young men. HLA-B27 is a potential genetic predisposing factor. Patients present with painful, asymmetric oligoarthritis that affects mainly the knees, ankles, and feet. Low back pain is commonly present, and radiographic evidence of sacroiliitis is found in patients with long-standing disease.

Most patients recover within 6 months, but prolonged recurrent disease is more common in cases that occur after chlamydial urethritis. Anti-inflammatory agents help to relieve symptoms. The role of prolonged antibiotic therapy in eliminating microbial antigens from the synovium is controversial.

questions.text: 155. Which of the following structures marked in the given image of the sole of the foot, is involved in the Windlass mechanism?
questions.solution:
Plantar aponeurosis (marked 'A') is involved in the Windlass mechanism.

Windlass mechanism:

Dorsiflexion of the great toe causes heightening of the medial longitudinal arch of the foot. This is called the Windlass mechanism.

The anterior pillar of the medial longitudinal arch is formed by the medial three metatarsals and the posterior pillar is formed by the posterior part of the inferior calcaneal surface. Plantar aponeurosis acts as a tie beam and connects these pillars. Whenever the great toe is stretched, the plantar aponeurosis is also stretched, drawing the anterior and posterior pillars together. This results in the heightening of the arch.

Below image shows Windlass mechanism





Medial longitudinal arch:

The arch between the heel proximally and the medial three metatarsophalangeal joints.

Bones involved: Calcaneus, talar head, navicular, the three cuneiforms and the medial three metatarsals.

Stability of arch:

* Plantar aponeurosis (most important)

* Spring ligament

* Talocalcaneal ligaments

* Deltoid ligament

* Muscles: Flexor hallucis longus, Flexor digitorum longus, abductor hallucis, flexor digitorum brevis, Tibialis posterior and anterior

* Bones

questions.text: 156. Which of the following manoeuvre’s used in breech delivery is correctly matched with the part of the baby delivered?

choices.text: Burns marshall -  chin to pubis delivery

questions.solution:
Lovset’s manoeuvre is correctly matched with delivery of extended arms in breech presentation.

Pearl PM1839: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

* Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa

* Catch hold of the ankle

* Pull down along with abduction



 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

* Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.

* Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.

* Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 



 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

* Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.

* Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.



 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

* Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.

* When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.

* Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.



 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

* Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.

* Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.

* Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.

* Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.

* Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.



 

Mnemonic:

* Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)

* Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)
