questions.text: 158. The neonatology intern on ward duty noticed that a newborn's mother was unimmunized during pregnancy. What is the dose of antitoxin to be administered to this newborn for the prevention of neonatal tetanus?
questions.solution:
750 IU of antitoxin is administered to this newborn for the prevention of neonatal tetanus.

The infants born to mothers who have not received the 2 doses of tetanus toxoid during pregnancy have a risk of developing neonatal tetanus. They can be protected from this by administering 750 IU of antitoxin within 6 hours of birth.

In unimmunized pregnant women, two doses of tetanus toxoid are administered. First dose as early as possible, and the second dose one month later. The second dose should be administered at least 3 weeks before delivery. In previously immunized pregnant women, a booster dose is sufficient. Tetanus toxoid protects both mother and child from tetanus. Tetanus is an acute disease caused by the exotoxin of Clostridium tetani. It is characterised by muscular rigidity and paroxysmal spasms of voluntary muscles.

questions.text: 159. A 30-year-old female presented with brownish vaginal discharge and hemoptysis. The resident took a biopsy of a vaginal mass, which shows syncytiotrophoblasts. Past medical records show a history of molar pregnancy. Which tumor marker investigation would you advise to favor the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of choriocarcinoma, for which 𝛃-HCG would favor the diagnosis. 

Choriocarcinoma is a malignant trophoblastic neoplasm arising in the body of the uterus. In females, this neoplasm follows a pregnancy, 50% of which are evacuation of a hydatidiform mole. It usually manifests as vaginal spotting of bloody or brownish fluid. Metastasis occurs early and is hematogenous, which easily spreads to the lower vagina and vulva. The most common sites of metastasis are the lungs, depicting a ‘cannonball’ appearance.

Histologically, it consists of proliferating syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts, and chorionic villi are absent. Serum 𝛃-HCG is a very specific marker, and chemotherapy can be administered based on this.

Other options:

Option A. CA-125 is a tumor marker for ovarian tumors. 

Option B. TP53 is a tumor marker elevated in various cancers, including colon, lung, pancreatic, and bladder cancer. 

Option C. AFP is a tumor marker elevated in neoplasms of the liver, yolk sac tumors, teratocarcinoma, and embryonal carcinomas.

questions.text: 160. A patient presents to the emergency department with an episode of acute anxiety. On examination, vitals are HR 120, BP 130/89, RR 24, SpO2 99. After some time, he develops tingling sensations and spasms in both his hands. What is the reason and the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The development of tingling sensations (paresthesias) and hand spasms indicates increased neuromuscular irritability, which is characteristic of hypocalcemia.  In this case, the hypocalcemia is caused by respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation and the management is paperbag rebreathing. 

Hyperventilation-induced respiratory alkalosis due to CO2 washout causes an increase in pH, i.e. blood becomes alkaline. Hence, Ca2+ ions replace the sites on albumin that were bound by H+, decreasing ionic Ca2+. The decreased transient ionic calcium due to increased binding of Ca2+ to albumin causes sensory and  motor symptoms. It could be prevented by a rebreathing bag, which prevents the excess washout of CO2, hence balances the pH from becoming alkaline. 

Patients with hypocalcemia may present with a range of symptoms depending on the severity and duration of calcium deficiency. While mild hypocalcemia may be asymptomatic, moderate to severe hypocalcemia is typically associated with neuromuscular irritability, leading to paresthesias in the fingers, toes, and around the mouth. Physical signs include a positive Chvostek’s sign—twitching of the facial muscles when the facial nerve is tapped and a positive Trousseau’s sign, demonstrated by carpal spasm upon inflating a blood pressure cuff above systolic pressure for several minutes. In severe cases, hypocalcemia may cause carpopedal spasms, seizures, bronchospasm, laryngospasm, and prolongation of the QT interval on ECG. These features are characteristic and clinically significant in the diagnosis and management of hypocalcemia.

questions.text: 162. The transvaginal sonogram of a 45-year-old woman with heavy menstrual bleeding revealed a globally enlarged uterus with striated projections from the endometrium into the myometrium. She has completed her family but does not want a hysterectomy, and requests medical management of her symptoms. Which among the following is unlikely to be effective in this case?
questions.solution:
A multiparous woman over the age of 40 presenting with heavy menstrual bleeding, along with the described sonographic findings, is suggestive of a diagnosis of adenomyosis. Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs), such as tamoxifen, are not used in the management of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis refers to the growth of the endometrium (both stromal and glandular components) directly into the myometrium. Patients generally present with heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia.

Risk Factors of adenomyosis include:

* Increasing age

* Multiparty

A definitive diagnosis is usually made by histopathological examination of the specimen after hysterectomy. Transvaginal sonography may show global uterine enlargement with ill-defined hypoechoic areas, heterogeneous echoes in the myometrium, and endometrial infiltration into the myometrium. MR imaging is superior to sonography and is considered when the diagnosis is inconclusive.

Medical management is aimed at reducing symptoms of pain and bleeding. It includes:

* Cyclic NSAIDs at the time of the menses

* Combined oral contraceptives and progestin-only regimens- bring about endometrial atrophy and reduce endometrial prostaglandin secretion

* Levonorgestrel intrauterine device- reduces bleeding

* GnRH agonists are used in cases of subfertility or for relief just before surgery. 

Hysterectomy is the definitive management. Endometrial ablation or resection using hysteroscopy is also effective.

questions.text: 163. An 8-year-old girl presents with vomiting and abdominal pain for 5 days. She has been having 4-5 episodes of non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. IgA-tissue transglutaminase titer is found to be elevated. Which of the following HLA alleles is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of celiac disease or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. It is associated with HLA-DQ8 alleles.

Celiac disease (CD) is a T-cell–mediated chronic inflammatory disorder. The strongest association is with HLA-DQ2.5 (one or two copies encoded by DQA1*05 [for the alpha] and DQB1*02 genes [for the beta chain]). Such a DQ molecule is present in most of the CD patients. The highly homologous DQ2.2 molecule confers a much lower risk, whereas the data available on DQ2-negative CD patients indicate that they almost invariably are HLA-DQ8 positive (DQA1*0301/ DQB1*0302).

It is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing foods such as barley, rye, oats, and wheat (mnemonic: BROW) in genetically predisposed individuals. In these individuals, digestion of the gluten-containing diet leads to the formation of gliadin peptides. These peptides result in the following immune reactions:

Antibodies associated with celiac disease are: 

* Anti-gliadin antibodies

* Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-ttG)

* Anti-endomysial antibodies

Microscopic findings include:

* Villi atrophy and flattening

* Crypt hyperplasia

* Increased intraepithelial T cells

questions.text: 164. The mutations implicated in hereditary pancreatitis are:
questions.solution:
Hereditary Pancreatitis is caused due to the mutation of PRSS1 and SPINK1.

Hereditary pancreatitis is an autosomal dominant disorder due to mutations of the cationic trypsinogen gene, PRSS1. Mutations in PRSS1 cause premature activation of trypsinogen to trypsin and cause abnormalities of ductal secretion, both of which promote acute pancreatitis. SPINK1 protein blocks the active binding site of trypsin, and mutations in the SPINK1 protein are likely to predispose to acute pancreatitis.

Recurrent episodes of pancreatitis are usually seen in childhood, between 5 and 10 years of age, having no identifiable cause. The presentation, natural history, diagnosis, and treatment of this disease are similar to those for other causes of pancreatitis. Hereditary pancreatitis should be suspected in any patient who experiences at least two episodes of acute pancreatitis without obvious risk factors, such as trauma, hyperlipidemia, gallstones, or pancreas divisum. It should also be considered in any child with acute pancreatitis and a family history of this disease.

questions.text: 166. Which of the following pairs of electron microscopy finding and disease is incorrect?

choices.text: Linear deposits along the basement membrane - Goodpasture syndrome
Mesangial and paramesangial dense deposits - IgA nephropathy

questions.solution:
Basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is seen in the case of Alport syndrome. 

Alport syndrome, also known as hereditary nephritis, is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. This is a major component of the basement membranes. The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. Ocular manifestations include anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal dystrophy.

Light microscopy appears normal during the first decade of life. Later glomeruli may have mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening. This may lead to progressive sclerosis of the glomerulus. Electron microscopy shows diffuse thickening and thinning along with splitting of glomerular and tubular basement membranes. It is seen as a characteristic basket-weaving appearance of lamina densa, as shown below.



No specific therapy is recommended to treat Alport syndrome. Proteinuria can be treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin 2 receptor blockers.

Subepithelial deposits are seen on electron microscopy in cases of membranous nephropathy. It typically has a noninflammatory pathology. It presents as a nephrotic syndrome in most patients. Non-nephrotic proteinuria, hematuria, and mild hypertension can be seen in some cases.

questions.text: 167. A 45-year-old male patient presented to your clinic with complaints of slowly progressive reddish-brown skin lesions, with itching and scaling located predominantly over the non-sun-exposed parts of his body for the past couple of years. On examination, there are bluish and reddish-brown ulcerated plaques and nodules. Histopathology reveals the following findings. Identify the structure marked by the arrow in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The arrow mark is pointing towards a collection of atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis termed as Pautrier microabscess. This is an important histopathologic feature of mycosis fungoides, which is the most common type of cutaneous T cell lymphoma.

Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma is commonly seen in men more than 40 years of age. Mycosis fungoides is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Other types include Sezary syndrome, which occurs when the malignant cells from the skin enter the circulation. It is characterized by erythroderma.

questions.text: 168. A woman with third-degree uterine prolapse wants to avoid hysterectomy. The surgeon plans a uterine-sparing procedure using the Purandare sling operation. Which ligament is utilized in this sling procedure?
questions.solution:
The Purandare sling operation suspends the uterus using the round ligament, which is looped and sutured to provide uterine support while preserving fertility.

Other options:

Option B: Uterosacral ligaments provide posterior support and are used in procedures like uterosacral colpopexy, but are not utilized in the Purandare sling operation.

Option C: Cardinal ligaments provide lateral support to the uterus but are not involved in the Purandare sling technique.

Option D: The broad ligament is a false support of the uterus, as it mainly serves as a peritoneal fold rather than providing direct structural support. It acts as a conduit for blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves, but does not contribute significantly to uterine suspension.

questions.text: 169. A 47-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis associated with alcohol abuse presented with a 2-day history of shortness of breath. Before this symptom developed, he had been treated with repeated thoracentesis of the right side for cirrhosis-associated hydrothorax. A chest X-ray was taken and is given below. What is the diagnosis, along with its other potential causes?

choices.text: Pleural effusion; Rupture of hydatid cyst

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of shortness of breath, history of thoracentesis, with the chest x-ray showing the presence of both air and fluid within the pleural space, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Hydropneumothorax. One of the other causes of Hydropneumothorax is Bronchopleural fistula.



On an erect chest radiograph, recognition of hydro pneumothorax can be rather easy and is classically shown as an air-fluid level. It can occur due to:

* Thoracentesis 

* Rupture of a hydatid cyst

* Thoracic trauma

* Bronchopleural fistula

* Oesophagopleural fistula

Other options:

Option A: Lung Abscess presents with a cavity containing a gas-fluid level. It can occur due to aspiration, tuberculosis or pneumonia.



Option B: In Pneumothorax, the patient presents with a history of breathlessness, and chest X-ray will show hyperlucency (darker area without lung markings) with inward shifting of the visceral pleural line (sharp white line). In tension pneumothorax, there will be a mediastinal shift to the opposite side. It can occur due to Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

The image below shows a left pneumothorax with total left lung collapse and tracheal deviation to the right.



Option D: Pleural effusion is characterised by homogeneous opacification of the lower chest with obliteration of the costophrenic angle and the hemidiaphragm. It can be exudative or transudative.

questions.text: 170. Consider the cycle showing management sequence of sudden disaster. Which of the following is correctly matched?
questions.solution:
The number 2 is correctly matched as rehabilitation.

1 - Response

2 - Rehabilitation

3 - Mitigation

4 - Prevention

5 - Preparedness

Rehabilitation includes measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control. Control programs for vector-borne diseases should be intensified in the emergency and rehabilitation periods, especially in areas where such diseases are known to be endemic. Of special concern are dengue fever and malaria (mosquitoes), leptospirosis and rat bite fever (rats), typhus (lice, fleas), and plague (fleas).



Disaster management includes the following aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: Immediate actions taken after a disaster to manage mass casualties and reduce further harm. It includes search and rescue, first aid, triage, and field care.

2. Rehabilitation: Focuses on restoring pre-disaster conditions by taking steps such as:

* Water supply restoration

* Basic sanitation and personal hygiene

* Food safety measures

* Vector control

3. Mitigation and Prevention: Long-term measures to prevent hazards from becoming disasters or reduce their effects. Includes structural modifications, disaster risk reduction strategies, and environmental policies.

4. Preparedness: These are actions taken before a disaster to ensure readiness. It includes training, drills, emergency stockpiling, and early warning systems.

questions.text: 171. A 4-year-old child is diagnosed with strabismic amblyopia in the right eye. Best-corrected visual acuity is 6/60 in the right eye and 6/6 in the left eye. There is a history of constant right exotropia since infancy. Cycloplegic refraction is +1.00 D in both eyes. Fundus examination is normal. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this patient’s condition?

choices.text: The right eye is suppressed, and the left eye needs to be patched.
The left eye is suppressed, and the right eye needs to be patched.
The right eye is suppressed, and the right eye needs to be patched.
The left eye is suppressed, and the left eye needs to be patched.

questions.solution:
This child has strabismic amblyopia in the right eye, caused by a longstanding right exotropia (outward deviation of the eye). In this case, the right eye is suppressed, and the left eye is patched.

The better eye must be prevented from seeing or from seeing clearly, to allow an amblyopic eye to be used. This can be done by complete occlusion, using a patch that covers the better eye and is fixed to the skin with adhesive material to prevent the child from removing it. Occlusion should be total because, if both eyes are used together, active inhibition of the squinting eye that was done using patching rapidly undoes any improvement achieved. 

The regimen, full-time or part-time, depends on the age of the patient and the density of amblyopia. The younger the patient, the more rapid the improvement, but there is a greater risk of inducing amblyopia in the normal eye. It is very important to monitor visual acuity regularly in both eyes during treatment.

questions.text: 172. A 45-year-old woman with pain and tenderness around the base of her right thumb is diagnosed with de Quervain's tenosynovitis. The tendon of which of the following muscle is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The tendons of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis are affected in de Quervain's tenosynovitis.

The abductor pollicis longus runs under the first dorsal compartment of the extensor retinaculum and splits into two parts. One is attached to the radial side of the first metacarpal base and the other to the trapezium. The extensor pollicis brevis is medial to the abductor pollicis longus.



De Quervain's tenosynovitis is a condition characterized by pain, tenderness, and swelling over the radial styloid process, which results from inflammation of the common sheath of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons. On examination, tenderness is localized to the radial styloid process. 

Finklestein's test may be performed where the patient's thumb is grasped and the hand is abducted in ulnar deviation. This maneuver results in excruciating pain over the radial styloid, which indicates de Quervain's tenosynovitis.

The Eichoff test is performed by instructing the patient to make a fist with the thumb enclosed within the fingers, followed by ulnar deviation of the wrist. A positive test is indicated by pain over the radial styloid region, which indicates de Quervain's tenosynovitis.

The following images show the Eichoff test and Finklestein's test.





De Quervain's tenosynovitis is treated conservatively with a crepe bandage or slab. Analgesics and ultrasonic radiation can also be provided. Severe cases may need slitting and excision of the tendon sheath.

questions.text: 173. A 30-year-old man with chronic osteomyelitis presented with purulent discharge from a wound in his right leg. The following test is performed with the bacteria isolated from the wound discharge. Which of the following is a feature of the bacteria?

choices.text: Cultured on buffered charcoal yeast agar
Alpha-hemolysis is seen on blood agar

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the laboratory test showing a positive tube coagulase test is likely indicative of an infection of Staphylococcus aureus. S. aureus contains protein A which is one of its virulence factors. 

S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus arranged in grape-like clusters that may cause various pyogenic infections like a carbuncle, furuncle, abscess, osteomyelitis, and even septicemia. S. aureus produces catalase, which converts hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen and produces bubbles, as shown below. (Option B) Buffered charcoal yeast agar is used to culture Legionella.



On nutrient agar culture, smooth, shiny, easily emulsifiable golden yellow-pigmented colonies are formed due to the presence of β-carotene. On blood agar, it shows a wide zone of beta (complete) hemolysis with sharp edges (Option D). It is not cultured in buffered charcoal yeast agar. (Option C) 

S. aureus is coagulase positive. The coagulase test can be done using two methods:

*

The tube test detects free coagulase. When 0.1 mL of an agar culture suspension of S. aureus is added to 0.5 mL of human or rabbit plasma in a test tube with an anticoagulant and incubated in a water bath at 37°C for 3–6 hours, the plasma clots and does not flow when the tube is tilted. This shows a tube coagulase-positive test. 

The below image shows positive and negative tube coagulase tests.



The slide test detects bound coagulase (clumping factor). The bacterial isolate is emulsified with a drop of saline and added to a drop of rabbit or human plasma. A prompt clumping of the cocci is suggestive of a positive test. It should be performed after ensuring the absence of autoagglutination and can be positive for S. aureus and for a few strains of coagulase-negative staphylococcus.

B. Secondary infection

questions.text: 174. A 32-year-old woman at 36 weeks gestation suffers a cardiac arrest in the emergency department. Despite 4 minutes of effective cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), there is no return of spontaneous circulation. The fetal heart rate is detected at 120 bpm. What is the next line of management?

choices.text: Continue CPR for another 10 minutes before cesarean section
Perform immediate cesarean section with a low transverse uterine incision
Perform immediate cesarean section with an upper segment vertical uterine incision
Wait until maternal circulation is restored, then proceed with cesarean section

questions.solution:
Immediate perimortem cesarean section with an upper segment vertical uterine incision is indicated in cases of maternal cardiac arrest occurring at or beyond 20 weeks of gestation, ideally at 24 weeks or more, depending on institutional protocol.

If there is no return of spontaneous circulation within four minutes of initiating high-quality cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), the goal is to deliver the fetus within five minutes of the arrest. This rapid delivery helps improve both maternal and fetal outcomes by relieving aortocaval compression and enhancing venous return.

In such emergency scenarios, an upper segment vertical incision is preferred because it offers faster and more direct access to the uterus and fetus. This approach bypasses the lower uterine segment, which may be underdeveloped or thinner in early gestation or during emergencies, and allows for a larger incision with better exposure, minimal bleeding, and quicker delivery.

Although a low transverse incision is generally favoured for elective or routine cesarean deliveries due to its superior healing profile, it is less suitable in emergencies as it takes more time and provides limited surgical access.

questions.text: 175. The image below shows the Y-shaped sutures in the lens. Which of the following statements about lens sutures is correct according to developmental anatomy?

choices.text: Anterior lens sutures are inverted Y-shaped, and posterior lens sutures are Y-shaped.
Anterior lens sutures are Y-shaped, and posterior lens sutures are inverted Y-shaped.
Both anterior and posterior lens sutures are inverted Y-shaped
Both anterior and posterior lens sutures are Y-shaped

questions.solution:
Anterior lens sutures are Y-shaped, and posterior lens sutures are inverted Y-shaped.

Lens consist of an inner nucleus and outer cortex. The fibres of the nucleus of the lens in the initial stages of development meet around sutures, which are anteriorly Y-shaped and posteriorly inverted Y-shaped.

Types of lens nucleus and their age of development: 

* Embryonic nucleus: Innermost nucleus formed at around 1–3 months of gestation

* Fetal nucleus: From 3 months of gestation till birth

* Infantile nucleus: From birth to puberty

* Adult nucleus

questions.text: 176. Which of the following correctly describes a cement line?

choices.text: Area consisting of inorganic matrix where two osteons meet
Small flattened space between adjoining lamellae

questions.solution:
An area consisting of an inorganic matrix where two osteons meet correctly describes a cement line.

The cement line is that place where the periphery of one osteon comes in contact with another osteon (or with interstitial lamellae). Along this line, there are no collagen fibres. The line consists mainly of an inorganic matrix.

Other options:

Option B: Small flattened spaces between lamellae are called lacunae. Each lacuna contains one osteocyte. 

Option C: Communication between the two lacunae is called Canaliculi. The canaliculi are occupied by delicate cytoplasmic processes of osteocytes. They network with each other and facilitate the diffusion of metabolic products between osteocytes.

Option D. The area surrounding an active osteoclast is called the Lacunae Howship or resorption bays. These are pit-like structures, and osteoclasts occupy these pits.

questions.text: 177. A neonate who was apparently normal at birth is brought to the emergency department with complaints of bilious vomiting. An upper gastrointestinal barium study was done and the image is given below. Identify the characteristic radiographic finding shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows the corkscrew sign which is a characteristic radiographic finding in midgut volvulus.

Midgut volvulus is a complication of malrotation of the bowel and may result in proximal bowel obstruction. It can occur at any age but it is commonly seen in the first few months of life. The baby presents with bilious vomiting, abdominal pain, and failure to thrive.

Characteristic radiographic signs include:

* Corkscrew sign - It is a barium meal study finding seen in midgut volvulus. It describes the spiraling of the duodenum and jejunum around the mesenteric vessels. 

It has been identified as a diagnostic indicator of midgut volvulus.

* Whirlpool sign - It is also known as the whirl sign. It is seen due to the rotation of the bowel around the mesentery leading to whorls of mesenteric vessels. It can be seen in ultrasound and CT scans.

The whirlpool sign on a CT is shown below:



Rigler's sign - It is also known as the double wall sign and it is an abdominal radiograph finding in pneumoperitoneum. Here, both the inner and outer walls of the bowel are visible.



Coffee bean sign - It is also known as the kidney bean sign or the bent inner-tube sign. It is a plain abdominal radiograph finding in the sigmoid volvulus, shown below.



Pearl PM1804: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign



 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 



 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign



 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 



 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign



 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.



Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 



 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.



 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.



 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).



Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: 178. Which of the following oral hypoglycemic drugs can cause vitamin B12 deficiency?
questions.solution:
Metformin is an oral hypoglycemic drug that can cause vitamin B12 deficiency.

Metformin interferes with the absorption of vitamin B12. Side effects of metformin are gastrointestinal disturbance like nausea, indigestion, abdominal cramps or bloating, diarrhoea, and lactic acidosis. Contraindications for metformin include a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) <30 ml/min and heart failure.

questions.text: 179. A positive Stallworthy sign is seen in
questions.solution:
A positive Stallworthy sign is seen in a low-lying placenta.

A positive Stallworthy sign is the slowing of the fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which soon recovers promptly as the pressure is released is suggestive of the presence of low-lying placenta, especially of posterior type.

Pearl PM2262: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.



 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.



 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.



 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.



 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.



 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 



 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.



 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 



 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.



 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.



 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.



 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: 181. Which of the following toxins causes endemic ascites?
questions.solution:
Pyrrolizidine causes endemic ascites.

The weed seeds of Crotalaria contain Pyrrolizidine alkaloids that are hepatotoxic. The millet Panicum Millaire gets adulterated with weed seeds of Crotalaria and produces symptoms of endemic Ascites, which is rapidly developing ascites and Jaundice. 

Preventive measures include:

* Sieving of millets at home

questions.text:
182. Which of the following strategies is ineffective in preventing post-LP headache?

LP: Lumbar puncture

choices.text: Performing LP in left lateral decubitus position
Inserting needle with bevel oriented in a cephalad to caudad direction

questions.solution:
Supplementing fluids is ineffective in preventing post-LP headache. Although routinely practiced for patient comfort, studies have shown that fluid supplementation does not reduce the risk of developing a post-LP headache. However, it may help reduce the severity of symptoms in patients who do develop a headache.

Effective strategies to reduce the incidence of post-LP headache are:

* Use of atraumatic needles like Sprotte and Whitacre

* Replacement of the stylet before the removal of the needle

* Performing LP in the lateral decubitus position

* Insertion of needle with bevel oriented in a cephalad to caudad direction (when using standard needle)

Ineffective strategies to reduce the incidence of post-LP headache are:

* Bed rest (up to 4 h) following LP

* Supplemental fluids

* Minimizing the volume of spinal fluid removed

* Immediate mobilization following LP

While some guidelines recommend bed rest and fluid intake for general comfort and observation, evidence from randomized controlled trials shows that these measures do not reduce the incidence of post-LP headache.

questions.text: 183. From which of the following layers does the regeneration of endometrium take place?
questions.solution:
The endometrium regenerates from the zona basalis.

The basal layer adjacent to the myometrium remains intact and is the source of new endometrium. This arises from the proliferation of the endometrial glandular remnants and the stroma of the interglandular connective tissue.

questions.text: 184. A 35-year-old male patient presents with complaints of fever and abdominal pain for the past couple of weeks. His past history is significant for bloody stools with colicky abdominal pain and tenesmus several weeks ago. Examination reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant. A CT scan of the abdomen is attached below. Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding the causative agent?

choices.text: Mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form
Causes flask shaped ulcer found in the jejunum
Characteristic anchovy paste is produced in the abscess

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and upper abdominal CT scan revealing an abscess in the right liver lobe are suggestive of amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. Causes a flask-shaped ulcer found in the jejunum is the incorrect statement. Flask-shaped ulcers occur in the colon.

Humans acquire infection by ingestion of food and water contaminated with mature quadrinucleate cysts in the faeces. So, a mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form. The ameboid trophozoite is the only form present in tissues. The cytoplasm may contain phagocytosed red blood cells, which is a pathognomonic feature.

It can manifest as acute intestinal amebiasis with symptoms of dysentery, lower abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. Low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhoea, weight loss, and fatigue are present in chronic amebiasis.

The amebic ulcer, which is flask-shaped, is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis. The ulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, the ulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoido-rectal region. A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon, which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.

The most common extraintestinal manifestation is amebic hepatitis or liver abscess. The contents are necrotic and bacteriologically sterile, with active amebae confined to the walls. A characteristic anchovy paste is produced in the abscess and seen on surgical drainage.

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating both amebic colitis and amebic liver abscess.

questions.text: 185. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies does not cause Hyperhomocysteinemia?
questions.solution:
Niacin deficiency does not cause hyperhomocysteinemia.

Elevated blood homocysteine is a significant risk factor for atherosclerosis, thrombosis, and hypertension. The condition is the result of a deficiency of Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6), Cobalamin (B12), and folic acid, failing to convert homocysteine to methionine, thus leading to hyperhomocysteinemia.

Pearl PM2304: Homocystinuria



The concept for treatment:

* Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.

* As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: 186. What is the recommended ratio of suture material length to length of suture line for appropriate wound closure?
questions.solution:
The recommended ratio of suture material length to length of suture line for appropriate wound closure is 4:1.

Jenkin's rule for abdominal closure states that the length of the suture should be at least four times the length of the wound. This calculation prevents the inappropriate length of suture material used for suture closure and thus helps in the correct closure of the suture line. If a ratio of less than this is achieved, the suture bites are likely to be too far apart and/or too tight. 

However, recent evidence suggests that a strategy of taking smaller bites (5 mm) with smaller space (5 mm) between them is associated with a lower rate of incisional hernia. This strategy achieves a ratio of suture to wound length even greater than 4:1.

questions.text: 187. As a part of evaluation, a psychiatrist enumerates all the colors of the rainbow to his patient. The next day, when the patient was asked to recollect these colors, he was unable to recollect the 6th color. The doctor mentioned the first few letters of the color, and then the patient answered. The function of which part of the brain is evaluated here?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, priming is being assessed, which depends on the functioning of the neocortex.

Priming is a form of nondeclarative memory that helps in recognizing words or objects to which the person was exposed previously. It is usually assessed by checking for increased reading speed, faster naming of objects, and faster recollection of getting a clue when presented with previously exposed information.

Memory is usually divided into two forms:

* Explicit or declarative memory is associated with consciousness or awareness.

* Implicit or non-declarative memory does not involve awareness and its retention. It does not involve the hippocampus in its processing.

Memory can also be classified as:

Short-term memory- lasts for a few seconds to minutes. Working memory is a form of short-term memory. It keeps the information available, usually for a very short time, until the individual plans some action based on it.

Long-term memory can be recollected after years or even for a lifetime. These memories are stored in various parts of the neocortex. The various types of memories, such as visual, auditory, olfactory, etc., are localized to the cortical regions.

Other options:

Option A: Striatum forms a part of the basal ganglia and is involved in decision-making functions, such as motor control, emotion, habit formation, and reward.

Option B: Amygdala, a component of the limbic system, is responsible for the control of emotions, behavior, and memory formation. 

Option C: The Cerebellum is responsible for the coordination of movement, maintaining posture and balance, muscle tone, and motor learning.

Pearl PM0907: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.





Pearl PM1607: Tests for evaluating attention, concentration and memory

Memory:

Memory is of 3 types:

* Immediate memory and recall are usually tested by digit span/ digit repetition test.

* Digit span test: Digits spelled at the rate of 1 digit per second. It is of two types: Digit forward and Digit backward.

* Digit forward: Reproduction of increasingly longer digits. E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 –5 –7 –9.

* Digit backward: Reproduction of longer digits in the backward direction. Eg: Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat it backward. 9 -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2.

* The above tests should be stopped when there are 2 successive failures. Hence 2 skips are not allowed.

* Recent memory: Ask them how they reached the hospital or what they ate for breakfast.

* Remote memory: Relevant questions from the past like close relative's birth dates. 

Attention:

* Is the patient's attention easily aroused and sustained?

* Digit span test.

Concentration:

* Is the patient easily distractable or can they concentrate?

* Serial subtraction test: Minimum of five subtractions done serially is taken into account

* Count backward from 20.

* Enumerate the months in reverse order.

questions.text: 188. A man with seizure disorder was hospitalized due to a recent exacerbation of seizure episodes. He was prescribed lacosamide as adjunctive therapy. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
Lacosamide blocks the voltage-gated sodium channels.

Lacosamide is a stereoselective enantiomer of the amino acid L-serine. It is used as adjunctive therapy for focal-onset seizures in patients older than 17 years.

It is the first anti-seizure drug, which prolongs the slow inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels and limits sustained repetitive firing, the neuronal firing pattern characteristic of focal seizures. Lacosamide also binds to collapsing response mediator protein-2 (CRMP-2), which is a phosphoprotein mainly expressed in the nervous system and involved in neuronal differentiation and control of axonal outgrowth. The role of CRMP-2 binding in seizure control is unknown.

Therapeutic Uses:

* It is used for both monotherapy and add-on therapy for focal-onset seizures in patients 17 years and older.

* It is mostly beneficial in hospitalised patients because it is available in an intravenous formulation, has minimal hepatic metabolism, and has no adverse respiratory effects.

questions.text: 189. A 23-year-old sexually active woman presents with lower abdominal pain, fever, and purulent cervical discharge for 3 days. On bimanual exam, cervical motion tenderness and bilateral adnexal tenderness were noted. Her β-hCG test is negative. The most appropriate outpatient antibiotic regimen for this patient is:

choices.text: Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 14 days ± Metronidazole
Azithromycin 1 g orally once + Metronidazole 2 g orally once
Cefotetan 2 g IV every 12 hours + Doxycycline 100 mg orally or IV every 12 hours
Clindamycin 900 mg IV every 8 hours + Gentamicin IV/IM (loading + maintenance)

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests the diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) for which Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 14 days ± Metronidazole is an appropriate regimen. 

CDC recommended outpatient regimen for PID (mild to moderate cases) is Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose (covers N.gonorrhoeae) plus doxycycline 100 mg PO BID for 14 days (covers Chlamydia trachomatis), and metronidazole 500 mg PO BID for 14 days is optional (covers anaerobes, such as Bacteroides). 

Other options:

Option B: Azithromycin + Metronidazole: This is not standard therapy for PID; azithromycin is used for chlamydia but not for full PID coverage.

Option C: Cefotetan + Doxycycline: This is part of the inpatient regimen, not the outpatient.

Option D:  Clindamycin + Gentamicin: This is an inpatient regimen, typically used in cases of tubo-ovarian abscess.

questions.text: 190. A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester is diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria and her blood smear was found to be positive for plasmodium falciparum. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Falciparum malaria during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy should be treated with Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT).

Treatment of uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria during the first trimester of pregnancy consists of Quinine. Quinine can induce hypoglycemia, so pregnant patients are advised to eat regularly while on this treatment regimen. During the second and third trimesters, area-specific ACT is the preferred treatment option. 

* For all states except north-eastern states: Artesunate and Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine

* For north-eastern states: Artemether and Lumefantrine.

Other options:

Option C: Chloroquine is used for the treatment of P. vivax malaria during pregnancy. 

Option D: Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnant patients.

questions.text:
191. A 64-year-old man with end-stage renal disease presents with lethargy and muscle weakness. He has missed his last dialysis session. His serum potassium is found to be 6.8 mM. Arrange the following ECG changes in the order they typically appear with increasing severity of progression.

* Tall peaked T waves 

* Loss of P waves

* Widened QRS complex

* Sine wave pattern
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of changes is 

* Tall peaked T waves 

* Loss of P waves

* Widened QRS complex

* Sine wave pattern

Hyperkalemia is an increase in the levels of serum potassium >5.5 mM. It is a medical emergency and has to be treated when ECG changes are present or severe hyperkalemia (serum K >6.5) without ECG changes.  Features include cardiac arrhythmias which include sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation and asystole.

ECG shows tall and peaked T waves, loss of P waves, widening of QRS complexes, and sine wave pattern. The relationship between specific ECG changes and blood potassium levels is inconsistent and may have limited diagnostic value. Laboratory testing remains essential for accurate diagnosis.



Management is as follows 

* Intravenous infusion of 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate for 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. It helps to antagonise the cardiac effects.

* Intravenous regular insulin 10 units followed by 50mL of 50 % dextrose. This helps in shifting the plasma K+ into the cells

* Nebulisation with β2 agonists such as albuterol or salbutamol is effective. 

* Cation exchange resins, diuretics and or dialysis are useful to remove the potassium.

questions.text:
192. A 29-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks' gestation is in active labor. She suddenly experiences a gush of fluid per vaginum. On vaginal examination, the umbilical cord is palpated below the presenting part. A CTG tracing is obtained (see image). Based on the CTG tracing and clinical findings, which type of deceleration is most likely present?

CTG- Cardiotocography
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of cord prolapse, in which variable decelerations are present on cardiotocography (CTG). 

Variable decelerations are abrupt in onset, often appear as V-shaped or U-shaped on CTG, and frequently show shouldering (brief accelerations before and after the deceleration). They vary in timing, depth, and duration, and are classically caused by umbilical cord compression, as seen in cord prolapse in this case.

Other options: 

Option A: Early decelerations are gradual and mirror uterine contractions. They result from fetal head compression, not cord compression, and lack the sharp V-shape or shouldering seen here.

Option B: Late decelerations are gradual decelerations that begin after the peak of contraction, indicating uteroplacental insufficiency. They are not abrupt and lack the V-shape or variability in timing.

Option D: A sinusoidal pattern is smooth, regular, wave-like, and typically reflects severe fetal anemia or hypoxia. It does not involve sharp decelerations or shouldering.

questions.text: 194. The couple protection rate of a community is 60%. What does this percentage signify?

choices.text: 60% of eligible couples are using contraception
60% of eligible couples are effectively protected against childbirth
40% of births are third or higher-order births

questions.solution:
A couple protection rate of 60% indicates that 60% of eligible couples in the community are effectively protected against unplanned childbirth through the use of one or more approved family planning methods. This encompasses both the effective utilization of contraception and procedures such as sterilization.

The couple protection rate (CPR) is an indicator of contraception practices in the community. Attaining a 60% CPR would be highly effective in restricting all third or higher-order births. It is considered a dominant factor for the reduction of the net reproduction rate.

Other options: 

Option A: While a high CPR likely indicates high contraceptive use, it also considers the effectiveness of those methods in preventing unplanned pregnancies. 60% of couples using contraception doesn't guarantee all these methods are successful in every case.

Option C: A high CPR would likely decrease unintended pregnancies. However, it doesn't indicate the exact percentage of unintended pregnancies in a community. 

Option D: A high CPR might lead to fewer third or higher-order births indirectly, but it does not measure the same.

Pearl PM1715: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).



* In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.

* In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

* It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.

* It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.

* Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: 195. A young patient started neglecting one-half of his body after an accident. He uses only his right side of the body, trims his beard only on the right side of his face, and reads only the right half of the page. There are no apparent primary visual, auditory, or somatosensory defects. This occurs due to an injury in which of the following parts of the brain?

choices.text: Superior temporal gyrus of the categorical hemisphere
Inferior parietal lobule of the representational hemisphere
Superior part of the hippocampus and mammillary bodies
Angular gyrus of the categorical hemisphere

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is neglecting one-half of his body. This is called unilateral inattention and neglect which occurs due to an injury to the inferior parietal lobule of the representational hemisphere.

In our human brain, one hemisphere is specialised for sequential-analytic processes (the categorical hemisphere or dominant hemisphere) and another is specialised for visuospatial relations (the representational hemisphere or the non-dominant hemisphere).

Lesions in the representational hemisphere lead to:

* Astereognosis - the inability to identify objects by feeling them due to a lesion in the parietal lobe

* Agnosia - inability to recognize objects by a particular sensory modality, even though the sensory modality itself is intact. This commonly occurs due to a lesion in the parietal lobe

* Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognise faces

* Unilateral inattention and neglect - Patients neglect one-half of their bodies and may experience personal neglect syndrome. It occurs due to an injury to the inferior parietal lobule and a region of the posterior parietal cortex close to the occipital lobe

The function of the non-dominant side of the parietal lobe is spatial orientation and constructional skills. Its lesion causes spatial disorientation, constructional apraxia, neglect of the non-dominant side, dressing apraxia, and homonymous hemianopia. 

The somatic sensory area and related parts of the posterior parietal lobe project to the premotor cortex. It is associated with aiming and manipulating the hands at an object and hand-eye coordination. Neurons in this posterior parietal cortex contribute to the descending pathways involved in motor control.

The functions of the dominant hemisphere are logical, analytical, sequential thinking, and verbal tasks, such as math, language forms, and philosophy. In this hemisphere, the parietal lobe is concerned with calculation, language, planned movement, and appreciation of size, shape, weight, and texture. A lesion here causes dyscalculia, dysphasia, dyslexia, apraxia, agnosia, and homonymous hemianopia. 

Other options:

Option A: Lesions in the superior temporal gyrus of the categorical hemisphere lead to Wernicke's aphasia. 

Option C: Lesions in the hippocampus, mamillary bodies, nucleus basalis of Meynert, and areas of the forebrain result in memory disturbances.

Option D: Lesions in the angular gyrus of the categorical hemisphere result in anomic aphasia.

questions.text:
196. A 64-year-old chronic smoker presented to an emergency department with dyspnea and a productive cough. His oxygen saturation is 82% on room air. Arterial blood gas shows pH 7.25, PaCO2 55 mmHg, PaO2 62 mmHg. He was started on NIPPV. For which of the following is NIPPV recommended?

NIPPV- Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease with Type 2 Respiratory failure, for which NIPPV(non-invasive positive pressure ventilation) is recommended to reduce the hospital length of stay. 

NIPPV is initiated in respiratory failure and COPD(chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) patients with PaCO2>45mmhg, which results in a significant reduction in hospital length of stay, mortality rate, need for intubation, complications of therapy.

Contraindications to NIPPV are cardiovascular instability, impaired mental status, copious secretions, inability to cooperate, craniofacial abnormalities, extreme obesity, and significant burns.

questions.text: 197. The given image shows newly discovered salivary gland tissues seen on PSMA (prostate-specific membrane antigen) PET/CT. These salivary gland tissues primarily overlie the _____
questions.solution:
The given PSMA PET/CT shows the recently discovered pair of nasopharyngeal salivary glands, which are present over the torus tubarius, the cartilaginous structure that supports the entrance of the eustachian tube.

These newly identified glands have been named the “tubarial salivary glands”. These glands extend from the pharyngeal wall to the Rosenmüllers’ fossa.

These gland cells showed almost 100% cytoplasmic expression of PSMA, similar to the PSMA-ligand uptake of minor salivary glands in the palate. Bilateral PSMA-positive areas were seen on PSMA PET/CT, which extend from the skull base along the posterolateral pharyngeal wall, on the pharyngeal side of the superior pharyngeal constrictor muscle, with a PSMA-positive mass overlying the torus tubarius.

Note: PSMA PET/CT is positron emission tomography/computed tomography with prostate-specific membrane antigen ligands.

questions.text: 198. In a healthy adult, the serum potassium level remains within the normal range despite excessive dietary intake of potassium. Which of the following is the primary site of this regulation?
questions.solution:
The distal tubule and collecting ducts are the primary sites of the regulation of K+ excretion based on dietary intake.

The renal mechanisms that maintain the extracellular K+ concentration despite wide variations in dietary intake are known as external potassium balance. A combination of filtration, reabsorption, and secretion regulates the urinary excretion of potassium.

In the kidney, K+ is freely filtered across the glomerular capillaries since it is not bound to plasma proteins. 65% of the filtered K+ is reabsorbed by the proximal convoluted tubule, while another 25 - 30% is reabsorbed at the loop of Henle. The amount of reabsorption occurring at these two sites is relatively constant.

The regulation of K+ excretion depending on the dietary intake of potassium occurs mainly at the distal tubule and collecting ducts as follows:

* In the case of high dietary intake, there is an increase in the secretion of K+ into the lumen via the Na+-K+ ATPase pump on the basolateral membrane and passive diffusion into the tubular fluid

* In the case of low dietary intake, there is a decrease in the secretion of K+ and increased reabsorption.

questions.text: 199. Which of the following conditions is not associated with a cough impulse?
questions.solution:
Cough impulse is not seen in primary hydrocele.

Cough impulse refers to the impulse felt on palpation of a swelling, either as a thrill, as seen in (varicocele, lymph varix), or an expansile impulse where the swelling increases in size when a patient is asked to cough, which is otherwise not normally felt. Cough impulse is a positive clinical finding in swellings that are in continuity with the abdominal (inguinal hernia), pleural (empyema necessitans), or cranial cavities and spinal canal (meningocele), as coughing increases the pressure in that compartment, which is represented by the impulse. 

Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis. In the case of a primary hydrocoele, as the fluid is collected within a closed sac, a cough impulse is unlikely to be seen. However, in the case of a congenital hydrocoele due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis, a cough impulse may be positive as a thrill. Important positive clinical findings in a hydrocoele are that they are irreducible,  the testes cannot be palpated separately, ability to get above the swelling, and transillumination of the swelling.

Other options:

Option A: Saphena varix refers to the saccular enlargement of the termination of the long saphenous vein at the saphenous opening. A cough impulse felt in a saphena varix is called a positive Morrissey's test and indicates sapheno-femoral incompetence.

Option B: Empyema necessitans is a rare complication of empyema, characterized by the extension of undrained pleural pus through the parietal pleura into the chest wall. The persistent inflammatory response leads to sinus tract formation, allowing the pus to track externally. Clinically, it presents as a boggy swelling on the chest wall, often associated with a cough impulse and localized intercostal tenderness.

Option D: Meningocele is a neural tube defect presenting as a sacral swelling that may be associated with a tuft of hair. Increased intra-abdominal pressure from coughing is transmitted to the CSF, leading to a cough impulse as the swelling is in communication with the subarachnoid space.

questions.text: 200. The electrocardiograph of a neonate, presenting with the following facial rash, is suggestive of a complete heart block. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given findings of a periorbital rash with ECG findings of a complete heart block are suggestive of neonatal lupus erythematosus. It is most likely to be associated with anti-Ro antibodies.

Neonatal lupus results from the passive transfer of maternal IgG autoantibodies (anti-Ro and anti-La) to the fetus. Hence, mothers with a known history of SLE or those who are positive for autoantibodies should undergo screening with fetal echocardiography. Detection of anti-Ro antibodies in a newborn is specific for neonatal lupus syndrome.

Clinical manifestations of neonatal lupus include a characteristic annular or macular rash typically affecting the face (especially the periorbital area), trunk, and scalp. The rash typically appears within the first 6 weeks of life after exposure to ultraviolet light and may last for 3-4 months.

The most feared complication is congenital heart block. Conduction system abnormalities range from prolongation of the PR interval to complete heart block. In severe cases, they can develop progressive cardiomyopathy. Conduction system abnormalities can be detected in utero by fetal echocardiogram beginning at 16 weeks of gestational age. Other noncardiac features include hepatitis, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia.

Treatment options include corticosteroids (dexamethasone or betamethasone), intravenous immunoglobulins, plasmapheresis, hydroxychloroquine, and terbutaline, which are given to pregnant women with anti-Ro or anti-La antibodies to prevent occurrence or progression of fetal cardiac abnormalities. Treatment for neonates is directed at specific organ involvement. With cardiac pacing, children with conduction system disease in the absence of cardiomyopathy have an excellent prognosis. 

Other Options:

Option A: Serology for rubella antibodies is done to confirm congenital rubella syndrome, which can have heart defects (most commonly patent ductus arteriosus). However, other features of the syndrome, like sensorineural hearing loss, blueberry muffin rash, and cataracts, are not present in this patient.

The given image shows a blueberry muffin rash seen in congenital rubella syndrome:



Option B: Serology for anti-treponemal antibodies is done to confirm congenital syphilis. Heart block and periorbital rash are not the features of congenital syphilis. In congenital syphilis, the maculopapular rash is characteristically present on the palms and soles. There will be hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes.

The given image shows maculopapular rash in congenital syphilis involving the soles:



Option C: Serology for anti-dsDNA antibodies is a highly specific test to diagnose systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Features of SLE include malar rash, arthralgia, serositis, etc. These antibodies will be present in the mother but not in the baby.

The given image shows malar rash in SLE:
